TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the bombing of Darwin on 19 February 1942, and is of the opinion that:

TAB.TAB: (i)we, as a nation, should pay tribute to the 243 allied personnel and civilians who lost their lives in the first air raids on Darwin 50 years ago,

(ii)an enormous debt of gratitude is owed to the Australian, American, British, Dutch and Canadian military personnel who served in the Northern Territory during World War II, along with civilian personnel,

(iii)we should remember the hardships faced by evacuees, more than 1000 women and 900 children, who were forced to leave their husbands, fathers, sons, homes and possessions, sometimes with only a few hours' notice, and
(iv)the Northern Territory Government should be commended for organising the memorial year; and

PARA.TAB: (b)trusts that the commemoration will provide lasting recognition for those who served in the Battle of Australia and ensure that their sacrifices are never forgotten.
I seek leave to make a statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, on 19 February, the commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the bombing of Darwin was conducted in Darwin. There was a large contingent of former veterans and many other civilians from throughout Australia, and many of the allied nations associated with us in World War II gathered in Darwin for this very particular and important commemoration. I was pleased that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), along with a number of Government Ministers and Opposition shadow Ministers, were able to attend the important functions.

PARA.TAB: The motion I have put forward mentions the tributes we should pay to those who lost their lives 50 years ago, the debt of gratitude we owe to the service personnel of all our allied nations, and, very importantly, the evacuees and the families who were forced out of Darwin in 1941 and 1942. Throughout this year the Northern Territory Government has arranged a very important program which acknowledges the importance of this memorial year. This will have particular relevance to the thousands of veterans who will return to Darwin.

So far there have been a number of very important functions and there have been addresses to those functions by the Prime Minister, the Chief Minister and a number of other important personnel. I seek leave to table, for the interest of the Senate, a series of documents that have related to this matter so far. I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an index of these documents.

SPEECH.PARA: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

This Bill is an Omnibus Bill containing minor administrative amendments to the following legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy Portfolio, the Meat Inspection Act 1983; the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978; the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967; and the Wheat Marketing Act 1989.

The amendments to this Act provide for the definition of `authorised officer' to limit the number of such officers to only those people appointed by the Secretary. Currently the definition of authorised officer extends to all officers within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in addition to those appointed by the Secretary.
Since the formation of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in 1987, such a wide definition has not been altogether necessary.

The amended definition will be the same as that which exists for authorised officer in the Export Control Act 1982. The Secretary will continue to have the power to appoint people outside the Department to be authorised officers.

Secondly the Bill makes the Act consistent with current criminal law policy of omitting references to monetary penalties where terms of imprisonment are provided for. The provisions of Section 4B of the Crimes Act 1914 will apply. For each 12 months of imprisonment provided for in the Meat Inspection Act 1983 as the maximum penalty, a court may impose a monetary penalty of up to $6,000 instead of or in addition to the imprisonment penalty for individuals, or 5 times that amount for corporations.
This obviates the need to amend the Meat Inspection Act 1983 when policy as to the relativity between imprisonment penalties and monetary penalties changes.
Where an offence carries a monetary penalty only, the maximum penalty is increased by the Bill to more closely correlate with the original real value of the maximum penalty for the offence.
The Bill also amends the regulation making power to beyond doubt the power to make regulations for the remission of fees paid.

The Bill also incorporates into the Meat Inspection Act 1983 a new offence of authorised officers receiving goods or services from the owner of a prescribed premises without the written approval of the Secretary. This offence was introduced into the Export Control Act 1982 in 1991.

Section 35 of the Meat Inspection Act 1983 currently prohibits the owner of a prescribed premises from providing goods or services to an authorised officer. This amendment complements that provision by prohibiting the receipt of goods or services by authorised officers. Domestic meat inspection legislation must demonstrate the importance of integrity of inspection staff.
The amendments to this Act are designed to improve the efficiency of its administration in three respects.

The first amendment transfers responsibility for determining the form of audited financial statements required under the Act, from the Minister for Finance to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. This will simplify administration of assistance programs under this Act, as all requirements of the Act would become the responsibility of one Minister.
It will also bring administration of programs under this Act into line with similar assistance programs administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

The second amendment permits acquittal of program expenditures by the senior executive officer of the State organisation or approved body receiving Commonwealth funds. Currently acquittal can only be made by the State Auditors-General. This will expedite acquittal of program expenditures and recognises the independence of State Auditors-General.

The third amendment makes the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory eligible to receive assistance under the Act. When the Act was drafted the Territories were administered by the Commonwealth, but now they are self-governing. It is important they again have the same eligibility for funding as the States.

The amendment extends section 8H of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 to enable delegation of routine Joint Authority powers under subsidiary Acts like the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Act 1967 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Act 1967. It corrects a drafting oversight in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1991 and maximises the potential gains resulting from the streamlining of administration under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967.

This amendment will extend by two months, to 1 September, the date by which the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) is required to submit its Corporate Plan to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for approval. This change will more closely align the development of this Plan with the AWB's financial year, which commences on 1 October. The amendments will also provide for the preparation of Annual Operational Plans, based on the Corporate Plan, by 1 October, again better reflecting the AWB's budgetary cycle.

The sections concerning Ministerial approval of the AWB's Annual Operational Plans will be amended to remove the requirement for Ministerial approval of the AWB's Annual Operational Plan in line with the recommendations of the Davis Review of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities.

That review considered that Ministerial approval of Annual Operating Plans conflicted with the principle of managerial autonomy, since operational plans only detail how objectives and strategies already approved in the Corporate Plan will be achieved.

This aspect of the Davis Review has already been implemented for the wool industry, in sections 35 and 36 of the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991. The amendment therefore, will result in a requirement for the AWB's Annual Operational Plan to be submitted to the Minister for information only before the commencement of the AWB's financial year.
None of the proposed amendments affect Government expenditure and they will not have any staffing implications for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
POULTRY INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE

AMENDMENT BILL 1991 This Bill provides for amendments to the Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965 to allow the Commonwealth to recover costs incurred in collecting and disbursing outstanding Commonwealth Hen Levies and for those costs incurred to be reimbursed from the Poultry Industry Trust Fund.

The amendments are part of a strategy developed in consultation with industry to wind up the Poultry Industry Trust Fund as soon as possible and then allow the repeal of the Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965.

The Commonwealth Hen Levy was imposed by legislation for the assistance of the egg industry through the equalisation of returns between domestic and export sales. The levy was paid into the Poultry Industry Trust Fund and distributed to the States and Territories for the assistance of the industry. The levy ceased in 1987 but the legislation continues to operate to enable the recovery of outstanding debts, the payment of debts recovered into the Fund and to permit disbursement of monies in the Fund. When any outstanding levies have been recovered, the money is to be used for the benefit of the Australian egg industry.

At the end of June 1991 the Trust Fund had a balance of almost $670 000 and outstanding debts owed by eleven egg producers, all in New South Wales, amounted to $1.7 million. The majority of the debts are the subject of legal actions for recovery in New South Wales Courts and while some amounts may be irrecoverable, all possible avenues are being pursued to collect the debts.

The Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Act 1988 allows the Commonwealth to recover from rural industries the cost of collecting and disbursing funds raised through levies and charges on rural production and exports.

However the Primary Industries (Recovery of Levy Collection Expenses) Act 1988 did not amend the Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965 to allow such recovery of expenses for Hen Levy collection. Previously the Commonwealth had entered into agency agreements with the States for the collection of levies and the Poultry Assistance Act 1965 allowed the Minister to make a determination for the States to be reimbursed for costs incurred from the Poultry Industry Trust Fund. Accordingly there was no provision in the Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965 for the Commonwealth to obtain reimbursement of collection expenses.

The New South Wales Egg Corporation, the statutory egg marketing authority in that State, signed the agency agreement with the Commonwealth. Following deregulation in the New South Wales egg industry and the termination of the Egg Corporation in October 1990, the Commonwealth assumed the responsibility of collecting all outstanding Hen Levies. While litigation proceedings are continuing for the collection of these outstanding levies, the costs of these proceedings and related expenses are incurred by the Commonwealth.

It is necessary then to amend the Poultry Industry Assistance Act to ensure that the egg industry meets the same obligations as other Australian agricultural industries by paying for any costs associated with the collection and disbursement of outstanding Hen Levies from the Poultry Industry Trust Fund.

It is expected that the major costs that may have to be met by the Commonwealth in collecting Hen Levies will be court costs in the event of litigation proceedings being unsuccessful, any associated legal costs incurred by the Australian Government Solicitor's Office and any charges made by that Office for its services.

These amendments will not prevent monies from the Fund being used for the existing legislative purposes of providing assistance to the industry or providing funds for research and development projects, subject to sufficient amounts being retained to cover likely levy collection costs.

Following consultation with industry, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy determined that available Trust Fund monies be transferred to a special sub account of the Egg Industry Research and Development Fund so they can be used for the benefit of the egg industry as a whole. The sub account has been established and an initial $500 000 was transferred to it in July 1991. The monies in the sub account are to be managed conservatively by the Egg Industry Research and Development Council for specific industry purposes of producer training and economic and market research.

Any levies recovered will be paid into the Trust Fund and transferred to the Egg Industry Research and Development Fund, after ensuring that sufficient funds remain in the Poultry Industry Trust Fund to meet Commonwealth collection costs. An accurate estimation of the likely costs is difficult but following consultation with the Australian Government Solicitor's Office and industry it is judged that the current balance of $180 000 will be adequate.
It is expected that litigation proceedings will be reviewed periodically to gauge likelihood of future levy recovery. Decisions taken regarding future legal action will follow these reviews.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No.4) 1991
This Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of aspects.

The Bill will implement the changes initially announced in the March Industry Statement to taxation depreciation arrangements. Following consultations with business and professionals, further details of the changes to depreciation were announced on 26 September 1991.
The Bill also introduces amendments to prevent avoidance of tax under various provisions which authorise tax deductions for capital expenditure incurred in income producing activities.

Another amendment provides for a deferral (or "rollover") of balancing adjustments that may arise on the disposal of property to which the various capital allowance rules have applied (eg. plant depreciation or the various capital allowances for mining property).

The Bill will provide a company that is the beneficial owner of shares held by a trustee or partnership, with a rebate for its share of net income of the trust or partnership that relates to the dividends paid on those shares.

The Bill will also bolster the trading stock provisions of the law by ensuring that tax deductions under section 51 for buying trading stock are not allowed until the stock is on hand. This will remedy a weakness exposed in a recent Federal Court case.
This Bill will also amend the tax law to streamline the Tax File Number arrangements.
The capital gains tax rollover provisions for transfers of partnership assets to wholly-owned companies are also to be amended to correct a technical deficiency.

Other minor amendments to be given effect by this Bill relate to foreign source income measures; foreign exchange gains and losses, the rehabilitation of mining, quarrying and petroleum sites; the research and development provisions; substantiation; and the taxation of education entry payments.
Finally, the Bill contains a number of minor technical or procedural amendments of the tax laws.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
The Bill will implement a number of announced changes to depreciation arrangements.

For the first time, a definition of effective life will be inserted into the income tax law. Broadly, effective life will be defined as the period during which an item of plant can reasonably be expected to be used for income producing purposes by any person.
This definition will facilitate the matching of depreciation deductions to the income generated by the item of plant.

The new effective life definition will apply to assets acquired on or after 1 July 1991. However, following representations from business groups, assets acquired after 12 March 1991 will be eligible for the new effective life rules from 1 July 1991.

Consistent with self-assessment principles, taxpayers will be able to estimate the rate of depreciation at the time an item of plant is first used, or installed ready for use, for income producing purposes. This estimate will be based on an objective view of effective life having regard to the statutory definition.
The Commissioner of Taxation will continue to publish advisory depreciation rates that taxpayers not wishing to make independent estimates may adopt for convenience.
The Bill will also give effect to several simplification initiatives.
The number of depreciation rates will be reduced from 18 to 7 broadbanded rate classes, effective from the 1991-92 income year.
All assets eligible for broadbanding (excluding motor vehicles) will receive loading at the rate of 20 per cent.

For assets acquired on or after 1 July 1991, 100% depreciation will be allowable where the value of the unit of plant does not exceed $300 or the estimated effective life of the item is less than three years. This will reduce the large accounting task associated with small items.
Also with effect from the 1991-92 income year, taxpayers will be able to pool items within a rate class for further administrative simplicity.
The estimated cost of broadbanding and 100% depreciation is $100m in 1992-3, with a declining cost in later years.

The Bill will correct a technical deficiency in certain provisions which provide tax deductions for capital expenditure incurred in income producing activities, eg. plant depreciation allowances and allowable capital expenditure in mining operations. The amendments will prevent avoidance of tax on recoupments of previously allowed capital deductions.

A common feature of the capital allowance provisions is that taxpayers are required to bring to account as income amounts received on the disposal of property that represent a recovery of deductions previously allowed. For example, under the plant depreciation rules, an assessable recoupment of deduction occurs when the disposal proceeds of an asset exceeds its depreciated value.

In some instances, the existing law allows taxpayers to nominate as the selling price of an asset the lesser of its market value and its tax written down value. This rule can result in tax avoidance where an asset with a high market value and a low written down value is disposed of by a taxpayer to a related entity at the lower value. If the related entity then sells the property at its true market value, the proceeds cannot be treated as a recoupment of the previous owner's deductions.

To remedy the situation, the various capital allowance recoupment rules are being amended to treat disposals of relevant property under non-arm's length arrangements, or under arrangements that involve some continuity of ownership of the property, as occurring at market value.

The Bill gives effect to the then Treasurer's announcement of 8 December 1990 that wholly-owned group companies could elect to defer capital allowance balancing adjustments that would otherwise apply to intra company group asset transfers occurring after 6 December 1990 where capital gains tax rollover relief applied.

A variant from the announcement is that, in respect of intra group disposals occurring after today, capital allowance balancing adjustment rollover relief will apply automatically whenever capital gains tax rollover relief is obtained.
The Government has also decided to extend capital allowance balancing adjustment rollover relief to the following kinds of asset disposals where capital gains tax rollover relief is obtained:

PARA.TAB: a disposal of an asset by an individual or trustee to a wholly-owned company;
a disposal of partnership property to a company which is wholly-owned by the partners; and
a transfer of an asset to a spouse as the result of a marriage breakdown.

SPEECH.PARA: An optional form of balancing adjustment rollover relief will also be available for disposals of property which are taken to occur as the result of a part change in ownership of property, eg. as can occur when the membership of a partnership is varied. This will enable owners of property to avoid being unnecessarily taxed on amounts that relate to a share of property which they continue to own.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Dividend rebates: company beneficiaries and partners

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will extend the scope of the intercompany dividend rebate to allow the rebate to companies that are not shareholders. The proposed amendment will overcome the effect of the High Court decision in the Patcorp case.

The effect of this decision was that only the registered shareholder was entitled to the intercompany dividend rebate. Even though a company was absolutely entitled to the shares as against the trustee and was taxed on the dividend as trust income, it was not entitled to the rebate.

The entitlement of the beneficial owner or partner that is a company to the rebate will be determined as if it was a shareholder and had received a dividend equal to its share of the income of the trust or partnership that relates to the dividend.

The amendment will apply to dividends paid after 17 August 1976—the day the High Court handed down the decision in Patcorp. But the assessment of any company that was not allowed the rebate in an assessment that issued before today will not be able to have that assessment amended to allow the rebate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deferral of Deductions for Prepayments of Trading Stock

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will affirm the principle of matching tax deductions for expenditure on trading stock against income from selling that stock in the appropriate tax year. This matching process is not just a principle of the tax law but is also a general accounting principle.

Under the present law, expenditure on trading stock is initially deductible under section 51 in the year in which it is incurred. To match deductions against appropriate income, section 28 then writes back as income the value of trading stock on hand at the end of the year. By this process, deductions are deferred until the stock is sold.

The Federal Court case of Federal Commissioner of Taxation versus Raymor exposed a weakness in the interaction of section 51 and section 28. In that case the taxpayer was able to achieve a tax timing advantage by prepaying the cost of certain trading stock that was not delivered, or even made, by the end of the relevant tax year. Because this particular stock was not on hand at year end, section 28 could not operate to defer the deduction allowable under section 51 for the expenditure incurred in that year.

The amendment proposed by this Bill will ensure that a deduction under section 51 for expenditure on stock is not available until the stock becomes trading stock on hand of the taxpayer. The amendment will apply to expenditure incurred after 19 December 1991.

Mr President, the amendments to the tax file number (TFN) provisions will deal with situations where a security, such as a share, is subject to a securities lending arrangement, or has been sold under certain "cum-dividend" or "cum-interest" contracts.

Also, investors in transferable investments such as shares or debentures will be required to quote their TFN by the "books closing time" for the investment if they want to avoid having 48.25% withheld from any income paid.
Securities dealers' "entrepot nominee companies", which are used solely to facilitate the buying and selling of securities, will be excluded from the TFN arrangements.
The amendments will also correct a technical defect in the current law by making the person liable to pay income for the trust the "investment body" for the purposes of deducting TFN amounts.
The amendments will have no significant effect on the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Capital gains tax rollover relief for partnerships

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes to correct a technical deficiency in the capital gains tax rollover provisions for transfers of partnership assets to companies wholly-owned by the partners.

Under the existing law, partners can obtain inappropriately high cost bases for shares received as consideration for transfers of partnership assets encumbered by attached partnership liabilities. This can result in increased capital losses or reduced capital gains when those shares are sold.
These outcomes are unintended, and the law is to be amended to ensure that the cost bases of shares received in such circumstances reflect assumed partnership liabilities.
The amendments will prevent an unintended cost to the revenue, and will apply to disposals occurring after 6 December 1990, the application date for the CGT partnership rollover provisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Taxation of Foreign Source Income

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment of the measures for taxing foreign source income in Part Ten of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will reduce the income of a controlled foreign company that is attributed to resident taxpayers by the amount of dividends paid by the company to unrelated parties on certain widely distributed finance shares.
This amendment, which will relieve taxpayers from an unintended liability to tax, is to apply from the time when the foreign source income measures took effect, generally the 1990/91 income year.

This Bill contains amendments which will ensure that the foreign exchange gains and losses provisions operate as intended. Any deductions for losses on a foreign exchange contract on capital account will be reduced by the amount of any offsetting gain on another contract if that gain is not included in assessable income.
Rehabilitation of Mining, Quarrying and Petroleum Sites
The Bill will make minor amendments to the rehabilitation provisions to clarify their operation.

It ensures that any rehabilitation which restores a site only part way to its pre-mining condition, or which restores only part of the site, will qualify for the deduction. It will also ensure that only depreciable expenses on plant or articles are excluded from the deduction.

These amendments, which will take effect from 1 July 1991, will alleviate concerns the mining and quarrying industries held on the operation of the rehabilitation provisions. They will not have any impact on the revenue.
Amendments to the research and development provisions in relation to core technology and expenditure on plant.
The Bill proposes three minor modifications to the research and development provisions of the law, which allow accelerated deductions in respect of expenditure on research and development.

Firstly, deductions in respect of "core technology" are to be limited to an arm's length amount. Secondly, amounts of expenditure incurred on core technology are to be excluded from the calculation of the reduced deduction that is available in the case of guaranteed returns.

The third amendment relates to deductions in relation to qualifying plant that is deductible in three equal instalments over three years. Where that plant is first eligible to be claimed as a deduction prior to 30 June 1993, it will continue to be deductible at a maximum of 150% after that date rather than 125% that is to apply to other types of expenditure deductible under the R&D provisions after that date.
The Bill will also amend the fringe benefits legislation to provide the Commissioner with a discretion to accept a lower level of substantiation than is currently allowable.

Under the present fringe benefits tax legislation, substantiation is required in order either to reduce the taxable value of certain fringe benefits or to ensure that certain other benefits are exempt from fringe benefits tax.
The proposed amendments will allow the Commissioner a discretion, similar to that contained in the income tax law when considering the substantiation requirements of the fringe benefits legislation.
The amendment will have little impact on revenue.

An education entry payment for sole parent pensioners was announced in the 1991 Budget. The payment will be available to sole parent pensioners commencing or continuing full-time or part-time education courses which attract payment of AUSTUDY.
The Bill ensures that, in common with other income payments, the education entry payment to be paid from 1 January 1992 will be taxed.
The impact of the proposal on revenue in each financial year is expected to be less than $100,000.

This Bill will make some technical and procedural amendments. One will clarify the operation of the provisions that deal with the carry forward of excess foreign tax credits. Another will make a technical correction to accurately reflect the text of the Australia-Fiji comprehensive taxation agreement. And another deals with the publication of indexation factors to be applied in calculating the motor vehicle depreciation limit and the capital gains cost base limit.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 be listed on the Notice Paper as a separate Order of the Day.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS (TASMANIA) REGULATIONS AND POLITICAL BROADCASTS (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) REGULATIONS

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 December 1991, on motion by Senator Parer:

That the Political Broadcasts (Tasmania) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 482, and the Political Broadcasts (Australian Capital Territory) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 483, made under the Broadcasting Act 1942, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is very much the debate that this chamber does not have to have. The motion before us today is unnecessary and a complete waste of the Senate's time. The Opposition had its opportunity to deal with this motion when the regulations were tabled in this place on 19 December 1991. That was the last sitting day of the Parliament last year. It was also the last sitting day before the ACT and Tasmanian elections. It was a day on which this matter was before the Senate. The Opposition embarked on the debate. It moved the motion for disallowance. But after about 20 minutes or so the Opposition decided that it had had enough and that it wanted to adjourn the debate.

PARA.TAB: Where does that leave the Senate? The regulations apply to the Australian Capital Territory and the Tasmanian elections. Those elections have been held and we have before us today a continued debate as to whether those regulations should apply. The reality is that they have applied. The reality is that on 19 December last year those opposite in their incompetence or laziness decided on their own motion to adjourn the debate. This is a debate that we do not have to have because the disallowance cannot be made to apply retrospectively and the elections about which the Opposition is concerned have already taken place. What more Monty Pythonesque behaviour can one imagine? The Opposition is seeking a disallowance of regulations that have already had effect.

But this will not stop Opposition senators. They will come in here today, as they have continually in respect of this issue, with a campaign of dishonesty, misinformation and hysteria. They will be wheeled out this afternoon. They will come out in their wheelchairs, they will come off their perches, they will squawk all day, but at the end what will happen? They will go off and congratulate themselves and in doing so will make absolutely no impact on the Australian electorate.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite should be concerned about this. Their behaviour today and their growing isolationism from the electorate on this particular issue is symptomatic of their behaviour all over the place. They have been running a histrionic debate for 15 months on this issue, but what is the response out in the electorate? As John Laws has said, `They don't give a hoot'. That is precisely the way in which the electorate has responded in the past few months. The isolation of the Opposition from the electorate is a growing characteristic in Australian politics.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Liberal senators may well laugh, but at a time when the business community, the union community, other community groups and this Government all accept that on the basic issue of economic recovery there is scope for fiscal injection, which one group in this community says no? Which one group says, `We will give you a bigger and longer recession'? It is the Opposition.
—We will give you that debate.

—We will have that debate, Senator Kemp, but the Opposition's growing isolationism out there will be something that it will have to contend with by the end of this year. This legislation in its application has been a success.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite can laugh all they like, but this legislation has done a number of things.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not know whether this sort of cathouse behaviour should be allowed to continue in this place. I ask you to draw attention to what all those characters over there are doing.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! I say by way of advice to all colleagues here that I am not sure whether everybody is aware how sensitive our microphones have become. I remind honourable senators that almost everything you are even thinking is now becoming available to the Chair. So I issue a caution to assist the Minister and honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us look at the effect of this legislation so far. It has drastically reduced campaign expenditure in the three elections to which it has applied. In the Entrance by-election and the Tasmanian and ACT general elections political parties spent far less than they would have been required to had the ban not applied.
—What about the movie screens?
—I will tell the honourable senator about the movie screens.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, those opposite are a bit frisky this morning. In the Tasmanian poll one major party, our party, indicated that expenditure was down by 50 per cent, but significantly in the same interview the Liberal Party's campaign director, Bob Lister, also stated that he did not believe the ban had caused disadvantage for any particular party.

PARA.TAB: When the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill was introduced we were told that the major consequences would be people not knowing about elections and not turning out for elections. But is it not interesting that in the Entrance by-election the voter turnout was 91 per cent, despite the fact that the election was held during school holidays and postal voting was not available? There was a high turnout. We were warned that people would not know about elections; they knew full well.

In Tasmania, in the electorate of Denison, the turnout was higher than the turnout in the last Federal election—95.8 per cent. People knew about the election. Why did they know about it? Because of a growing characteristic in Australian politics caused by this ban. It is now imperative that candidates work harder at contacting the electors directly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just spent all your money on movie screens.
—Senator Macdonald can say what he likes. The mouth that walks, the Mouth from the South, had this to say about the ban:

SPEECH.PARA: I think people are very glad not to see politicians in their living rooms all the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President, is the Minister able to refer to a member of Parliament in another House in the derogatory way that he did?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I withdraw, but I am sure Mr Hodgman enjoys that sort of title; in fact, he was the one who promoted it. The eminent Speaker of the Tasmanian Parliament, Mr Hodgman, a former Minister in a conservative government in this place, had this to say about the ban:

SPEECH.PARA: I think people are very glad not to see politicians in their living rooms all the time.

I can understand that, in the case of some Opposition senators. The point is basic: the electorate has responded warmly to the ban. The Greens candidate in Tasmania was also impressed with the ban. Dr Gerry Bates said that the campaign technique of meeting and speaking with the electorate was something that he planned to do between election campaigns.

PARA.TAB: It was not only Mr Hodgman and Dr Bates who said that. It was not only Mr Bob Lister who said that the ban did not cause any disadvantage for any particular party. Even Mr Groom, the new Premier of Tasmania—and this goes to the point about the success of the ban—said that, on the one hand, there is public acceptance, on the other hand, there is no detraction from the process of democracy and, on the third hand, importantly, the Liberal's total expenditure will be less than half the average amount spent by a successful single candidate at the last Federal election.

We did reduce campaign expenditure and we did so in a way that has not detracted from the democratic process. In the period of the ban so far, independents have been selected, there have been changes in government and record turnouts. The basic point is that the Opposition cannot accept the reform, it cannot accept the basis for it and it will continue its campaign of dishonesty. During the adjournment we introduced regulations, and we did have to amend those regulations. The basic point of that process, though, was—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which set are you talking about?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Could honourable senators on my left please exercise a modicum of restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: —Short of going out there and printing the Commonwealth Gazette myself, there is nothing else the Government could have done in this particular instance. Having realised the problem with the first set of regulations, having also realised the problem with the subsequent set, at least six days before any ban was to take place this Government rectified it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators may very well laugh and indulge in all sorts of histrionics, but I refer them to this advice from the research officer to the Senate, which was portrayed by Opposition senators as eminent legal advice. I refer them to page five where there is a whole litany of examples where regulations have had to be withdrawn and re-proclaimed. In fact, in one instance the wrong Act of Parliament was proclaimed. This was a problem with the machinery, we realised it immediately and we acted to rectify it immediately.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make a very important point with respect to this matter. I mentioned the campaign of dishonesty and obfuscation on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go back to the regulations.

—If I were Senator Parer, I would not. Some political capital was attempted on this particular issue during the adjournment. At one stage we had a press statement from Senator Parer saying that he had advice from the Clerk of the Senate that all sorts of things would happen—Nostradamus' predictions of disaster would take place and so on—because the regulations were not valid.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the advice which I believe was tendered improperly in a political hothouse atmosphere. Both the first advice and the accompanying paper—a legal paper prepared by a research assistant to the Senate—reached the conclusion that the first and second sets of regulations made on 19 December and 3 January were imperfect or invalid but that the third set was probably valid and corrected the faults in the first set of regulations. The first advice that Senator Parer received was that the regulations were probably valid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could be.

—They were `probably valid', not `could be'. Then we come to the second advice. For some reason, supplementary advice was provided stating that in the view of the Clerk there was another possible problem with the regulations. Despite his earlier advice, Mr Evans stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the original sets of regulations as amended by the third group of regulations are probably valid.

He went on to say that it may be, however, that the proper construction of sections 48A and 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act is that the provisions in the second set of regulations which repeal the first set of regulations were not the same in substance as those regulations. The regulations would therefore stand unless effectively repealed. The Clerk concluded:
If this interpretation is correct, there are now no valid regulations in force. . .

Somewhere between the Clerk's letter and Senator Parer's press release of 2 February the qualifying `if' was dropped. Senator Parer stated that the Clerk's advice confirmed that the regulations were invalid. He said:
What this means is that there are now no valid regulations in force. . .

This is a gross act of dishonesty, improper behaviour and distortion of the advice, although a continuation of consistency in Senator Parer's campaign. It did not just stop there. Senator Parer also stated that the Clerk's advice suggested that television stations could sue the Government for loss of advertising, yet nowhere in the Clerk's advice and nowhere in the research officer's paper do we find any suggestion that television stations could sue the Government for loss of advertising. That is a gross distortion of the truth, but that does not bother Senator Parer. If he has been consistent about one thing in this place, his consistency has been in distorting the truth. Nowhere in either the Clerk's advices or the paper accompanying them is this proposition canvassed. Not only do qualifications appear but also phoney propositions are wrongly attributed. This idea did not come from the Clerk, it did not come from the research officer; it came from the fantasy in Senator Parer's mind—the bush lawyer from Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We got advice on this matter. We got advice from the Chief General Counsel. He advised us very clearly that there was no substance to the point raised by the Clerk's second letter; in fact, it was so basic it was not even worth canvassing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that legal advice?

—I told Senator Walters where I got that legal advice. In the way that we handle these matters, I am prepared to show it in private to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), given the fact that this is a process that we have adopted in the past. I am prepared to do that.
—One of your Labor Party hacks.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask for a withdrawal from Senator Macdonald.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—I was just about to conclude the same. Senator Macdonald, would you like to withdraw that comment about the legal person advising the Government here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will if you direct, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—I will so direct. I do not believe you could call legal counsel a party hack.
—Can the Minister tell us who it was or can he table the advice?
—The Minister may do that; that is a separate issue. Would you please withdraw that reference to legal counsel.
—I do, in deference to your ruling, Madam Acting Deputy President, but at this stage I take a point of order.
—You have withdrawn the comment and you now wish to proceed while you are on your feet to a point of order.
—Yes. I ask the Minister to table his advice.
—With respect, that is not a point of order. I think that the Minister has the message clear.

—I made it very clear that the advice had come from the Chief General Counsel of the Commonwealth. Given the new sound system in this place, Senator Macdonald would have very clearly understood that. That is the person to whom I referred. As I said, we have a system in this place of not making public legal advice, but I have offered to discuss the matter with the Opposition Leader in the normal way that we discuss these matters and we can proceed in that way. The basic point is that the Clerk's advice, and the research assistant's advice to the Clerk, was distorted dishonestly in the way that the Opposition has run this campaign consistently over a period of time. We are asked about the ACT flaunting the ad ban.
—The ACT Labor Party.

—The ACT Labor Party. During the recess these allegations were made, but the point about the ACT Labor Party's use of advertising in cinemas is that it was anticipated that parties could do that. Parties knew that very well. `Shock, horror, surprise', says Senator Parer during the recess. The ban applies to electronic advertising; it was always to apply to electronic advertising, and the Bill was limited to such. If those opposite go back to the second reading debate and the committee stage, they will find that it was limited to such. They will also find that advertising in cinemas and on movie screens is not electronic advertising. Those opposite knew that at the start. They knew that in the debate; they raised it in the debate. It did not stop them from going upstairs and conning the Press Gallery that it was shock, horror, and they had not anticipated it.

PARA.TAB: I will tell those opposite one thing, in closing this debate. I know that for the duration of today they will—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Sky Channel electronic?

—Of course it is. The legislation was framed in a way that was discussed at that stage, and if there is some debate as to whether the ban should apply to Sky Channel we will look at whether we can apply consistency in respect to it. The ACT Labor Party advertised in cinemas. Parties have always advertised in cinemas; I was doing that in South Australia in 1974 and the Opposition has been doing it consistently.
—Did that save you money?

—It did not cost all that much at the time. I will try to close on this point without interruption from the other side. This ban has now applied for some two to three months. In that period there have been a number of tests of it. The reforms have three pillars.
—How do you get three months out of seven weeks?

—It just seems that long since I last saw Senator Macdonald. The reforms have three pillars. The disclosure provisions are the most comprehensive introduced in this country and the Government is very proud of them. The ban and the free time are the other two pillars of the legislation. Those three essential pillars of the legislation have survived this period unscathed and have been tested and found to be successful.

PARA.TAB: The end result of this short period of testing this legislation has been twofold. On the one hand, we have had an enormous decrease in electoral expenditure, which was one of our initial objectives. On the other hand, we have seen the process of democracy working in a way that we on this side of the chamber said it would and the Democrats also said it would. Governments have changed, independent minority candidates have been elected and there has been a massive turnout in the polls—in fact, in some instances, higher than in the previous Federal elections where advertising applied.

The people out there have, through formal and informal polls, made it very clear that they do not miss political advertising. The parties have also indicated, although indiscreetly sometimes in respect to some Opposition spokespeople, that they have appreciated not having to raise and spend as much money as they had to in the past. People have been able to get their information about the political process through the electronic media, through every other channel but paid advertising. When we introduced this legislation, we said at the start that there is nothing more undemocratic than having a person's voice and the level of that voice depend on how much can be spent to push it through the electronic media.

Since that time, nothing has happened to dispute that fact. In fact, other countries are already looking at this legislation. I have had messages from legislators in the United States supportive of it. There is nothing new about this Bill in a world sense; there is nothing radical about this measure in a world sense; there is nothing unprecedented about it. It applies in just about all Western liberal democratic countries. We somehow got it through the Senate. We anticipated that there would be opposition from the Opposition, which basically does not really see the need for reform in any area. We have brought in a measure which, in its initial application, has been successful. It has been successful in terms of both the process and the parties involved.

Finally, as I said at the start, this motion is Monty Pythonesque. The Opposition will spend most of today trying to disallow regulations which have already had their effect. The Opposition will come in here and ask the Senate to disallow regulations which have applied to the two elections that are the subject of this motion. What is the Opposition on about? If the Opposition's motion gets up, what effect will it have? It will have absolutely none at all. The Opposition would actually do service to this place and the Australian community if it called off this motion and got on with some serious business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) continues to defend the indefensible. The Minister said that there is nothing more undemocratic than people using a chequebook to communicate a message. There is nothing more undemocratic than denying the right of people in the Australian community access to put a point of view to the public of Australia. There is nothing more undemocratic than that. The ban put on by this Government is an infringement of all of our rights.

PARA.TAB: We are reliably told that the life of a Bill is almost a decade. Statistics will show quite clearly that Ministers usually do not have the same shelf life. It is therefore exceptionally unfortunate that weak government—aided and abetted by opportunists on the cross benches, I might add—can at times allow Ministers with a reputation for being less than able, free reign to deal with legislation which is, frankly, a bit too difficult for them to comprehend and administer. The result is, not unexpectedly, chaos. The Minister presently in question, Senator Bolkus, is quite clearly headed for the Opposition benches and subsequent political oblivion, leaving others to clean up this legislative mess.

We on this side of the chamber have been totally opposed to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act since its inception. From day one we have not opposed the disclosure provisions. John Hewson put that down clearly. He said that we would support full, fair and equitable disclosure of political donations. That is not in question. What is in question is the advertising component, the removal of the freedom of speech of the Australian community.

The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill was introduced last year purely as a cynical exercise to save the financially embarrassed Australian Labor Party from having to fund electronic political campaign advertising. The Labor Party well knew that it was on the nose with the business community; it well knew that come the next election campaign it would not get the sort of support from the business community that it had in the past; it well knew that the coalition would get this support and it wanted to remove the capacity for us to communicate to the electorate.

What has been the track record of this Administration since it was elected to government in 1983? Australia has had the worst recession for some 60 years and 1.5 million people are unemployed. The Government does not want the electorate to be reminded of its track record and its policy direction. The Labor Party was strapped financially. In an endeavour to make its position more equitable at the next election, it went down the track of walking over the rights of individuals.

As the Commissioner for Human Rights has clearly identified, what we have done is breach international covenants that we as Australia are a signatory to. We have breached our obligations internationally. We have removed rights of individuals and Australians. If there is one thing that we as Australians and as a Parliament ought to stand up and be counted for, it is the right for all Australians to be able to speak up loudly and clearly on issues that we believe in, and not ban or deny that right to individuals and Australians, as this Government and this Minister have done.

It is more than likely with what we see in this Bill that it will be found unconstitutional in the High Court on 17 March. That is the next real test for this Minister and this Government on this legislation. It will be before the High Court on 17 March. The judgment given by the members of the court clearly indicated that there was a case to be answered. On 17 March we will see just how close this Minister has been to the truth and reality in presenting this legislation.

It is a gross abuse of human rights and a defiance of civil liberties; that cannot be denied. It is disadvantageous to the print handicapped, migrants and the majority of our rural community who, as we all know, cannot readily access the print media. It severely financially disadvantages the electronic media not only by removing a regular source of income or revenue, but also by forcing radio and television stations to provide `free time' while allowing the print media to charge for space and direct mail to flourish. Clearly, what we said initially was that the same amount of money would be spent; it simply will be spent in different directions.
What we have seen in the ACT is Sky Channel being used on which to run the commercials—still an electronic form of communication—and theatres being used.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not Sky Channel. You don't know what you are talking about. It was closed circuit television.

—The Democrats clearly do not know what they are talking about. The Democrats, who came into this place as champions of the underdogs, champions of individuals in this community, have let them down. They have walked away from their basic constituency—the individuals out there. They sorted it out with the Government and removed individuals' rights to free speech, to speak up on issues that they believe in in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: Organisations like the Automobile Association in New South Wales, which has tens of thousands of members who want to communicate on road funding, are denied that right, as is the Australian Medical Association when it wants to put a point of view on a health issue. They are denied that right in election campaigns and the Democrats supported the Government in denying that right of the AMA and the Automobile Association.

Look at the print handicapped, look at the migrant community, look at the rural community—the list goes on. The Democrats have walked away from a basic and fundamental right that they are supposed to have stood for since their formation. They will be condemned in the ballot box for walking away from Australians in the way in which they have, in breaching Australia's international obligations of human rights and civil liberties. That is what they have done, and they well know that they have done that. We have seen that this legislation also ostracises independent candidates while greatly advantaging people such as the Democrats as payment for their support.

Put simply, it is a mess, incompetently crafted from sloppy advice and badly mismanaged by the Minister from start to finish in this chamber. I know from discussions with some of those opposite that many Labor politicians are quite incredulous at the procession of errors made by Senator Bolkus and his staff in dealing with this Bill. Some shake their heads. Others simply laugh at his incompetence. All just wish the whole thing would go away because they realise such a contentious piece of legislation needed to be moved through as smoothly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Mr Recession agrees with that.

—Even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as Senator Macdonald says, has acknowledged that. It did not need every mistake in the book being made and then some more added to it. It would be fair to say that the Minister had not a clue what the ramifications of this Bill were when it was passed in December here in this chamber. I would also go so far as to say, neither did the Democrats. Of course, the Democrats did not actually care as long as they got to plunge their hands into the lolly jar, so to speak, as offered. It is just as likely Senator Bolkus—
—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I ask Senator Olsen to withdraw the assertion that we had our hands in the lolly jar. I think it is a very unfair reflection.
—It was the till.
—He said, `the lolly jar'.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—My understanding is that it is not without precedence in this chamber. You will have the opportunity to explain, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been assessed that in the last election campaign the Democrats spent some $380,000 on electronic advertising. Under the provisions of this Bill, they are to get $1.8m of free time. Yet they say their hands are not in the lolly jar. Not much! They are better off to the tune of about $1.5m as a result of supporting this legislation.
—Are you objecting to your taking free time?
—Senator Kernot well knows that we have consistently opposed this legislation all the way through.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, the honourable senator from Tasmania, Senator Sherry, might wait to get to his seat before interjecting. It is quite unruly to comment while walking around the Senate chamber. It took more than a week after this Bill had been passed through the Senate for the Government to decide what had and had not been amended, added and deleted during the marathon debate in this chamber. How on earth can we say with a straight face to those in the electorate that this is their Parliament at work? The handling of this Bill cannot but help make anyone with a modicum of respect for the political process cringe with embarrassment.

PARA.TAB: When we come to the regulations, we go from chaos to outright catastrophe. Even Senator Schacht would have been able to handle this far better than Senator Bolkus. I am sure that Senator Schacht would have been able to at least get draft No.3 right, if not draft No.1 or draft No.2. He would not have had to go to four drafts, as the Minister did.

I have seen advice that these regulations are most probably invalid, after yet another procession of errors and gaffes by the Minister. That one statement calls into question the fairness of recent elections. Thanks to the inadequacies of a Minister processing a suspect Bill with unseemly haste, we are facing the ridiculous situation where, as someone suggests, the election results could be called into question. Here in the ACT the independent, Michael Moore, is quite adamant that, as he had no access to the free time allocation, should he lose he will challenge the ACT election in the court. He will argue that, as a candidate in the election, he was denied the opportunity of access to free time.

I remember us having a debate in this chamber about whether independents from all sections of the community would get a fair go. Well, they are not getting a fair go, and the Democrats might well reflect upon that. Have a talk to Michael Moore about being denied access to free time to communicate what he stood for in the recent ACT elections. By supporting this legislation, the Democrats have denied him, as a candidate, an opportunity to communicate to the electorate prior to that election. Depending upon the election result, it may well be that, if he is not elected, he will challenge that in the court. If that occurs and he wins, which some legal opinion suggests he might, there will be another election. That is something that I am positive nobody wants. The electronic media in both Tasmania and the ACT may be able to sue for compensation for free time provided. It may seek to be recompensed for advertising revenue lost or forgone as a result of these regulations which, in advice that we have seen, are null and void.

The script writers of Yes, Minister would reject such a story outright as being too far fetched and stupid for their audience. Yet this is Labor politics Australian style. Labor is not only denying free speech when its political back is to the wall but, in addition, it is going a step further. This Government needs to be reminded that the legislative process is not a game; that it is not something to be treated with contempt. Every Bill that we, as elected representatives of the community, have the responsibility of dealing with affects the daily lifestyles of many thousands of people.

Exceptionally damaging to the political process is the comedy of errors surrounding the regulations of this Bill. It is even more damaging that the Minister has not made one apology but has simply continued to play out his farce, insisting that he and he alone is right. Today he had the temerity to criticise the Clerk and the Senate Table Office for providing advice to the Opposition, the Opposition having sought some information. If we, as members of this chamber and members of this Parliament, cannot seek advice from the Table Office or the Clerk of the Senate in a bipartisan way—

TALK.START.PARA: —You blokes aren't bipartisan.

—Senator Schacht scoffs. He is also going to join Senator Bolkus in this partisan attack on officers of this Parliament. The Opposition sought some advice, some information. That was provided—and so it should be provided—by the Senate Table Office and officers of this Parliament. It is irresponsible and damning of a Minister publicly to criticise in this chamber the Senate Table Office, the Clerk or research officers preparing information as requested by a political party or a member of this Parliament. I reject totally his assertion that that was done in a partisan way.

PARA.TAB: The interpretation is another matter. The seeking and obtaining of advice ought to be a fundamental right and ought not to be walked over by Senator Bolkus, supported by Senator Schacht—and the Australian Democrats, what is more. Here they go again, criticising us for seeking advice from the Table Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand your angst. You just can't stand being losers.

—Have a look at the Bulletin poll today. We know who has its political back squarely to the wall. We know why this legislation is in. Senator Schacht, as a former ALP State Secretary, well understands the importance of running advertising campaigns and how they can have some impact during election campaigns. So Senator Schacht joins other members of the Labor Party in wanting to deny the coalition the right to advertise in the lead-up to the next election campaign, to remind the electorate of the performance and the policy direction of the Labor Party over the last seven or eight years. That is what it is about. Labor Party members are cash-strapped. That is why they went down this track, and well Senator Schacht knows it.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the point that the Minister has not made any apology for the comedy of errors that we have seen in the regulations. He sought rather to criticise and damn the Table Office, the Clerk and the research assistants, which I think is totally inappropriate and uncalled for. He also tried to cite examples where regulations were withdrawn and represented on previous occasions, in an endeavour to excuse his actions, his conduct, the way in which he has handled this legislation.

If I were to explain in detail exactly every error that has occurred with the regulations we would be here for some hours, so what I will do is precis that document of administrative incompetence. Basically, the Government missed the boat. It gazetted the proclamation a day late, on 2 January, making all regulations void. It tried to fix that up by a second proclamation, gazetting both on 3 January. At this point the Government had repealed and redrafted the regulations. However, these regulations were the subject of an unresolved disallowance motion in this chamber, the very same motion we are now debating and, as such, the regulations could not legally be remade and so are void.

I have seen advice which states clearly that the point contained in sections 48A and 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act indicates that there are no valid regulations in force relating to Tasmania, the ACT and New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe.

—Senator Kernot should listen to the whole speech rather than tuning in and out as it suits her particular circumstances. Added to this mess we have the final incompetence. It was discovered that there were major errors with all three sets of regulations—referring to sections of the Act which did not even exist. This was corrected by yet another set of regulations on 10 January. But, according to advice, these may well also be void. So what we have ended up with here is two proclamations, each with a different date, and four sets of regulations, all of which, according to some advice, are void.

PARA.TAB: The Minister, still bumbling along trying to save face, claims that he has advice to the contrary. We heard some reference to that today. We want to see the Minister's advice. I know that the Minister has left the chamber now, but I am sure that Senator Schacht will communicate this to him. We would like to see the advice that contradicts not only some advice by the Clerk but also the advice of some of the best constitutional lawyers in the country. If the Minister is fair dinkum, let him put his legal advice on the table—not show it behind a closed door so that the public cannot see it. Let him put his legal advice on the table so that it is freely available to the media and the public, as the advice to us has been. All we ask is for him to put it on the table. If he is so sure of it, he should put it out; let us have a good look at it.

Meanwhile, we wait until 17 March to see what the High Court has to say about this whole piece of legislation. It just seems rather difficult to comprehend that his advice should be so different and correct, given the procession of legislative errors that the Minister has been responsible for already. But he assures us that that indeed is the case, so I believe that we have the right to know who provided that advice and to have it tabled.

Based on advice we have received—the only visible advice at the moment, I might add—it seems that these regulations can be construed as null and void. As I have said, we have had this procession of errors all through January—a level of ministerial incompetence.

The Government has a dilemma and it cannot say that it was not warned. Come the High Court challenge on 17 March, it is likely to face an even bigger one. This Act—its chaos and its contradictions—is making a mockery of the political process. There is only one course. If the new Prime Minister seeks to prove that he has the courage of his convictions and a concern about the comedy of errors on this piece of legislation, he should ensure that the Act is repealed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on this very strange debate because the Opposition wants us to disallow regulations for elections that have already happened. I find that rather strange.
—Do they not apply for the future?

—For every future election a new set of regulations will be tabled. If one reads these regulations, one will see that they are headed, `Political broadcasts—Australian Capital Territory regulations'. These regulations were specifically for that election. There are also the Tasmanian regulations which were specifically for that election. For each future election there will be a set of new regulations. The Senate asked that the regulations for each election be tabled specifically, separately, at the time so that the mob opposite could have a chance, if it did not like them, to disallow them. This is what honourable senators opposite asked for in the debates last year—and they got it. The regulations applying to those elections—The Entrance by-election, the Tasmanian election and the ACT election—now, of course, do not operate because the elections have been successfully held. No-one has complained at the local level. Apparently one candidate is concerned about his allocation of free time.

PARA.TAB: Let us go through all the arguments we heard from the other side, particularly from the two dud senators who served on the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures—Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp—who fought in their party room to get on that committee. They said, `We will use this Select Committee to stop any ad ban Bill going through and to stop disclosures'. They were the hairy chested ones. Even Senator Bronwyn Bishop got rolled, because Kemp and Olsen had to prove how hairy chested they were. They promised, with Senator Parer, that this Bill would not go through. There was statement after statement saying, `This is a dead Bill'. For month after month they crowed in this place and, of course, now they have to cop it; they lost. This is another chance that they are using to try to tell their mates in the Liberal Party, `Look, we are still having a good go. We are sorry we lost last year. We promised you that we would defeat it. We promised you that we would knock it over in the Select Committee but we failed. But we will have one more go'—by trying to disallow regulations that are already dead! That is how stupid they are.

Let us go through the results of the three elections. We were told by honourable senators opposite that this Bill represented the end of free speech: the equivalent of the end of motherhood, Christianity and everything else that is good in society. The first place in which it operated was The Entrance by-election. Usually in State or Federal by-elections in the last 50 years there has been very little electronic advertising. The Liberals said, `We will have radio ads in The Entrance'. They were taken off air. This was represented as a dreadful defeat for free speech.

What happened in The Entrance by-election? Despite Greiner trying to pull a stunt and holding it in the middle of the holiday season, in the middle of January, what happened? There was the highest turnout in recent history; 93 per cent of the enrolled electors in The Entrance turned out and voted. If this Bill was denying free speech and stopping communication, how come we had such a high turnout? Of course, we cannot get an answer out of members of the Opposition as to why we had such a high turnout despite, as they say, the electronic ban operating.

The people in The Entrance knew the issues. They knew the campaign. As was said in The Entrance election, all the parties had to go back and campaign amongst the people—face to face contact. That may be one of the reasons there was over a 90 per cent turnout when in a normal by-election it is somewhere between 75 per cent and 85 per cent. So on the first issue the Opposition has raised—that the ban would stop people being aware of an election—its argument has failed. That Entrance by-election had one of the highest turnouts in the history of Australia. There has been not one comment from the other side about that.
We then turn then to Tasmania. It was said that this Bill would keep the Labor Party in office for ever and a day everywhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody said that. We knew nothing would keep them in.

—Senator Walters from Tasmania said that this Bill was going to be used to keep the Labor Party in office everywhere in Australia. That was the argument used by those opposite. Of course, in Tasmania, unfortunately for my side of politics, there was a big swing against the Labor Party. Despite the ban on electronic advertising, there was a big swing and a big shift in opinion and the Liberal Party comprehensively won the election with its best first preference result in Tasmanian history. This was after an electronic advertising ban which it was said would only help the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: The most interesting comment I heard about the Tasmanian election was in an interview on the ABC AM program on 28 January 1992. A Labor Party campaign director, Mr Alan Evans, was interviewed about the impact of an electronic ban. A Mr Bob Lester—I do not know him—was also interviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lister!
—Sorry, Lister. Mr Lister is the campaign director for the Liberal Party. What he said is very instructive. The ABC interviewer, Marius Benson, introduced him by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party's counterpart to Alan Evans, the Labor campaign coordinator, is campaign director, Bob Lister.
Mr Lister then said:

I don't believe there's any disadvantage for any particular party. It has, of course, lessened the impact of the election on the community. Some people from our own polling would indicate that they're not too sure whether there's an election or not.
Mr Benson then stated:

It was argued that the ban would actually improve the quality of campaigning when you got away from the flim-flam of electronic campaigning, that there'd be more substance, there'd be more rational discussion. Have you seen any evidence of that?
Mr Lister responded:

Well, certainly the public has had the opportunity to question policies and candidates which, I'm sure, is a good thing, and I believe the candidates have got closer to the public with some of their issues and have listened to the public, so I think that can only be good for the campaign, as well.

Who said that? It was not a stooge of the Labor Party. That is what the Liberal Party's appointed campaign director for Tasmania said about it, and those opposite are screaming that it is the end of free speech! He said it is a good thing.

PARA.TAB: I bet he is going to be censored by Senator Walters and the other ratbags of the Liberal Party State Council. Poor old Mr Lister is probably for the high jump now that he has been exposed for telling Senator Walters, with all her screaming and ranting in here about this Bill, that she is wrong. It has had a good impact on the election campaign. That is what Mr Lister, a Liberal Party campaign director said. I wonder whether Senator Walters will get up and say that Mr Lister was wrong? I wonder whether Senator Walters will do that? So we have a Liberal campaign director saying that the impact of the Bill has been to benefit the electoral process.

Then we get to the ACT election. We have had that election with the regulations working and free time having been made available. Probably it would have been one of the most complex arrangements in respect of free time because there were so many sitting independents—usually called non-self-government parties and the other sundry ratbag parties which had been running around in the ACT but represented in the ACT Assembly. There was a complex arrangement aimed at giving them access to free time. Apparently one of them has complained, according to Senator Olsen, that he did not get access to free time. Ironically, he looks like being elected without having such access. It defeats the point that Senator Olsen was making as the man in question appears to have got elected without such access.

I understand that before I came into the chamber one Liberal senator made an accusation that the ALP was using Sky Television in the ACT election. I point out that what the ALP in that election did was to make video tapes.
Opposition senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Faulkner, there is quite a bit of normal interjection in the debate, but if you encourage it it will only make it harder for Senator Schacht. Perhaps all members could bear in mind that Senator Schacht has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was seeking to point out that in the ACT election the ALP was accused of using Sky Television. What happened was that the ALP made electoral video tapes and distributed them to the various clubs, which played them on large television screens, absolutely outside the impact of this Act.
—Were they talking heads?
—They may have been talking heads, but what is for certain is that they would have been much more attractive talking heads and more sensible ones than yours.
—Did it cost them anything?

—Probably they had to pay for it, but so what? They complied with the Act. It is obvious that the ACT Liberal Party did not have the wit to attempt it. Those opposite cannot complain if the incompetents in their own organisation in the ACT could

SPEECH.PARA: not think of a way of election campaigning within the law.
