PARA.TAB: I noticed in January, particularly from Victoria from a man whose name I think is Kroger, the Liberal President there, statements to this effect: `We are getting around the electoral ban by putting ads on TV about the Victorian State Government'. They were not getting around the ban at all. The electoral ban allows advertising in any form on television and radio in non-election periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not how you started off.

—No, but that is how the Parliament carried the legislation. When I was asked about it during January, I said, `Mr Kroger is not getting around the Act; he is not breaking even the spirit of the law. He is carrying it out. In a non-election period, if he wants to spend his money, or the Liberal Party's money, he can go for it'. If the Liberal Party in Victoria has bagfuls of money to spend, that is its business, but it cannot do so in an election campaign. There was no breaking of the spirit, there was no smart activity by the Liberal Party to get round the law. The law allowed it to do so and it took that opportunity.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to other remarks made by Senator Olsen. I heard him say that this Bill breaks every international covenant on free speech, human rights, and goodness knows what else. He did not quote one paragraph from any international covenant as to where it could be broken. I point out to the Senate, and particularly to Senator Olsen, that during the Select Committee hearings when the point was made about breaking international covenants, we asked the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade whether in the previous 30 years it had at any stage thought it necessary to raise with countries that have much more draconian bans than contained in this legislation that this was an infringement under one of the United Nations covenants on political and civil rights.

The simple one-paragraph answer was `No', because no-one had ever claimed that the much more draconian bans in England, France, Germany, Spain, Norway or Sweden were in any way an infringement on free speech. So it was factually wrong for Senator Olsen to have got up and made the bland statement he did today. No-one anywhere has taken a case to any international court against any government over controlling, banning or limiting electronic advertising.

Since 1942 there has been a ban on paid advertising for three days from midnight on the Wednesday for State and Federal elections. No-one opposite challenged the constitutionality of that as a States rights issue in the High Court. In fact, a former Liberal senator from New South Wales, for many years the General Secretary of the New South Wales branch, Senator Carrick, was one of the great defenders of that three-day ban for State and Federal elections. After the 1983 election, I heard him propound that view before the original Select Committee on Electoral Matters. He did not even want to remove the limitation, which we removed, on having free comment on television or radio for the last three days.

Senator Carrick, who for 20 years was State Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party, said that we should even have the ban for the last three days in State and Federal elections. He was not arguing that this affected New South Wales. He did not argue a States rights case. He thought it was quite reasonable. Even at the height of the Menzies period, when States rights was the Liberal Party's highest icon of ideology, not one State branch of the Liberal Party wanted to challenge the power of the Federal Parliament under the Broadcasting Act to ban advertisements completely for the last three days of every State and Federal election campaign across Australia. We did not hear one word out of the Liberal Party at that stage. No-one challenged the ban. No-one said, `It is an invasion of free speech if for the last three days you ban television and radio advertising for all elections everywhere in Australia'.

It is rather hypocritical, a case of selective history, for honourable senators opposite now to claim that they are the great defenders of political free speech when previously their representatives in this chamber defended the right of the Federal Parliament to use the Act to ban paid advertising on television and radio. No-one in this chamber has argued that, constitutionally under the Broadcasting Act, we have the right to ban cigarette advertising. The tobacco lobby has screamed and shouted that that is an infringement on free speech. I must give credit to a number of Opposition senators for supporting the Australian Democrats Bill to ban tobacco advertising. No-one has argued the constitutionality of the Broadcasting Act powers being a Federal power and that when the legislation is passed here it takes effect. It is irrelevant that people have worked themselves into a lather over States rights.

Do those opposite really believe that the Federal Government, through the Broadcasting Act, cannot legislate to control in one form or another the nature of television advertising in a political campaign? Do they believe that people will say, `No, you have no power to control broadcasting in Australia for State election campaigns'? Does that mean that State governments can make laws relating to what goes on radio and television for their State elections? It is an extraordinary assertion that State governments could overrule and amend a Federal Act, a Federal power. The contorted, convoluted arguments of States rights that some people opposite are now running with are extraordinary and are against all good government measures, and they themselves, in their saner moments, should realise that they cannot be proceeded with.

The High Court will deal with this case in March. I hope that the High Court allows, above all else, ordinary good commonsense to apply to the fact that, constitutionally, the Federal Parliament has the power to amend the Broadcasting Act as it sees fit and to decide what shall and what shall not go on television and radio.

Some of the people in the radio and television industry who are part of that challenge, who complain about free speech and so on as far as the Broadcasting Act and television Act are concerned, are the first people to come trotting to Canberra to demand that the Federal Government make regulations to control the entry of other television and radio stations. They want the Federal Government to regulate and control the radio and television spectrum. They want regulations made, wherever necessary, to ensure that their access to a monopoly market is controlled. They want no-one to be allowed to affect their powers to broadcast. When we say to them, `Look, you people want deregulation in some areas. Let's deregulate control of the spectrum' they are panic stricken. They do not want someone else jamming their signal. They accept that the Federal Government has the power to regulate the broadcasting and radio industry in this country, and to control the radio spectrum and broadcasting spectrum, which is a community resource.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a top little regulator there now, I can tell you.

—Yes. Yesterday I was delighted to see that the ABT announced new regulations—it is going to re-regulate the amount of advertising. I think 98 per cent of Australian television consumers and viewers would be delighted with that decision.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the view that the Act that was passed by Parliament—and I accept that it was controversial—was absolutely constitutional in that we have power over both radio and television broadcasting in Australia. I refute completely that it is an invasion of free speech because practically every other Western democracy with which we are endlessly compared usually has much more draconian regulations than this Act has.

TALK.START.PARA: —And more corruption.

—A lot less corruption than some of Senator Kemp's mates around the place. They made those decisions. Unlike the people screaming and shouting opposite, nobody in those countries or elsewhere has complained that it is a breach of free speech.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the real charade of this debate is that these regulations no longer apply. The elections have been successfully held and the democratic process has taken place. The Liberals won the general election in Tasmania in a landslide. Their best result ever was achieved under this new regime so I do not know what they are complaining about. We won the by-election in The Entrance. Although the Labor Party held office in an open election in the ACT, it is still in a minority position; the minority parties still have the balance of power. I do not see that that is in any way an infringement of the political process.

From all the evidence that I have seen, the ordinary voters said during those campaigns that they thought it was a wonderful idea to get rid of annoying television and radio political advertisements. People I spoke to who door-knocked during those elections said that voters told them, `Isn't it great that we got rid of those dreadful ads'. There has been no revolt in the streets and no public ground swell at all. People did not demand to have the ban lifted in respect of those elections and by-election.

What we have today is the final last gasp effort by a couple of defeated sorry Liberal senators who could not deliver the goods, despite all of the promises they made to the select committee. They are making an effort to get up and say, `Well, we will disallow the regulations that no longer apply'. Talk about a charade! Talk about idiocy! This basically proves that in the long term future—if the Liberal Party had any—Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp should not be appointed to any select committee that has any decent work to do because they have proved themselves to be duds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the remarks made by Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht and to support my colleagues in their motion to disallow the regulations in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991. Senator Schacht made some personal comments about me and Senator Olsen. I will not bother to respond too much to those, except to say that when Senator Schacht speaks about human rights principles there will always be a hoarse laugh from this side of the chamber. When we look closely at his speech, do we see any element of the principle that people have a right to convey their views to the public, if they wish to, in the manner they choose?

PARA.TAB: It was very noticeable on this side of the chamber that Senator Schacht's performance as Chairman of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures was absolutely disgraceful. Is it any wonder that Mr Keating did not promote Senator Schacht in the recent reshuffle in the Australian Labor Party? The reason for that must be that it would be seen to be Labor Party suicide to have Senator Schacht in control of any departmental matter before any committee in the future in view of his prior performance. In my mind, that view would be absolutely correct.

Speakers on the other side of the chamber raised the issue of how this particular Act and its consequent regulations work. I plan to look at that issue in my remarks. A number of things can be said in summary about the effect of this legislation and the regulations about which there is a motion of disallowance before the chamber. Firstly—and I do not think anyone now argues this—the Act was entirely motivated by the financial destitution in which the Labor Party now finds itself. It is broke in most States, in huge debt in most States. It is a Labor Party without support, without the possibility of raising money, and a Labor Party which is determined as far as it can to tap into the taxpayer to fund its election campaigns.

In response to Senator Bolkus's comment that expenditure will be cut by this Act, that will be tested in the years to come, particularly in the next Federal election. My view is that expenditure will rise and rise substantially, but this time it will be the media companies that will be paying for it with free time and the consumers who will be charged extra as a result of the other advertisements on television. Above all, there is the amount of money that will be sucked from the taxpayer. So when the final accounts are in for the 1993 Federal election, we will find that election expenditure will have risen, and risen substantially. It will not be cut, as alleged by Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht today.

Senator Bolkus made the point that this Bill has received wide acceptance. Senator Bolkus cannot be reading the newspapers, because virtually every media commentator and virtually every leader in major newspapers has roundly condemned this particular Act. Human rights organisations have also condemned this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was before they saw how it was implemented.

—I will come to Senator Kernot in a minute. The third general comment I wish to make is that the actions of the Australian Democrats in supporting this disgraceful Bill have been widely noted and widely condemned in the public. I have said in this chamber on at least four other occasions that the big winners out of this Act are the Australian Democrats and that is why they supported this Act. I have stated that the Act is worth $1.8m to the Australian Democrats in free television advertising in the next Federal election. This is probably the fifth time I have said that. I have contrasted that $1.8m with the $400,000 which the Australian Democrats spent in the 1990 election.

PARA.TAB: In other words, there is a bonus in the order of $1.5m to the Australian Democrats in TV advertising as a result of this Act being passed. I shall be listening to Senator Kernot's speech to see whether she challenges those figures. I have put them down four or five times and she has never argued about them. This is a disgraceful pay-off to her Party. The Democrats now receive extensive free time TV advertising, which they were never able to pay for before, while all those other groups, minor parties and lobby groups are banned from TV advertising. That is the deal the Democrats did with the Government. My figures have never been challenged by the Democrats, despite the fact that I have raised them four or five times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot says that I am right. At last we have the admission. Senator Kernot has said that my figures are right. For the record, in 1990 the Australian Democrats spent $380,000 on election advertising; under this new Act, the Australian Democrats will be entitled to $1.8m in TV advertising. Senator Kernot has confirmed that my figures are correct. I thank her. What a disgraceful act it is to receive so much money on your own behalf while preventing other people from running advertisements on TV.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that support for the Democrats has fallen to 5 per cent. Frankly, the people who used to support the Democrats used to think that they, above all, were concerned with human rights and free speech. I suspect that they were concerned with those issues. The actions of Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter in supporting this Act have been widely condemned by members of their own Party. I suspect that if they look at why their vote has fallen to an all time low, they will see that this Act and the support they gave it is one of those reasons.

The final general point I wish to make is that the handling of the regulations in this Parliament by Senator Bolkus has been marked by a degree of incompetence and confusion that we have rarely seen in the Parliament. Senator Olsen has drawn attention to this. Senator Olsen outlined in some detail the mistakes that were made relating to the gazetting of this Act and the regulations.

I think it is worth recording that these mistakes in the gazetting of the regulations are not only a matter for this Parliament, they are a matter for the Governor-General as well. This is not a trivial point. The whole purpose of allowing the Governor-General to make regulations is to ensure that by putting this process at the highest level of government, it is done properly. No-one can dispute, looking at the succession of errors that have occurred, that the Governor-General, Mr Hayden, has been placed in a most awkward and embarrassing position. He signed a proclamation that was not gazetted until the following day, in breach of the required procedure. He then had to be advised to sign another proclamation for the same Act the next day so that that could be properly gazetted.

I think honourable senators will know that it is a statutory requirement that the gazetting of proclamations must take place on the same day as, or an earlier day than, the commencement. It is not clear, to my mind, that the second gazetting validly commenced the Act. As Senator Olsen pointed out, this may be tested in the courts.

In my view, the Governor-General should look very closely at any future advice coming from Senator Bolkus and the Department of Administrative Services. I am not aware that Senator Bolkus has apologised to the Governor-General for the embarrassment that he caused—I certainly hope he has. It does not end there. The Governor-General has been advised to sign three different sets of regulations for the same Act. Furthermore, it is still not clear, despite what Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus have said, whether any of those regulations are validly in force.

I believe that the best thing this chamber can do now, as a result of the workings of this particular Act and as a result of the confusion surrounding the tabling of regulations, is to throw them out lock, stock and barrel. I remind Senator Kernot that this Act was rushed through the last sitting of the Parliament, with the support of the Australian Democrats, and it has now been tested, as a number of speakers have pointed out, in four elections. Despite what Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus have said, in each of those elections there has been major controversy relating to this Act and the decisions that have been made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

Let me give an example from my own State, Victoria. An extraordinary situation arose in my own State in relation—would you believe—to a local council by-election in southern New South Wales. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal advised seven country TV and radio stations situated in Victoria not to broadcast Liberal advertisements concerning the Kirner State Government because of an upcoming local council by-election across the border in New South Wales in the Shire of Hume. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal claimed that the ads might be beamed to the voters in the New South Wales by-election. The fact that the Liberal Party was not even advertising in the region is a cause for some amusement.

Nonetheless, this pre-emptive action by the ABT gives an indication, I believe, of the pernicious nature of this Act. As the Age newspaper pointed out, this direction from the ABT could have deterred the stations from broadcasting advertisements in a Liberal campaign directed at Victorian electors in anticipation of a Victorian election possibly many months away. I point out to Senator Kernot that, as it turned out, only one candidate emerged for the Hume Shire vacancy and no poll was required. By comparison and somewhat inconsistently, the ABT did not warn Victorian radio stations within hearing of Tasmania where a State election was imminent. No wonder there is widespread confusion about the operation of this Bill.
As stated by the Victorian State Director of the Liberal Party, Mr Petro Georgiou, the ABT's move in the Hume council election:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . shows the absolute fractious nature of the Act, when a by-election in a local government area can affect the conduct of another State.

Just to clarify this matter for honourable senators, a by-election in southern New South Wales for a local council area could have affected TV advertising relating to an election in Victoria which could have been held many months distant, yet the ABT felt that because of the regulations in this Act and because of a council election in southern New South Wales it had to warn the seven TV and radio stations situated in Victoria that they should not be running Liberal Party advertisements. What an absolute farce! As Petro Georgiou said:
The Labor Party has set out to protect itself by banning political ads, but forming a rats nest of contradiction and stupidity.

How true that is. I inform Senator Faulkner that even the State Secretary of the ALP, Ms Jenny Beacham, who is probably a person well known to him, was reported in the Age as saying that she was surprised the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal had interpreted the Act so widely. An absurd result occurred as a result of the Hume Local Council election in southern New South Wales and its consequent effect on Victoria.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Faulkner will recall, Senator Olsen raised these concerns at the Senate Select Committee hearing on a number of occasions. His concerns were dismissed by the Committee's report, yet what he predicted so well has in fact occurred. One positive result from the debacle of the Hume Local Council election of New South Wales and its effect on Victoria is that it seems to have prompted some rethinking by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure you have spoken to me about this.

—I am quoting from one of Senator Kernot's spokespersons in the press. Occasionally one does not know who to speak to in her party. It is a very divided party. All I am doing is quoting the press report. The Democrats' spokesperson said in the press report that they never intended the Act to ban advertising in local government elections. That is what their spokesperson said.
—Really!

—The press spokesman also said that the Democrats would consider putting through amendments to the Act to make sure that that occurs. So when Senator Kernot stands up, she can tell us how she is going to fix that to get the amendments through this chamber and the other place.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats were told time and time again that this Bill was rushed through the Parliament and that these silly consequences would occur, yet they insisted on bunging it through, helping the Labor Party get it through the Parliament. I do not know whether Senator Kernot is having second thoughts about it, but some people in her party are.

TALK.START.PARA: —No serious second thoughts.

—No serious second thoughts? Senator Kernot thinks that the consequences of the Act and the way it related to local government elections in Hume in New South Wales and its effect on Victoria are perfectly okay. Someone in the Australian Democrats says that they will amend the Act. As I said, Senator Kernot can tell us, firstly, whether that is correct and, secondly, if they are going to amend the Act, how they will do it.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to Senator Kernot that the only way to do this in a practical sense is to throw out these regulations lock, stock and barrel. That will ensure that the confusion does not occur. But the Democrats will not do that because they are getting a $1.5m bonus out of this Act, and there is no way that they will support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In proportion to the voters we represent.
—In proportion to their voters; but not everybody else who can claim 5 per cent of the vote will get what the Democrats have for got themselves.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht spoke about the results of the election in Tasmania. We repeatedly said that, if this Bill were passed, it would seriously affect groups apart from the major political parties and stifle free speech across a broad range of political activity. The Australian Democrats will say, `We did not get any free time in Tasmania'. Of course they did not get any free time in Tasmania because they did not run any candidates.

Since our human rights expert in this chamber, Senator Schacht, told us that it all worked well in Tasmania, let us take the case of the company Forest Resources and the Forest Industries Association whose advertisements were withdrawn by Tasmanian television stations because they might have breached the political advertising ban Act during the State election. It is clear that the legislation is so wide and ill-constructed that Tasmanian television stations could not risk the wrath of the Government should the ads be deemed to be in breach of the regulations. Senator Kernot would not worry about that because the matter involved a forest company and a forest association; but they are entitled to free speech and to put their views across as much as she is.

So one particular group with a major interest in jobs in that State—and jobs was a central issue of the campaign in Tasmania—was unable to put its views across. But guess which group could put its views across on free time? The Green Independents had plenty of free time to put their views across. I would like Senator Kernot, when she gets up, to tell me whether she believes that that is fair so that we can test yet again the commitment of the Australian Democrats to human rights. Again, we will wait with interest for Senator Kernot's speech.

According to Dr Robert Bain, the Executive Director of the National Association of Forest Industries, the advertisements which were pulled had been running for months and, in his view, none of them contained a political message. Yet, as Dr Bain explained, they fell foul of the legislation simply because forestry may have become an issue in the Tasmanian election. So while the forest industry was prevented from running its ads, there is no doubt that the Green Independents, who in many areas opposed the forest industry, were given a pretty good go at putting their views on television.

But the debacle did not end there. It may not be appreciated by honourable senators that, when the Forest Industries Association advertisement was banned in Tasmania, it caused the cancellation of the advertisement in regional Victoria. How did this happen? It so happens that the television station handling the advertisements for the forest industry in Tasmania receives part of its programming from BCV-8 in Bendigo, Victoria. Consequently, when the advertisements were banned in Tasmania they were also pulled in regional Victoria, even though there was no election there. Again, we see shades of the Hume local government election.
As the editorial in the Australian newspaper observed:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's dangerous ban on political advertising through the electronic media has affected the election campaign in Tasmania, to the detriment of voters—and the election.
It concluded:
Bans on freedom to communicate information can only stifle useful debate and informed voting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who cares what the voters think about it?

—I am glad that that phrase is recorded in Hansard because it may well come back to haunt Senator Kernot. `Who cares what the voters think?', says Senator Kernot. I care what the voters think, as do those opposite. The Democrats's vote has fallen to 5 per cent, so it is no wonder they do not care what the voters think.
—You don't care what the voters think; you only care what the Australian newspaper says. Ask some voters.

—The Australian newspaper industry is the big winner out of this ban because, as Senator Kernot well knows, the money that would have been spent by political parties on television ads will be diverted in part to advertisements in newspapers. So in that practical sense, newspapers are the big winners.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Kernot does not understand is that, unlike our human rights expert, Senator Schacht, the newspapers are taking a principled stand. Despite the financial benefit they get from this Act—like the one the Democrats get from the Act—they are violently opposed to what they call a dangerous ban. The newspapers are quite right in opposing it.

The election in the ACT was raised, and a number of matters occurred that are worth recording for later consideration. One issue that arose in that election was privatisation. It is interesting that ACT Electricity and Water was allowed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to continue an advertising campaign of community messages with a `feel-good' appearance, as they say, which clearly could have been interpreted as or had the effect of influencing viewers' minds on the issue of privatisation. That advertising was apparently allowed to run, although, as I mentioned, the privatisation issue was a matter of debate in the ACT.

The forest industry, whose ads were banned in the Tasmanian election, was allowed to run ads in the ACT election. It is no wonder that there is total confusion over how this Act operates. People who wish to take part in election campaigns do not know what their rights are.

Other issues are involved. Honourable senators will recall the referendum campaign in the ACT. The Hare-Clark Campaign Committee was the victim of the Act this time. Despite receiving legal advice from four separate sources, as well as initial verbal advice from the ABT, that it could run its ads in favour of the Hare-Clark system, it joined the banned brigade in the end. At the last moment the solicitors advising FACTS advised television stations not to run the ads. Apparently, FACTS used a very narrow interpretation of the Act. But can it be blamed? In the absence of reliable guidelines, the industry has been forced to err on the restrictive side or run the risk of heavy fines or, indeed, licence loss.

Apparently, it was argued in the ACT in relation to the referendum and the Hare-Clark Campaign Committee that, because a political party was registered with the name `Hare-Clark' in its title and the candidate for that party was entitled to free time as a former member of the Legislative Assembly, the Hare-Clark Campaign Committee could not run its ads. The risk posed by the Bolkus Act was too high. In other words, it was said that this information was already being run in free time. The fact that it was being run by a different organisation and people who may or may not have had the same focus on a particular issue did not deter FACTS. It was clear that FACTS had to make a very conservative decision in the absence of clear guidelines. That example highlights the unfairness with which these regulations treat community groups.

It also highlights the fact that, given the lack of guidelines, TV stations are forced to withdraw advertisements which might not offend the Act, just to avoid the chance that after the fact they might lose their licences. That has happened. Senator Kernot can sneer, but who can blame the TV stations for taking a very restrictive view because they may lose their licences?

TALK.START.PARA: —A bloody minded view.

—Senator Kernot may believe that she would be pretty tough on this but, again, it is not her money on the line; it is not her licence on the line. As was pointed out by some of my colleagues, one party in the ACTU was able to circumvent the Act. One party was able to get its advertisements on TV and in the clubs. What party do honourable senators think that was? It was the ALP. Members of the ALP believe in rules to tightly regulate and restrict election activities. They believe in that legislation. But they do not believe in applying it to themselves, as we have seen time and time again.

PARA.TAB: Just what are the criteria being used by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to determine what advertisements can be aired and which cannot? This question has been raised by the Business Council of Australia, which has expressed concern that the ABT has no clear guidelines for determining what advertisements may be banned under this Act. The BCA is also concerned about the prospective element of the ABT's discretion. That is, the ABT not only has the apparent discretion to ban an advertisement dealing with an issue which is the subject of an election, but also may ban an advertisement that might become an issue in the election. Exactly how the ABT determines the subjective element is a matter of great concern, I suspect, to a wide range of community groups. As the Business Council's Director, Mr Paul Barrett, has observed:

SPEECH.PARA: It is vital that the ABT publicly explain its interpretation of the new laws.
Mr Barrett is further reported as saying:

PARA.TAB: The ABT has adopted a wide interpretation of what constitutes political broadcasting, one which has particular implications for the rights of individual businesses and business organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just business organisations that are affected, but any community organisation which wishes to run advertisements which could be interpreted as being in any way political. As I said, just look at what happened to the Forest Industries Association.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer, the shadow Minister for Administrative Services, wrote to Mr Westerway, the Chairman of the ABT, seeking some clarification on paid advertisements on radio and TV in respect of the referendum in the Australian Capital Territory. In reply, Mr Westerway said that the ABT does not have the charter it claims to issue guidelines to licensees as to what is an acceptable or unacceptable advertisement in relation to the Act. Instead, it is up to the licensee to decide the issue—and at his peril if he gets it wrong. The licensee can be forgiven, therefore, if he decides to withdraw questionable advertisements and to avoid the possibility of massive fines or the loss of a licence.

I have been through a number of examples which have emerged in relation to the elections which have been held in the seven weeks since this legislation became law. I believe that these regulations, and the way they have been interpreted, cause massive confusion and serious inequities in relation to the campaigns which were run in the various States and the ACT. I have shown how the Act can have very perverse effects where, for example, a local government election in New South Wales can affect political advertisements in my home State of Victoria.

This is disgraceful legislation. It was brought in to advantage the Labor Party in its state of financial crisis, a financial crisis mirrored in the financial crisis to which it has led this country. I believe, along with my colleagues, that the regulations which are before this chamber should be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard another imbecilic performance by Senator Kemp. I suppose that we should be used to that by now. We suffered similar rantings and ravings by Senator Kemp right through the proceedings of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. Although I did not agree with a word that Senator Olsen said in this chamber today, at least he presented his arguments in a far more measured tone. Having heard Senator Kemp speak on this matter for about the tenth time, my only suggestion is that the next time he comes into the Senate and speaks on this matter he take a couple of Valium so that we can get through it a little easier than we did on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in January this year that the Government would monitor the effectiveness of this legislation and would re-examine it with the experience of the Entrance by-election, the Tasmanian State election and the ACT election behind him. He did that because so many amendments had been moved to the original legislation that it would be sensible to see how it worked in its final form after it had been tested.

Now that those three elections are over, there is certainly an ample supply of evidence for us all to examine. The first thing that should be said is that this legislation has produced some of the expected benefits that those on this side of the chamber argued would occur as a result of this legislation being enacted, plus a benefit that no-one really expected or canvassed during the debate that we had on this legislation. That was the benefit of the return to personalised campaigning, or grass roots campaigning as it has been termed by others.

I would like to concentrate on three aspects in trying to make a judgment on the effectiveness of the legislation: firstly, voter turnout; secondly, the quality of campaigning; and, thirdly, the cost of campaigning. In relation to voter turnout, we were told by the Opposition ad nauseam that, with an electronic advertisement ban, electors would not know an election was on, would not go out and vote, and that there would be a low voter turnout.

The first real test of that came smack in the middle of the Christmas holidays when, for the first time since 1939, the Premier of New South Wales called a State by-election in the middle of the Christmas holidays. Of course, I expect these sneaky, desperate manoeuvres from people like Nick Greiner, and he was very desperate. He is really on the ropes in New South Wales. He has lost his parliamentary majority. So he decided to pull a swiftie on the voters of the Entrance. He hoped to catch everyone napping. He hoped to catch the Labor voters who were out on the beach having a well-earned holiday and thought that he would be able to use a dirty trick to gain some short term political advantage and perhaps win the Entrance by-election.

So, even though this is the first by-election held in the Christmas holidays in New South Wales since 1939, the voter turnout in The Entrance was outstanding. Also, for the 10 by-elections held prior to The Entrance by-election in New South Wales, the turnout figure ranged from 70.06 per cent in the North Shore by-election to 87.6 per cent in the by-election for Wallsend. In the by-election for The Entrance, the turnout was 91.01 per cent—in the middle of the school holidays. That compared with a general election turnout in The Entrance on 25 May 1991 of 93.46 per cent. Nobody, not even the Opposition, can argue that that is not an outstanding result in terms of voter turnout. In fact, it is a record by-election turnout in New South Wales.

The Opposition also said that without electronic advertising there would be a massively increased informal vote in elections but, of course, that proved to be incorrect in The Entrance also because, while the informal vote in the general election of 1991 was 8.26 per cent, in The Entrance by-election it was 1.57 per cent—a drop of 6.69 per cent. So, again, they are extraordinary figures. The only differences that I can see between what occurred in The Entrance and all other by-elections and the general election are, firstly, the sneaky trick of Nick Greiner to hold it when he thought people would not be around—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Mr Greiner', please.

—The sneaky trick of Mr Greiner to hold it when he thought no-one would be around in the school holidays; and, secondly, the electronic advertising ban. Those figures are even more amazing when one considers that absentee voting was not available to the electors in The Entrance.

PARA.TAB: A similar pattern can be seen in Tasmania. In the previous State election in Tasmania the total State turnout was 93.5 per cent, but in the recent State election, again, there was an increased voter turnout of 95 per cent. I might say that the seat of Braddon had its highest turnout ever. There was a turnout of 96.7 per cent; the previous figure was 94 per cent.

Again in Tasmania, the State-wide informal vote fell from 5.3 per cent at the previous State election to 3.8 per cent on the most recent occasion—giving the lie to what the Opposition said would occur in relation both to turnout figures and to informal voting. Frankly, I think we can say that the jury is not out on either of those issues: everything that the Opposition argued would occur in relation to these voting statistics was wrong—on all counts.

Another thing that has changed, of course, is the quality of campaigning. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 January, Deidre Macken, talking about The Entrance by-election in New South Wales, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Without the distractions of music and slow-motion images of politicians, the messages should become more substantial, thoughtful and detailed.

Of course, that has become true. What has occurred is that, with the electronic advertising ban during the campaign period, candidates had to get out and do more grassroots and more localised campaigning. For the first time in a long while, prospective politicians had to get out and meet a few voters—and many people from all sides of politics have recorded that as a very positive impact of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: In an article in the Age of 1 February of this year, Andrew Darby said this:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been another discovery: that electors still like to meet the politicians they vote for. In community halls, on boat cruises, at athletics carnivals and in street markets, all the serious candidates have been out meeting voters.

At the time this legislation went through, there were some who suggested—even some in the Australian Labor Party—that the Labor Party might well be throwing away a great advantage that it had as a political campaign tool, because there is no doubt that the Labor Party has proved, over at least the last decade if not the last two decades, that it was a far superior campaigner on the electronic media. It was suggested that we might in fact be throwing away a major advantage. But I am pleased to say that The Entrance by-election result proves yet again that our superiority is not limited to only the electronic media; we are certainly superior at localised and personalised grassroots campaigning.

PARA.TAB: That was shown by not only the result in The Entrance but also the response of the electors of The Entrance to our doorknocking campaigns and our booth workers. This can be contrasted with the way the Liberal Party handled the election campaign, which was to hire some spivvy electronic media consultants who were associated with one of Reagan's election campaigns in an attempt to buy the by-election, having already tried to gain a distinct advantage by pulling on the election in the Christmas holidays. It did not work.

This move to grassroots campaigning is something that not only Labor Party members can say advantages them; there is also a range of people from other political parties who have obviously noted that some of the impacts of this legislation are very good. Let us take, for example, Tasmania, where a range of Liberal Party candidates and officials argued that the ban, in fact, had been very positive for the whole of the political process. That included the Mouth from the South, Michael Hodgman, and Bob Lister, the coordinator of the Liberal Party campaign in Tasmania. On the AM radio program on 28 January he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, certainly the public have had the opportunity to question policies and candidates which, I am sure, is a good thing, and I believe the candidates have got closer to the public with some of their issues and have listened to the public, so I think that can only be good for the campaign, as well.
He went on, as Senator Bolkus said earlier, to say:
I don't believe there's any disadvantage for any particular party.

Of course, the proof of the pudding is in the eating: the senior Liberals in recent elections and by-elections have conceded that they have no reason to complain about this legislation or the results of it.

PARA.TAB: The only other thing I would like to touch on is the issue of cost in election campaigns. The new Tasmanian Premier, Mr Groom, indicated that the cost of the Liberal Party campaign in Tasmania was down by about 50 per cent. The Australian Labor Party's campaign coordinator in Tasmania said that the Labor figures were very similar. Of course, the only exception to that was The Entrance by-election, where the Labor Party's campaign expenditure was down significantly—well under six figures—whereas, of course, the Liberal Party on that occasion tried to buy the by-election by spending over a quarter of a million dollars, but I am pleased to say that it failed.

At least there is significant evidence that things are moving in the right direction. From the two elections and one by-election since this advertising ban was put in place, there is significant evidence that the costs of campaigns have come down. I believe that that will in turn lead to cleaning up the political process in this country—something which the Government has so strongly supported and which was the fundamental reason for our introducing this legislation into the Parliament last year.

In summary, to the extent that we have been able to make a judgment about the effect of the Bill in its operation in the ACT election, the Tasmanian State election and the Entrance by-election, I think that it has worked well. There is every hope, and the evidence suggests, that the legislation will work well again in the future. I oppose this preposterous disallowance motion presently before the Senate. I ask not only the Government but also the Democrat senators to hit this motion right out of the ballpark to where it belongs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess that the attraction of this debate is that it is something of a re-run of the so-called passion that we experienced in the all night session back in December. I do not think that there has been very much emphasis on the substance of this debate about why the regulations ought to be disallowed. After all, I think this is just an opportunity to have a re-run of all the arguments that we heard for all of those hours—arguments with which we are very familiar—as to why we should not have this Act.

PARA.TAB: I would like to reflect on the regulations for a moment. Senator Olsen said that the Australian Democrats joined with the Government in condemning the Clerk of the Senate. Of course, he checked with me, did he not, before he made that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he?

—He did not check with me. It is absolutely untrue that we condemn the Clerk of the Senate for fulfilling the important role that he has played in providing advice to honourable senators in this place.
—Aren't you going to condemn Senator Bolkus?

—The advice that the Clerk provides is of important assistance to us in our role as senators. However, I think the real issue which nobody else has touched on yet concerns what is being done with that advice. I ask Senator Parer to tell us whether he checked with the Clerk of the Senate for his permission to distribute this advice as an attachment to a press release.
—Aren't you going to condemn the Minister?

—I will condemn any member of this place, including the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who makes reflections on the role of the Clerk of the Senate in fulfilling his job of providing advice. I ask Senator Parer whether he had the permission of the Clerk of the Senate to distribute that advice as an attachment to a press release. What worries me is that the words of the advice which I have seen are qualified. The advice is carefully worded, of course, as one would expect it to be. The advice states:

SPEECH.PARA: If this interpretation is correct—
not `This interpretation is correct'—
there are no valid regulations in force relating to Tasmania, the ACT and New South Wales.
Suddenly, `If this interpretation is correct' becomes:

Advice from the Clerk of the Senate suggests television stations in New South Wales, Tasmania and the ACT could sue the Government for lost advertising in the wake of the Political Ad-ban Legislation.
And:
. . . the Clerk has provided me with an opinion which confirms that the regulations. . . are invalid.

I think it is very unfortunate that the advice of the Clerk has been distributed and misused in this way. The qualification is a very big and important qualification. It is one thing to seek advice, but it is another thing to use that advice in a partisan political way.

PARA.TAB: Previous speakers have cited examples of those who, having experienced the impact of this legislation for the first time, have pronounced it to work well and to be a great idea. I too want to go on record as quoting the remarks of that very voluble Liberal from Tasmania, Mr Hodgman, who is reported in the Age to have said that the campaign in Tasmania conducted under this legislation was a very successful exercise not just because of the face-to-face contact but also because politicians in markets and on corners talking to constituents were a very colourful scene which captured media attention.

During the debate we heard a great deal about how nobody would be able to get his message onto the news because the news would not want to cover such boring things as politicians talking to electors. That has not been the early experience in Tasmania. The article went on to say that Mr Hodgman believes that the legislation is quite popular with the community and that he thinks that people `are very glad not to see politicians in their living rooms all the time'. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been another discovery: that electors still like to meet the politicians they vote for.
That is a very important principle of which we have lost sight in campaigning in recent years. The article continued:
In community halls, on boat cruises and at athletic carnivals and in street markets all the serious candidates have been out meeting voters.
That is much healthier than people voting for anonymous candidates on party tickets. The Australian newspaper of 24 February this year stated:
Politicians are having to work to win votes as both the Labor Party and the Coalition embark upon old-fashioned `press the flesh' campaigns to beat the ban on television and radio commercials.

That is another healthy return to something which, I think, can only be to the advantage of the political process in this country. In the ACT elections, Malcolm Mackerras made a point of saying to the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, that although he was opposed to the legislation when he first heard about it, now having seen it work, having been part of the Hare-Clark campaign in the ACT, he thought that it had worked extremely well and that it had not been disadvantageous to the political process.

PARA.TAB: At this point I have a word of criticism for the ACT Chief Minister, Rosemary Follett, and the ALP because I believe that they deliberately flouted the spirit of the legislation by advertising in cinemas and on closed-circuit television—not on Sky Channel, as Senator Olsen asserted, but on closed-circuit television in clubs. Of course, this does not come under the technical definition of free to air broadcasting. Nevertheless, the intention of using it is exactly the same.

It has always been the Australian Democrats' view that cinemas and closed-circuit television ought to be included in some definition of broadcasting. The ALP may have thought that it was very clever to have exploited this loophole, but I think it is just typical of the tactics and the manipulation that the electorate is crying out to be protected from and which is represented in their approval of this legislation. I understand that when the advertisements were shown in the cinemas they were greeted with loud and hearty boos.

Senator Olsen and others have been raising the argument yet again of the loss of freedom of speech. I point out to him what his Liberal colleagues are doing in Victoria. Within the spirit of the Bill, they are now advertising, as they are allowed to under this Bill, for the 337 days of the year when an election campaign is not being conducted.

The merit of this is that people watching these advertisements have time for reflection, consideration and discussion of the issues raised. I think that is a necessary part of the democratic process. They should not be bombarded by 30 second grabs and mindless jingles and slogans; they should have time to think.

Senator Kemp said that commercial television networks operated in fear of being in breach of the regulations. The truth is, I believe, that the television networks were absolutely bloody-minded because it suited them to be in their interpretation of the regulations. They wanted to show that they could make it difficult for the regulations to work.

When they screened the free time, they coincidentally said, `We are being forced to show this advertisement and this advertisement is costing us money'. But it was rather funny how in the Queensland referendum campaign the commercial television stations were quick to jump in and offer free time to those who were advocating a Yes vote because that vote coincided with their own political view. There was no concern there about the loss of revenue or the principle of having to screen advertisements on a political point of view because it coincided with their own view. It was hypocrisy on their part.

Senator Olsen said that the Democrats had walked away from the protection of the rights of the individual. In fact, I repeat that this legislation protects people from the emotive, manipulative, deceptive advertising which has been a characteristic of campaigns in this decade. Senator Olsen said that the Democrats were advantaged by this legislation. He said that we had our hands in the lolly jar, and Senator Kemp repeated that we would receive the benefit of $1.5m.

Senator Kemp might be surprised to know that I do not resile from this because it is a consequence of an important principle—the principle that democracy should not depend on the purchasing power of political parties, and that everyone who is represented in this Parliament is entitled to be heard. It does not matter whether the 10 per cent of the vote is reflected proportionately in $1.5m, $500,000, $2m, or whatever is the going rate for advertisements; it is the principle that matters.

If Senator Kemp does not like the democratic principle, if he prefers the principle that money talks, I do not believe that he can stand up and talk about freedom of speech and the rights of the individual. Whether the 10 per cent translates into money for the Democrats, the Greens, the Citizens Electoral Council, the Fred Nile group or the conservative Liberal Party, the principle is that money should not speak. Much more important is the principle of people being represented in proportion to the votes cast in favour of their candidate. They have a right to be heard.

Senator Kemp said that the Democrats did not qualify for free time in Tasmania because they did not run. Of course, that was the case, but he neglected to use the example of the ACT where they did run and where they did not qualify for free time. They accept that and they were not elected. Senator Kemp spoke of the need for amendment, as if that would be such a shockingly outrageous thing. Of course we never amend legislation in this place, do we? Without compromising the spirit and principle of the Bill, on behalf of the Democrats I am willing to look at areas where amendment is needed or necessary.

I remind honourable senators of the words I used in my speech during the second reading debate. I said that very few Acts of Parliament are perfect, whether drafted by Labor or Liberal governments. It is more than appropriate that we review all legislation. That is why we successfully moved an amendment to this Bill calling for an automatic review of this Act after two Federal elections.

I am not convinced that the technical problems with the regulations, the failure to gazette by the due date, the renumbering by the Clerk of the House of Representatives, or the other anomalies to which previous speak-

SPEECH.PARA: ers have alluded, are sufficient to warrant the disallowance of these regulations. By all means let us look at where some of the smaller hitches occurred, but let us not abandon the principle that money does not buy government in this country.

PARA.TAB: Let us not go down the American path. The coalition in its health policy has rightly identified the fact that it does not want to go down the American path where only those who can afford to can receive adequate medical attention. We in the Democrats do not want to go down that path in the conduct of elections in this country. Let us not abandon the principle that money should not buy government—that information and not glib misinformation is vital to democracy.

I believe the arguments in this debate and the way the electorate feels about the matter were well summed up in a cartoon I saw. The cartoon portrayed viewers sitting in front of a television set on which were the words `Political advertising banned'. The viewers were celebrating with glasses of champagne and streamers. There was much jollity. They know that they are being saved from banality and from the misinformation that does nothing for the democratic processes in this country.

With the concentration on grassroots campaigning, which has been one of the consequences of this legislation, I think the ultimate effect could well be that the level of the public's respect for this institution and for parliamentarians could well be raised. We have to argue that that could only be positive. We have had a re-run of all the same old arguments and we will get them again. The principles are clear and the Democrats cannot support the disallowance of these regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are debating a particular brand of Labor democracy. We have done so on many occasions. When Labor ran out of money because Western Australia Inc. came to light, it decided that at the next election it would not have enough money to advertise on the electronic media. The view was that if it could not do it, nobody could. Labor argued that if it could not pay and we were not allowed to pay, there must be a way around it—so it decided that it would get the taxpayers or the commercial companies and the television stations to pay. So once again the taxpayers are to foot the bill.

PARA.TAB: Let us not forget that it was only a few years ago that the Government decided that the taxpayers really should be footing the bill for an election campaign. The Government decided that the taxpayers should pay the relevant party 92c—nearly a dollar—per vote for that party. Following the first election the votes were counted and at the next election the taxpayers had to pay that particular party nearly a dollar a vote for every vote it collected. That applied to all the parties and all the independents that got the vote. So the taxpayer is already paying a considerable amount for each Federal election.

The coalition vigorously opposed that legislation. We do not believe that the taxpayers should be burdened with that type of payment. I ask whether Senator Button could imagine that applying to the States. At the moment, with Labor getting only 29 per cent of the vote in Tasmania, at the next election it would not have much to spend. That is quite a thought. However, that does not apply to State elections, only to Federal elections.

Let us have a look at what else the taxpayer will pay for under this new legislation. In all their wisdom the Government and the Democrats decided that they would not have the money come an election and that the taxpayers would pay for every household in Australia to get a pamphlet put out by every candidate—not every sitting member, every candidate. So the thousands of candidates that will be up for the next election for all the seats in the House of Representatives and the Senate will be entitled to have their personal pamphlet put in the letterbox of every household at taxpayers' expense. It is estimated that will cost over $8m in addition to what the taxpayers already pay.

Imagine the abuse in a country town where a businessman has set himself up and has not been doing too well. He cannot afford the normal advertising that would blanket every household. He could decide that, for the up-front payment of just $250, he would supposedly stand as a candidate because his pamphlet would contain his photograph and what he wanted to put in it. Therefore, for that paltry cost he would be able to have a pamphlet containing a description of him and his business and a photograph, put in the letterbox of every single household in his area—all paid for by the taxpayer.

Senator Button will acknowledge, because he has been here some time and done it for many elections—as I have done—how difficult it is, after all the candidates have been selected, to get their photographs and what they want in their pamphlets all concisely done very quickly. The Electoral Commission will be responsible for getting that pamphlet into the letterboxes. Sometimes it is only three weeks before the election that the last of the independents or the candidates are selected. In those three weeks the Electoral Commission would be responsible for getting photographs of all the candidates in Australia and what they want in their pamphlets delivered into the letterboxes of householders. Can the chamber imagine this being done in time? Absolute rubbish! As I have already said, the abuse that is open to a businessman, for a paltry cost of $250, to saturate his area with his photograph and his business advertisements, I believe, is quite a problem.

So we have the taxpayer paying for that. We have the ABC—and, of course, it is not the ABC, it is the taxpayer—once again paying for a considerable amount of free time. We have the television and radio commercial stations also being told they will foot the bill. Not the Government, not the taxpayer, but the commercial stations are being forced to put on free time and foot the bill. What will happen is that the commercial stations will pass on those costs of the advertisements to businesses. So there is an additional cost for businesses.

We have the free time on radio and the free time on television being forced on commercial stations, the taxpayer paying for the ABC and this is how the Government is meant to be making election advertisements more fair and equitable. It might more fair and equitable for the coffers of the Labor Party and the Democrats, but it is not more fair and equitable for the taxpayer.

That is not where it stops. Also in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, donations between $2 and $100 to a political party will be tax deductible. I ask Senator Button: what will be the cost of that to the taxpayer?

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted it unlimited.

—We did not want the Bill at all, and Senator Bourne knows that. We suggested that, if the Government was going to force unions into paying for the Labor Party, it must also make that fair and equitable.

PARA.TAB: It does not stop there. The taxpayer is also paying millions of dollars in direct mail. Let us not misunderstand how much the Government has altered that. Every politician is now given a considerable amount of money—often as much as people earn—to direct mail their whole constituency. So, come an election, the taxpayer will be paying a considerable amount.

It is only the particular brand of democracy that the Labor Party believes in that comes into this legislation. We have heard a lot from Senator Kernot, Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus on how well this went down in Tasmania. Again, they only used their own brand of democracy. Let me tell the chamber just what did occur in Tasmania. The Labor and Liberal parties got their fair share of free time. They did very well. We admitted we did very well out of it. So did Labor; it got its fair share of free time.

What happened to the independents? We had a considerable number of independents. One group, the Advance Tasmania Group, ran candidates in every electorate. The only reason they were not a party was that they did not have time to go through the formal procedure to turn themselves into a party. So they were still a group and, as such, they were independents. All the independents' names went into a hat and one was drawn out. He did not belong to the Advance Tasmania Group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ian Jamieson from the west coast.

—It was Mr Jamieson from the west coast. He was the one lucky independent in the whole of Tasmania who got free time. Good democracy Labor style! Fantastic democracy Labor style! Senator Kernot put it very well today: make sure all those in Parliament can be heard but do not worry and let us all forget about the independents and the people not yet in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is an absolute disgrace. As I have said many times in this Parliament, the Labor Party has its own brand of democracy and it will use it according to its likes and forget what democracy is all about. My reading of democracy is that, come an election, everyone should be able to broadcast and put their advertisements across. Everyone should be able to raise the money to do so; the taxpayer should not have to. Those whose names are not drawn out of a hat should not be denied the right to be heard on radio and television, which this Government and this legislation forces on them.

I come now to the issue of referendums. During the parliamentary recess two referendums have been held—one in Queensland, a referendum on daylight saving, and one in the ACT, a referendum on the Hare-Clark system versus single member electorates.According to the Act, advertising for a referendum was meant to be excluded only when that referendum applied to the Constitution. Neither of these referendums applied to the Constitution. Yet in Queensland advertising was allowed but in the ACT no advertising took place. Senator Parer wrote to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to seek its advice on whether this was the correct procedure in the ACT or whether it could advertise. He was told by the Tribunal:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal cannot assess material for broadcast before it has gone to air. It can respond to complaints from viewers and listeners after a program has been broadcast only.
We had the situation where no-one in the ACT was game to put in advertisements for the referendum. The whole thing is a complete shemozzle.

PARA.TAB: We have had an election in our State where the Government was absolutely thrashed. It got only 29 per cent of the vote. In the electorate of Braddon, where there were candidates for seven positions, only one Labor member won and that was the Premier. The only seat out of seven members that Labor could win was one. The Liberals got five seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should have got six.

—They nearly got six. In the final cut-up one of the Greens eventually got elected. So we had one Labor member, one Green and five Liberals. This particular brand of democracy that the Labor Party pushes will go against it on every single occasion. I believe this was one of the causes for such a landslide against it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's disgraceful misrepresentation yesterday of a paper prepared by Dr Chris Murphy relating to the coalition's Fightback package and to the fact that Dr Murphy has subsequently found it necessary to issue a formal statement correcting the Prime Minister's `significant misrepresentation'. Why did Mr Keating fail to tell the truth on this matter on his first full day in the Parliament as Prime Minister, and is this the standard of political integrity we can expect from him in the lead-up to the next election?

—I think the Prime Minister said something about Dr Hewson playing the man rather than the ball yesterday and on several previous occasions. Let me just say in relation to that that one of the extraordinary things about this Opposition has been its incapacity to read its own documents, to read the tables in the Fightback! document, and to understand what Dr Murphy was in fact saying in his paper delivered at the ANU.

PARA.TAB: Let me tell honourable senators what the Murphy paper in fact shows. It shows that under the scenarios in the Fightback! document, unemployment would be higher after five years—only a little higher under the base case to which Dr Murphy refers, but by two percentage points if wage setting arrangements could not be guaranteed and they had to be discounted for the higher prices arising from the Hewson package. That is what Dr Murphy's paper says and shows.

The Opposition, which has no wages policy at all, speaks about the possibility of discounting wages—a defect which was with the Liberal Party through eight years of the previous Government, which is still loitering around and which will come back to haunt it every day of the next 12 months. Looking at what Dr Murphy says, those opposite have to ask themselves why workers would discount wages in the terms suggested under the Hewson package which would increase the price of food and clothing and all the staples that are much more relevant in the economy of a lower income family than they are in a rich family. And that is a fact—the price of food and clothing is a much more relevant fact for a poorer family. So why would workers discount wages, as is suggested? It would have to be a marvellous wage policy which would deliver such a result. But, of course, there is no wage policy at all.

The fact of the matter is that Dr Hewson himself is more intent on talking up confrontation with unions than in arriving at a sensible wages policy. Liberal Prime Ministers were more interested in going to royal weddings than dealing with wage policy issues. If there were ever a Liberal government again, its leader—the present leader, if he remains leader—would be more interested in confrontation than working out a sensible wages policy.
What do we have in Dr Murphy's paper, which I hope all those opposite will read? I hope they will look at the table on page 8 of the Murphy paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at his press release and see how he bags Keating.

—Yes, have a look at his press release—a simple-minded grab for the press. There are no pictures in it, so Senator Alston probably would not understand it. Under Murphy's own scenario, there would be a small increase in unemployment over five years and a small reduction in unemployment 10 or 20 years out. Those opposite may think they are going to be there for the long haul—10 or 20 years—but the people of Australia would not tolerate that.

PARA.TAB: This is what it would mean: in pursuit of an ideologically led, tax-led recovery, so-called, the people of Australia would be put through the incredible pain of there being no improvement in the unemployment situation and no improvement in GDP for 20 quarters. If the coalition could not deliver discounting of wages, there would in fact, under the Murphy document, be an increase in unemployment. Murphy goes on to establish that.

I refer those opposite to Dr Murphy's own paper, GST and the Inflation Rate, given on 24 February this year—it is hot off the press. If those opposite study the table on page 8, they will see in respect of the base case that 20 quarters out—that is, five years out—the unemployment rate at best has increased by 0.2 per cent. On the `wages up' case, the unemployment rate has increased by 2.1 per cent. That all depends on the capacity to deliver a wages policy.

The figures on GDP in the same document show real GDP, 20 quarters out, at minus 0.2 on the base case and minus 4.1 if wages go up in the relevant period. Five years of further misery is predicted by Dr Murphy in this document which he seeks to repudiate with a press release.

I suggest that rather than interjecting about this matter, members of the Opposition should go away and try to add a bit of numeracy and literacy to their otherwise noisy behaviour by studying their own document. The first thing they will do when they study their own document is decide, `Well, we will have to get out of some of this consumption tax nonsense because it is not going to work for us and it is certainly not going to work for the Australian people'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister seems to be adding to the misrepresentations of his leader. The Prime Minister said yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: Dr Murphy says that GDP would be reduced by 4 per cent as a result of the Hewson consumption tax. . .
I ask the Minister specifically: why did Mr Keating make that false statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a false statement at all.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If those opposite stop yelling and look at the document, they will see that there are three scenarios in relation to GDP. If wages go up—that is to say, there is no discounting for wages in terms of the iniquitous burden which will be imposed—
—Why should there be?

—`Why should there be?', said Senator Short. It is because the Opposition's consumption tax will put 15 per cent on the cost of clothing and food for every family in this country, and those opposite know that. If wages go up, if wages are not discounted—that figure is in Dr Murphy's document.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the review of the Materials Research Laboratory and the possible effect of that review on the food science establishment at Scottsdale in north-east Tasmania. The word seems to be around that the review will recommend removal of the laboratory from Tasmania. Can the Minister say whether this is true? At what stage is the decision making process? Can the Minister confirm that the matter is not already determined and that it might still be possible for this valuable institution to remain at Scottsdale?

—Following the force structure review and the Wrigley interdepartmental committee, DSTO is required to reduce its staffing by 700 by June 1996. The review of MRL Tasmania is part of a wider review process which is determining options on the implementation of these reductions. The function of the food science branch at Scottsdale is to undertake studies and investigations of energy expenditure, nutrition and the development of ration pack components for the ADF. The branch also operates a small freeze-dried production facility. There are cost penalties and disadvantages in operating a small laboratory at a remote location, some of which are borne by employees, such as diminished career opportunities and limited access to technical and further education services.

PARA.TAB: The report of the review committee was released on 21 February 1992 and made available to staff and unions for comment. The review recommends a transfer of the food science branch in Scottsdale to the main MRL campus in Melbourne with an associated cost saving of $400,000 a year. No final decision on the future of the Scottsdale facility has been taken by government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the recent comments of the Victorian Minister for Agriculture, Mr Ian Baker. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The best we could do, if you gave me a magic wand for industry generally, is to get rid of payroll tax.

I also refer him to Richard Blandy's article in yesterday's Australian in which he said that, from the point of view of business, a cut in payroll tax has the same effect on employment as a cut in wages. Does the Minister agree with his State counterpart's statement and Professor Blandy's comments that payroll tax is a significant burden on Australian business and costs many Australians their jobs? Is the Government proposing to take measures to abolish payroll tax, otherwise known as a tax on employment, in the forthcoming economic statement; and if not, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's priorities in terms of the economic statement will be revealed at 7.30 this evening. I do not propose to make a statement about that before then. However, in commenting on payroll tax, Senator Short has chosen a nice double in the Minister for Agriculture in Victoria, Ian Baker, and Professor Blandy. I think Mr Baker knows, as does anyone in the serious business of politics, that there are no magic wands. That is the trap the Opposition has fallen into. The Opposition assumes that there are magic wands in a package such as Fightback. Fightback imposes significant additional tax burdens on the Australian people and promises to abolish—
—It does not; it lowers the tax on business.
—Senator Short knows the tax table; it is a great rort for his rich mates but it is no good for the average Australian.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to be very careful in anything I say about the Fightback package. I think those opposite read it like a Biggles comic: everything in it is the absolute truth. As the year goes by, Senator Short will find out that there are no magic wands in politics. There certainly is not a magic wand with respect to payroll tax.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst I accept that I am not going to get a preview of tonight's statement from Senator Button, I ask him to answer the question that I put to him; namely, whether he agrees with his State counterpart, Ian Baker, that payroll tax is a significant burden on Australian business, that it costs many Australians their jobs and that the best thing one could do for employment and industry generally is to get rid of payroll tax.

—I certainly do not agree with the last part of the question. There are numerous things which are described as burdens on industry. Just as we have payroll tax in Australia, most European countries have a social services levy on business, which is considerably higher than the burden of payroll tax. There are burdens of this kind on industry around the world. The question of the right balance in dealing with the appropriate burdens which industry sees will be addressed tonight in the statement.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to the widespread concern for the continuance and now increasing rate of Aboriginal imprisonment. Is the Minister able to give an assurance that the utmost effort will be made once and for all to counter this dilemma on a national scale? Can the Minister inform the Senate what the major obstacles would be in bringing about the cooperation of the States in a national affirmative action program directed specifically at reducing the Aboriginal imprisonment rate?
—The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided me with the following response to Senator Beahan's question.
—How could he? It is a question without notice.

—Mr President, I am not responsible for this portfolio, as Senator Macdonald knows full well; I represent the Minister in the chamber. The Minister has provided me with the following response. The study found a national increase in the number of Aboriginal people—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The preoccupation some people have with trivia is extraordinary. The study found a national increase in the number of Aboriginal people in prison of 25 per cent. Between June 1987 and June 1991, the increase in particular States was extremely high: an 80 per cent increase in New South Wales; a 75 per cent increase in Victoria; and a 24 per cent increase in Western Australia. It is worth noting that in the Northern Territory and Queensland the number of Aboriginal prisoners declined marginally, although they were still dramatically over-represented in the prison population.
