PARA.TAB: These figures emphasise the vital importance of a comprehensive response to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, something which I am sure all members of this chamber support. These figures emphasise the absolutely vital national response to the Royal Commission, including responses from the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, which is expected to be tabled in Parliament on 31 March.

The Royal Commission's critical finding was that the disproportionate number of Aboriginal people in prison could only be addressed by tackling the underlying issues of Aboriginal disadvantage, such as education, employment, youth policy and substance abuse. The Commonwealth has been engaged in extensive discussions with the States and Territories on the implementation of the recommendations. We will be seeking to continue a cooperative approach in addressing the gross disadvantages of Aboriginal people.

The Government is determined that the Royal Commission's work will result in genuine long term changes in the lives of Australia's Aboriginal people. It must be emphasised that the States and the Territories have a heavy responsibility to join with the Commonwealth in allocating the necessary resources to address the underlying issues highlighted by the Royal Commission's investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has today's Australian Financial Review accurately reported the Government's intentions regarding the Industrial Relations Commission's consideration of enterprise agreements? If the report is accurate, how will the Government ensure that enterprise agreements are genuine, will not compromise award agreements and will not establish precedents for other sectors of the market where their application may not be appropriate? How does the Government intend to honour its commitment to award based wages and conditions in the future? How and by whom will the public interest be represented in the preparation of enterprise agreements?

—In the run up to tonight's economic statement the community of Australia has witnessed a strong piece of professional performance in government. There have been no leaks in the contents of tonight's statement. That has meant that a number of journalists have gone ahead and speculated about what the statement might contain. I do not propose to confirm or deny what the Australian Financial Review has said today with respect to what may or may not be the future of enterprise agreements and what the statement will say about it.

PARA.TAB: The best advice I can offer to anyone in this chamber is that as we are only a few hours off the Prime Minister delivering that statement, the kindest thing we can do is to wait a few hours for him to do that and then judge the statement on its merits, not on what people say it will contain before it has been delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With the neither confirm nor deny line, I wonder whether the Minister really does mean `yes'?
—The English language speaks for itself.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of reports that 21,000 school leavers in Victoria will miss out on university places this year? Will he advise the Senate on whether these reports are accurate and on what the Government is doing about unmet demand for places in higher education?

—I have seen the reports. They are of figures which are greatly overstated. In fact, the real figure will not become available until April when the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee reports the outcome of the oversubscription for university places.

PARA.TAB: It is probably necessary to make a few points in context. First, during the life of this Government the high school retention rate has doubled. Therefore, we have increased funding for higher education by 41 per cent in real terms since coming to office. Over the last five years there has been an explosion in the demand for university places. There are now 120,000 more places at university than there were five years ago, and that is estimated to go up by 25,000 over the next two years. Historically, about 40 per cent of year 12 students go on to university; this year about 80 per cent of year 12 students have applied.

The problem has to be seen against a background of a boom in university education, a record growth in the number of places and a record number of positions being achieved. It also has to be seen against the background that the growth of TAFE has been basically out of balance with the growth of university education. It has not kept up with the universities. It is not as attractive an option as it ought to be and it should be improved. That is the reason why the Government is putting money into and emphasis on the TAFE area—to make it a much more viable option.

The press reports that Senator Zakharov has referred to have indicated that there are 21,000 who will miss out in Victoria, 48,000 in New South Wales, 22,000 in Queensland and 15,000 in South Australia. It will be nothing like that. These are raw figures. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee will look at those figures and the actual figure, as I say, will be about 50,000.

The figures are overstated because some of the applicants are ineligible in the first place; some lodge more than one application at a university or in more than one State; some have a limited range of preferences and will become ineligible; and some would refuse if a place was offered. So we are looking at raw figures which do not indicate what the actual number is because of all of those other factors. As I say, there has been an explosion in demand. That is partly because of the conditions of the general labour market—that is true—and partly because of the high success we have achieved in secondary school retention rates.

By way of contrast, we are trying to make university places available on merit—on the merit of the applicants. The Opposition's policy in the Hewson consumption tax package makes university places available on a `Who can afford to pay the fee?' basis. How much the fee goes up will determine whether one gets a place at university. Therefore, the Opposition would be auctioning places at university to the rich and privileged, not making them available to those who have merit.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are telling fibs like Paul again.
—Liar.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that that interjection be withdrawn.
—Order! I did not hear who made the interjection, but twice today I have heard somebody call out `liar'. It is unparliamentary and I ask that people desist from doing so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Having regard to the fact that the introduction of pay television has been on hold throughout the life of the present Government, and that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure recommended its immediate introduction almost 18 months ago, will the Minister explain why he is now proposing to waste valuable time and taxpayers' money on yet another expensive overseas junket when he ought to be at home making some critical decisions in this area? Will he give an unequivocal undertaking that pay television will proceed in Australia immediately upon the expiry of the latest moratorium on 1 October 1992?

—By the time I return, given that I know of at least one journalist who will be accompanying me on the trip, I doubt very much whether even Senator Alston will be able to claim that this is a junket. The purpose of the trip is to attempt, insofar as it is possible in the space of two weeks, to speak to as many of the regulators, pay TV operators, network players and manufacturers as I can so that I can come back here and live up to the Beazley timetable. To do that I would have to go to Cabinet, I reckon, by about the middle of April or perhaps later on in April, and I will only be able to do that properly if I consider that I have enough knowledge. I think I will need to do a lot of work on that trip to make sure that I am armed with sufficient knowledge to make the proper recommendations to Cabinet.

PARA.TAB: There are, of course, a whole range of issues which need to be addressed with pay television. For a start, the level of foreign ownership will be critical. There are many people in the Government, probably many sitting here right now, who have had the view that that level ought to be restricted to 20 per cent. I am being told by many of those who wish to be players in the pay TV game here that if that is the case, we will not have pay TV. I will be talking to quite a number of them on the trip, and I want to try to assemble enough information to see what kind of level there should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't travel around to get the facts. Officers get the information.

—Senator Lewis is a classic. Senator Lewis says that Ministers do not travel around to get information. If they do not, we are all going to be in awful strife. I can remember a few Ministers when Senator Lewis was in government who did not take the same view. By the way, if Senator Lewis looks at his record of travel, he will see that he is very hard to get off the plane at the best of times; he is not very hard to get on it. Having said that, I do not believe that making decisions in the dark is necessarily a good idea. I intend to see a quite extraordinary number of people in the space of 14 days to make that all possible. I think I have made it pretty clear in the media in the last few days that I would have to be—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask honourable senators on both sides to stop debating.

—I have made it clear in the media in the last few days that I would need to be given a very good reason to have a further delay on pay TV, which is why I have not said at any stage that there will be a delay, and why I have continued to maintain that everything I do will be an attempt to live up to the timetable. If there is going to be any delay, then it will be for some reason that I will have to discover that I do not have now.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister seriously suggesting that there is not already an abundance of evidence on these issues available in Australia? Will he confirm that despite the public outrage which accompanied his extravagant outlays last year on a fleet of hire cars across Ireland and a suite at the London Hyatt Carlton Hotel, he has learned nothing and this time, in the middle of the worst recession in 60 years, not only will he be staying at the Ritz in London but also he will actually be flying Concord?
—As usual, Senator Alston does not get it partly wrong, he gets it totally wrong. No, I will not be staying at the Ritz and no, I will not be flying Concord.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald which outlined proposed changes for a range of charges for AOTC services. What assurances can he give the Senate that the public interest will be considered in any changes that AOTC may make?
—I thank Senator Faulkner for the question.
—Will you look after the public interest?

—Of course I will look after the public interest; that is what I am elected to do and I shall certainly do it in this portfolio. I have been reading with interest the articles over the last few days which suggest that these extra charges are to come in. I have not yet received any formal notification from AOTC of its intentions, at least as far as public pay phones or charging for directory assistance is concerned, but I expect to receive that at some time in the next few days.

PARA.TAB: As for my own role in it, I do not have to worry about those prices which come under the price cap; there are a number of those in rentals and local, STD and international calls. They will be in the price cap of 4 per cent this year and 5 1/2 per cent for 1992-95. So I will not be worried about those. But once public pay phones and charges for directory assistance have been formally notified, I can either disallow them or refer them to Austel. In the normal course of events and in these kinds of matters, one would refer them on to Austel. That is probably what I will do, although, as I said, I still have not received a formal notification or explanation from AOTC. So once that has been received by me I shall ensure that I promptly inform the Senate as to what I will do with those recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. When will the first sod be turned and construction actually begin on the third runway in Sydney? When will it be completed?

—We had to turn quite a few sods to get the decision made to go ahead and construct the runway. But I am pleased to advise the honourable senator that I had my latest briefing from the FAC in Sydney only last week on the progress that is being made. The Federal Airports Corporation is flat out on the preliminary planning work for the third runway. The current situation is that Minister Kelly said, as honourable senators will recall when she approved the environmental proposals—which both the Commonwealth and the New South Wales governments consider equally important in the construction of this major project—that the FAC has indicated it can comply with those conditions that she applied to the project. The Federal Airports Corporation is currently flat out putting together the environmental planning management required for the construction of the runway. The physical work on the runway is expected to commence on schedule halfway through this year—around June or July. The runway planning is currently on schedule and it is expected that the runway will be operational by 1995.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the solemn assurance that the Senate was given on 17 October 1991 that the Minister would personally turn the first sod before the end of 1991, how much credence can we place on this answer?

—As I said in my previous answer, when one considers the very significant issues that are available to be debated in this chamber, it is extraordinary to note the preoccupation the Opposition has with absolute trivia. Last year I said that the first sod would be turned.

PARA.TAB: Work commenced on the runway last year and, I might add, against some significant opposition from a number of parties. Last year I personally approved the Federal Airports Corporation spending in excess of $1m on forward planning for the third runway, even prior to the Cabinet decision being taken, to ensure that after that Cabinet decision the FAC would not delay any further.

The fact is that the work did commence last year, as I said it would. I have just described the nature of that work and the necessary preliminary planning that was required for it to commence. The physical work on the runway will commence on schedule in June this year and the runway will be completed on schedule in 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of recent press comments suggesting that women age pensioners whose partners are non-pensioners will be significantly disadvantaged by changes in the method of calculating their pensions? What are the facts of this change?

—There have been quite a number of articles on this issue in recent times. Some of them have not been as truthful as I would like to have seen. From 26 March, where only one partner of a married couple is eligible for a pension and claims it for the first time, the maximum rate payable will be half the combined married rate of pension rather than the higher single rate.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Giles would be aware, currently only where one partner of a married couple is of pension age, entitlement is the lesser of the single rate of pension adjusted for half the income received by the couple or the combined married pension rate adjusted for all the income received by the couple. The decision to change this was taken on equity grounds. It means that all married pensioners will now be treated the same irrespective of whether their spouses are also pensioners. All married pensioners will receive half the combined married rate of pension, subject of course to the usual income and assets tests.

The pension rate structure is based on the view that couples can achieve economies by sharing their living costs. That is pretty well generally accepted. For that reason, the pension paid to a single person is higher than that received by each of a married couple. It is therefore illogical to continue to pay the single rate of pension to a married person simply because the spouse is not also a pensioner. Consequently, the maximum rate of pension, including the pharmaceutical allowance payable to that pensioner from 26 March, will be $257.90—that is, half the combined married rate per fortnight—rather than $311.30, which is the single rate per fortnight. That is a reduction of $53.40 per fortnight.

While that is obviously a very significant reduction, a couple of things should be borne in mind. Firstly, very few of this group of pensioners are receiving the full rate of pension. Most of them have spouses who are working or in receipt of some other income such as superannuation. Therefore, the dollar drop will be nowhere near that $53.40 a fortnight in most cases. It should also be remembered that no pensioner currently being paid at the single rate will have his or her pension reduced. However, it will be frozen until it is equal to half the combined normal married rate, after which it will be indexed normally.

There has been some misleading press comment as to when women in particular might apply for the pension. The new rules start on 26 March, not the end of February. It needs to be pointed out that, even if a woman can claim before then, she cannot be paid until the first pension payday after she turns 60. So a claim before 26 March may not necessarily result in the current rules being applied. For example, if a woman claims on 19 March but does not turn 60 until 2 April, the new rules will be applicable. However, if she turns 60 on 5 March and claims before 12 March, the old rules will apply. The change is obviously not targeted specifically at women; it applies to all married pensioners alike.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Cooney in his capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I refer Senator Cooney to his Committee's findings on mergers, takeovers and acquisitions and the recommendation that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act be amended to prohibit mergers or acquisitions which would have the effect of substantially lessening competition. It is a recommendation welcomed by big business, small business and farmers and most, except a few, mega-corporations. Has Senator Cooney seen today's Australian which suggests that his Committee's findings will be scrapped and replaced by another government inquiry? Is that true? Is he prepared to go to the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister and demand that the rights of 98 per cent of Australian businesses and 100 per cent of Australian farmers that are delighted with his Committee's report be represented in this Parliament; or will his Government roll over and get its riding instructions from Mr McComas and other spokespeople for mega-corporations?
—Order! Senator Cooney, I assume that you were given notice of this question. I take the last part of the question as not to be really within your role as Chairman of the Committee.

—This is a very eminent report which, perhaps I should say straight away, comes from this chamber. It is a report made to this chamber, not to government. Hence I answer on behalf of all of us here, and in particular on behalf of members of the Committee, which, may I say, is a very good Committee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell says that the report has been welcomed by smaller businesses but not by the mega-businesses, and I think that is true. It is very much a subject for debate in society. There already has been a debate. Senator Boswell referred to a Mr McComas, although perhaps not in as generous terms as he might otherwise have done. Mr McComas arranged a meeting last Friday, I think it was, in Sydney, where this subject was debated. He had nothing but the right intentions in doing that. Perhaps the part that was printed in the press was rather selective. That is probably unique, but on this occasion it was the situation.

Senator Boswell asks me whether I saw the article in the newspaper and whether it is true. I take it from that that he is asking me whether it is true that the article was in the newspaper. That is certainly true. If what he is asking me is whether it is true that the Government is going to do what he suggests it is going to do, of course I do not know and I am sure that the newspaper does not know. I am sure because the only way it could find out would be if Cabinet leaked, and I have great faith in my Cabinet. I am not a person who would at any stage suggest that my Ministers, especially those who are in Cabinet, would leak to any newspaper.

Senator Boswell raises a serious and proper point, that is, the question of how trade practices in this country are to be regulated. What Senator Boswell suggests in his question—it is something in which I know he has taken a lot of personal interest—is that people should be protected, people who are not as big as those he calls mega-businesses at the top. There is a real problem that must be faced by us as a parliament: to protect the people who have to deal with those mega-companies and who find it very difficult. Mega-companies, of course, tend to dictate the terms that the smaller businesses must adhere to.

If the Government is going to go ahead with an inquiry in this area—as I say, I do not know—it could do no better than to start with this report because, although there may have been reports as good as this, there has never been one better. I see Senator Vanstone, my Deputy Chairman, nodding her head in agreement over there.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is becoming a very long answer, Senator Cooney.
—Yes. Mr President. As soon as you call me to order, I obey.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How many more times is Senator Cooney prepared to perform before these directors of mega-corporations so that they can belt him over the head in the press?

—As long as the belting goes on in the press and they do not belt me over the head with the press, I think I can tolerate it. In all seriousness, this is a big issue. The media have taken it up. There is much to be debated. Before my report, a report by Mr Griffiths, as he then was, into this area was a great step forward. I think this report is a great step forward. If the Government proposes another inquiry, no doubt that would be a great step forward. If I do get belted around the head, I am absolutely sure that Senator Boswell and the rest of this chamber, to whom this report was made, will come to my rescue.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the widely reported expectation that tonight's economic statement will encourage the entry of new foreign banks into Australia. For seven years the Minister, the Government and the Opposition have been telling us that foreign banks bring indisputable benefit to the Australian community, but the evidence is to the contrary. So I ask the Minister: what is different this time? How will ordinary Australians—particularly the 960,000 unemployed—benefit from further deregulation and an increase in the number of foreign banks in this country?

—I am totally unable to comment on anything which might be in the statement tonight. Senator Kernot, being a patient person, will undoubtedly wait to read the contents of the statement. But let me make some observations which I think have been contained in documents such as the Martin report and other reports. I think it would be generally agreed that there is a desirability for further competition in the banking sector in Australia. I do not think many people retreat from that view. I do not think the idea of further competition from foreign banks really involves further deregulation, to use a word which is pejorative in Senator Kernot's terms, as I understand it.

PARA.TAB: When foreign banks were first admitted to this country by this Government there were a number of restrictions imposed on them in terms of the sorts of business they were able or required to do. One of the restrictions was that they should provide retail banking facilities, which was probably a very difficult thing for them to do in the Australian market, where we had four major banks already in position operating networks of retail facilities throughout the country. That requirement was probably a bit onerous. I cannot prejudge what will be in the statement. Perhaps after the statement is made, this question may or may not be relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister will not comment on the statement, I will ask him to comment on the theory. What is different about conditions now that would make the theory of pure competition work with respect to the entry of more foreign banks?

—The position is that, in spite of the problems associated with the robust lending habits of the 1980s, the four major Australian banks are in a much better position in the Australian market than they were a few years ago, and their position is even more entrenched. In those circumstances competition would probably be helpful to them.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the much reported promise from the Prime Minister during the recent Tasmanian election of $500,000 to assist in a feasibility study for a steel mill at Bell Bay. I ask the Minister whether the Prime Minister's promise was ever ratified by the Cabinet and, further, whether he, as the Minister responsible for such a proposal, was consulted by the Prime Minister before the promise was made? Can the Minister also advise as to the source of funding for the $500,000 promise from the Prime Minister and give the Senate an indication as to his personal support or otherwise for the Prime Minister's promise? If the Minister did support the Prime Minister's original promise, and indeed the steel mill proposal, does he consider it appropriate that the promise of Federal funds should now be broken by the Prime Minister because of a change in government?

—As I understand the situation, the new Premier of Tasmania, throughout the election campaign, was almost vitriolic in his opposition to the proposal to have a steel mill in Tasmania and to have a feasibility study done.
—Where did you get that from?
—I said, `As I understand the situation'.
—Did you discuss this with the Prime Minister?
—As far as any discussions between the Prime Minister and me and other Ministers are concerned, they remain matters that I will not comment on in Question Time.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer, but I ask him what his source of information was as to the position of Mr Groom, our Premier?

—I said, `As I understand the situation'. I saw an article in the Launceston Examiner which I thought suggested that. Maybe I am incorrect. As I said when I answered the question, that is as I understand it. That was the impression I got from an article in the Launceston newspaper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Loss at Sea of Bulk Carriers

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. The Minister will be aware of enormous community concern in my home State of Western Australia at the loss at sea over the past year of a number of overseas bulk vessels which had loaded or completed their loading at Western Australian ports. I ask the Minister: what action has been taken to further investigate these incidents?

—Last year 40 bulk carriers were either lost at sea or suffered serious structural failure, with very great loss of human life as well as cargoes. This was a matter which I think could be fairly described as one of the major agenda items at the recent International Maritime Organisation conference in London. It has now become a matter of great international concern. Six of those vessels were loaded at Western Australian ports; two of the vessels loaded from Western Australian ports in fact foundered with very great loss of human life.

PARA.TAB: Late last year, I authorised the release of reports by the marine incident investigation unit of the Department of Transport on the loss of two bulk carriers after loading in Australia. The first, Mineral Diamond, foundered with the loss of all 26 crew in the south Indian Ocean on a voyage from Dampier to the Netherlands on 17 April last year. The investigation concluded that, while the cargo was presented and loaded correctly in Australia, it resulted in a high shear stress force applied at the engine room forward bulkhead. At sea, the ship is likely to have very rapidly foundered and broken up after a sudden catastrophic structural failure of the vessel.

The second vessel, Starfish, sailed from Port Walcott on 22 March last year for Poland. In the south Indian Ocean it diverted to Mauritius after water was being taken into the after cargo holds of the ship. The ship sank on 8 April after the successful evacuation, I am pleased to say, of the crew. The investigation into this incident found that the Australian cargo had been presented and loaded properly. There was insufficient evidence in Australia to determine the cause of the ship taking in water. While rough weather was encountered on the voyage from Australia, this should not have caused any problems for a well-found ship.

My concern with these ship losses is particularly shared by the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, Mr Peter Morris. Late last year I was pleased to take up his proposal for the Standing Committee to investigate issues in relation to ship safety and standards for vessels trading to Australia, particularly bulk carriers and tankers. The Committee has called for submissions by Friday, 13 March, and I urge all interested parties to participate actively in this important inquiry.

I conclude by advising the Senate that the investigation into the loss of the bow section of the Kirki has been completed, and I should be in a position to present the results of that investigation to the Senate next month.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Government entered into an arrangement with Russian interests which involves the taking of fish from the southern and south-eastern areas of the Australian fishing zone by Russian boats?

—I did not respond immediately following the asking of that question because I was checking to see whether I have a brief on that subject. I do not have a brief before me. I will take the honourable senator's question on notice, if I may, and reply in due course.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer the Minister to reports in today's Sydney Morning Herald that the New South Wales Government has decided to open the conveyancing industry in that State to competitive forces from outside the legal profession. I ask: does the Minister conclude from this that the decision is likely to result in a long term reduction in housing transaction costs to New South Wales consumers? Are there other factors that also ought to be considered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was delighted to see reports in today's Sydney Morning Herald that in New South Wales the Premier and the Attorney-General, Mr Peter Collins, have succeeded in browbeating the solicitors of the Law Society in that State into accepting a scheme and a plan to allow for competition so far as conveyancing is concerned. So long as there are very stringent safeguards to ensure the propriety and fidelity of what these conveyancing firms do by way of assisting home buyers and sellers in New South Wales to carry out that transaction, the move is certainly to be commended. The taking away of that shield of anti-competition that had been put up by the Law Society will, I am sure, bring down the costs to consumers of conveyancing in that State.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, I cannot give an assurance that there will be a long term beneficial impact for home sellers and buyers in New South Wales. For example, were the Federal Opposition, if it were elected to government, to impose its GST on those conveyancing fees, then the hundreds of dollars that would be saved through competitive forces being introduced into New South Wales conveyancing would be discounted—put to nought, I believe—by the 15 per cent GST on conveyancing fees.

According to the Real Estate Institute of Australia, in the December quarter last year the average house price in Sydney was some $180,000. A conveyancing fee charged by a solicitor to a purchaser in that State would be approximately $1,200 on the transaction. The GST would add $180 to the cost of the conveyancing fee in New South Wales. That is a very substantial impost which would go directly to Dr Hewson's Treasury. It would mean that hundreds of dollars on every

ANSWER.PARA: conveyance in New South Wales, certainly in that price bracket in Sydney, would go to Dr Hewson's Federal Treasury for the privilege of consulting a lawyer or to get a conveyance undertaken in New South Wales. There would be an Australia-wide impact.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about family law costs?

—Senator Newman is interjecting. In Tasmania, the average cost of a home in Hobart is $89,600. The approximate conveyancing fee is $762. GST would add $114 to the transaction costs for the home purchaser in Hobart. For the benefit of Senator Newman, I would like to have incorporated in Hansard a table showing the average house price in the capitals, the approximate conveyancing cost to the purchaser, and the impact of GST in each of those capital cities.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am being diverted. What we are talking about is the higher cost of justice which would come about as a result of the GST being applied to ordinary legal transactions such as the drawing up of wills—for the benefit of Senator Macdonald—or a custody dispute in the Family Court. Hundreds of dollars will be added to the cost of that sort of dispute in the Family Court. There would be an Australia-wide impact. We are talking about a $3 billion a year industry, and 15 per cent of $3 billion, or $450m, would be flowing into the Federal Treasury by way of the GST impact on those Australians seeking the advice of lawyers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer Senator Button to his answer yesterday regarding an assurance that the Government will not use the National Measurements (Standard Time) Amendment Bill to impose daylight saving on Queensland. The Minister said that he understood that Senator McMullan, on behalf of the Government, had `already given a public assurance to that effect'.
—That is right.

—I ask the Minister whether he would explain to me why, after Question Time, both his office and that of Senator McMullan were unable or unwilling to explain where this assurance was publicly given, when it was given or what the precise wording of that assurance was. Will the Minister now tell the Senate when and where the assurance was given, to whom it was given, and what the precise wording of that assurance was? If the Minister is unable to do so, will he concede that he has misled the Senate by suggesting that Senator McMullan gave an assurance publicly about daylight saving when he had in fact not done so?

—It is always important to whom one directs a question in this place. I suppose that in seeking a whole explanation from Senator McMullan it might have been useful to direct the question to him. I have been told by Senator McMullan that on three occasions on radio programs in Queensland he gave that assurance. That to me is a public undertaking, and I have nothing further to add.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I preface the question by saying that I asked both Senator McMullan's office and Senator Button's office for details of this. Neither was able to supply the information. I ask the Minister now to give me the details of that. I also ask Senator Button to now give an assurance to the Senate, on behalf of this Government, that his Government, for as long as it remains in office, will not introduce daylight saving in Queensland.

—What I said yesterday was that I understood that Senator McMullan had given that assurance. What inquiries are made at my office or elsewhere really have nothing to do with it. This is one of Senator Macdonald's stunt questions. As I have indicated, a public undertaking has been given on three radio stations in Queensland. That is a public undertaking. I cannot answer for Senator McMullan's office beyond that. I repeat the undertaking.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Teague asked me some questions about illegal immigrants. I have some further information for him and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
On Tuesday, 25 February 1992 Senator Teague asked the following question:

". . . . Is it true that since November 1989, a little over two years ago, eight boats landed on Australia's northern coasts carrying 382 illegal immigrants and, of these, only 19 have since left Australia? Why has the Government in this whole matter been so indecisive and with so much delay?
The answer to Senator Teague's question is as follows:
Since November 1989 a total of 9 boats carrying a total of 438 unauthorised arrivals have reached Australia.
A total of 22 people have so far left Australia.
55 people of the 56 on the most recent boat to arrive in Australia are presently in Port Hedland and the one who stayed back in Darwin for medical treatment is due to join them shortly.
The remaining 360 people are being considered for refugee status and are at various stages of processing. All applications have been given priority in the Department's DORs area.

The delays in finalising many of these applications have not been of the Government's making. The DORs process itself is necessarily a lengthy and meticulous procedure because of the need to ensure that applicants are given adequate opportunity to present their case in accordance with Australia's international obligations and domestic law.

In many cases, the start of the refugee determination process was seriously delayed because the applicants' solicitors were very slow in lodging applications—up to 17 months in some cases. The Government has since taken action to prevent a repetition of this kind of thing.

In other cases, the delays were caused by community and other organisations requesting that processing of the applications not proceed until additional detailed submissions had been made on behalf of the applicants."

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Government's disastrous failure to resolve Australia's record youth unemployment crisis and its dishonest attempts to pretend that the `real' youth unemployment rate is less than the adult rate.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite what the Government says, there is a crisis. That is why I am drawing to the attention of the Senate, in this matter of public importance, the Government's disastrous failure to resolve Australia's record youth unemployment crisis and its dishonest attempts to pretend that the real youth unemployment rate is less than the adult rate.

PARA.TAB: The facts of the existence of the crisis are self-evident, but let me quickly state them. There are no jobs available in Australia for one in every three full time job seekers. In some areas, it is closer to one in two young job seekers. One in two young Australians cannot find a full time job because there are no full time jobs available. The regions that are near or over the half way level—more than one in two—are north-west and outer western Melbourne; Wollongong; north and south-western Victoria, and we notice how Victoria dominates, having a Labor Government; northern Adelaide; Hobart; and Mackay in Queensland.

These figures massively understate the real crisis at a time when this Government is pretending that the real crisis does not exist. I will deal with those Government claims in a minute. The reality of how these latest figures understate the real crisis is self-evident when one looks at the Australian Bureau of Statistics' figures. In the first place, the actual figures—not the seasonally adjusted ones which are referred to by the Government and by newspapers—far exceed the seasonally adjusted figures. In other words, the present situation is far worse and, of course, will continue to be far worse than the seasonally adjusted figures indicate at the moment.

In the second place, the Australian Bureau of Statistics itself has produced a series of figures showing that there are 130,000 discouraged job seekers. These are people who have lost their jobs and who are not even looking for jobs because they have been so discouraged. The ABS has demonstrated in a survey that the current unemployment figures understate by over 130,000 the number of Australians really wanting to have jobs. If we apply that figure to the 15- to 19-year-olds, we see that about 15,000 discouraged teenagers have given up putting their names down as unemployed.

On top of that, the ABS has done a survey of those people who are underemployed. I will deal with that at some length because that survey shows—and I will be revealing these figures for the first time later in this debate—that the real level of unemployment is over 40 per cent for young Australians between 15 and 19 years of age. They are official figures. They are not Baldwin inventions. They are not phoney Government figures. They are the official Australian Bureau of Statistics' figures for underemployment.

I only took a section of the survey figures—a section that covers those people who were in part time work but who really wanted to have full time work and who would take a full time job if there were one available. On top of that we can see from the Australian Bureau of Statistics' figures the number of jobs lost over the last 12 months. We can see that the number of teenage jobs wiped out is about five times as high as the number of teenagers added to the unemployment list; the rest just disappear. I will explain why in a minute.

With the real unemployment rate at over 40 per cent, or two in five young people, we then see the way in which this Government has used Austudy to hide the real level of unemployment. The Government has been paying young people to go back to school to get them off the unemployment lists, but is not providing jobs for them when eventually those young people spill over the dam wall into the labour market. That does not matter, does it, to the Labor Government! As long as these people are out of the way for a while, the Government can doctor the unemployment figures. If the Government cannot doctor those figures well enough then it will invent them. The Government will then have Mr Baldwin inventing nonsense figures which are so nonsensical that not one developed country in the world uses the invented measure of unemployment that Mr Baldwin has magically discovered.

We can see how the Keating Government is fixing this crisis—this crisis that really exists. Just ask any of the social workers in western Melbourne who I have spoken to with Senator Kemp. Just ask any of the young people themselves as they crowd around the CES offices. Just ask them what the real level of unemployment is. They certainly do not agree with Mr Baldwin.

How is the Keating Government fixing this crisis? Firstly, it is fixing it by pretending that it does not exist. The Baldwin solution is to pretend that it does not exist. Mr Baldwin is the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. He, if anyone does, should have a responsible approach and know what on earth he is doing. What does he do? He pretends that the real unemployment level in Australia is 8.8 per cent, which is lower than the adult unemployment rate.

No-one in Australia apart from Mr Baldwin, and aNiMaLS—who go around lying to the Press Gallery on the instructions of this Government, saying that the ABS figures are wrong and that when I cite ABS figures I am somehow misleading people—believes that that is the way to solve the problem. Apart from the aNiMaLS lying on the instructions of this Government, and apart from the Minister dishonestly and disgracefully seeking to mislead the Australian people by saying that the real unemployment rate for young people is 8.8 per cent, no-one believes that pretending that it does not exist is the way to solve the problem.

If the big lie is repeated over and over again, it makes it sound right. It may be that the Minister really does think that the unemployment rate is only 8.8 per cent for young people. Maybe the Government overwhelmingly believes that it is telling the truth. In that case the Keating Government's disastrous failure to resolve the record youth unemployment crisis is at last explained. It does not know it is there—that is why it has not fixed it. This lack of effective action on youth jobs would then be explained clearly by this incredible statement. I want to repeat this incredible statement as to this invented rate of 8.8 per cent. Mr Baldwin said that the full time unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds is really only 8.8 per cent. He said that this was only a quarter of the size of the actual official youth unemployment rate reported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for January of 34.8 per cent, representing no full time jobs available for more than one in every three job seekers or 30 per cent after seasonal adjustments.

Mr Baldwin's pathetic claim that the ABS figures are 75 per cent wrong or have somehow been misrepresented is not backed up by any facts because there are none to back it up. I challenge Mr Baldwin—I challenged him last week and repeat that challenge—to produce the statistics on which his dishonest and disgraceful claim was made. Let me quote what this man said to try to pretend to the Australian people that there was no crisis:

SPEECH.PARA: The real percentage of young people genuinely seeking full time work who are unable to find it is 8.8 per cent.

How did this genius work this out? He took the total population of all young people under 20 between the ages of 15 and 19 and divided that into the seasonally adjusted unemployment figure. In other words, he included in his magic sums all those young people who are engaged full time in going to school or to tertiary institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the ones he has on Austudy.

—Including those on Austudy whom he has to get out of the dole queues. He has in the most phoney and dishonourable way used a device to try to pretend that the real unemployment figure is 8.8 per cent—a measure not used by any civilised country. But I suppose that when one looks at those opposite one understands why such an uncivilised system would be employed, and why such a phoney set of guides would be used. The clear fact is that there is no figure that substantiates this lie.

PARA.TAB: This is the big lie, and indeed this is the era of the big lie from this Government. It is following exactly the techniques that were used by the Wran Government in New South Wales. I suppose that is natural because our present Prime Minister comes from the same school. He was taught in that same hothouse atmosphere of the right wing of New South Wales, some of whose former standover men are in gaol. We would expect more and more of that kind of political thuggery to come now that this Government is in the hands of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales.
The reality is contained in a series of figures showing exactly what the unemployment rate is in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a number of tables.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: [THE TABLES ARE OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGES 232-233]

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The reason that these figures are important is that they destroy the basis on which this Government is pretending that the unemployment rate is 8.8 per cent. It is not. It is the great lie.

PARA.TAB: One of the key things about these figures, which I will briefly outline, is that about 154,800 unemployed 15-19 year olds are looking for full time work; about 290,400 are employed full time, and so there is a full time unemployment rate of 34.8 per cent. If Mr Baldwin can do so, will he please tell us which of these official figures are wrong, which of them is misleading? If he cannot do that, will he please tell aNiMaLS to stop lying to the Press Gallery?

These figures specifically and clearly exclude those young people at school or in tertiary training who are not available for work. There is no doubt about that. Yet Mr Baldwin in his press release pretended that somehow these figures were unacceptable because they included them. I repeat that these figures specifically and clearly exclude those young people at school or in tertiary training who are not available for work.

If Mr Baldwin wants to omit from his figures all those in such institutions, the total of full time youth unemployed is still 134,700 out of a work force of 394,200, giving a full time unemployment rate of 34 per cent. Goodness me, what an incredible difference—34.8 per cent in the original figures, 34 per cent if one adjusts them in the way Mr Baldwin says he wants them adjusted.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he won't break them up regionally.
—Yes, and there is no breakdown regionally. He cannot

SPEECH.PARA: invent enough figures regionally to come out with that sort of nonsense. There is no honest way that Mr Baldwin can get a real—and I stress this—full time 15-19 year old unemployment rate of 8.8 per cent. He can get a phoney figure, which is the proportion of the total population. It will be interesting to see Senator Cook cooking those books when it is his turn to respond.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, having given Mr Baldwin five days to reply, I asked a question in this chamber as to how he justified those figures. We got no justification. Senator Cook did not know; he just felt confident that the figure was right. In fact, the figure is phoney. The figure has been subject to attack by newspaper editorials, attacked by welfare workers and attacked by anyone who knows anything about the subject. Yet we could not get a coherent response from Senator Cook yesterday, and we got no further response today after Question Time, although he said he would try to find out. Maybe he will tell us today. Mr Baldwin's contemptuous dismissal of the youth unemployment crisis inherent in his dishonest 8.8 per cent jobless figure is compounded by his arrogant refusal to come clean on the real size of this national disaster that his Government engineered in the recession that we had to have.

How do we know that Mr Baldwin is phoney and behaving in a phoney way? We know because I have here an internal memorandum from the Department of Employment, Education and Training in which the Department of Mr Baldwin, who has invented a new system of measuring unemployment, uses the system that Mr Baldwin finds unattractive. I quote from the memorandum to the Minister's office from the South Australian end of his Department about two projects:

SPEECH.PARA: The projects are located in the Adelaide West Region (SA) and in the Illawarra Tablelands area (NSW). These locations have high youth unemployment and limited labour market opportunities for untrained workers.
There is a concession that there is a high level of unemployment. It says that in the western suburbs of Adelaide young people:

. . . are particularly disadvantaged in the education sector and in the labour market. Comparison of the May to July labour market statistics for 1990 and 1991 shows a 12.6 per cent decline in the 15-19 year old labour market participation rate.
Here we come to the guts of it. The memo says:
It is also apparent that the current trends in unemployment, and in youth unemployment in particular, call for effective action. . .

Maybe effective action means telling fibs about the level of unemployment. We have seen nothing more, except hiding these people in schools under Austudy to get them out of the dole queues in order to create better educated dole queues. It went on:
The teenage full-time unemployment rate—
this is Mr Baldwin's own Department—
has increased to 28.1% in June 1991—
it is a little behind the times; it is now 34.8 per cent—
higher than the July 1983 peak—
higher than the last recession—

of 27.6%. Increased educational participation explains the fact that as a percentage of the total teenage population, the teenage full-time unemployment was 8.4% in June 1991 compared to 12.5% in July 1983.

His Department says that it is because the Government has paid so many young people to get them out of the unemployment queues and send them back to school that, even as a percentage of the total population, the figure is slightly lower now than it was back in 1983. His Department uses the very measure that I use, the measure that this Government tells aNiMaLS to go around the gallery saying is a lie and which Mr Baldwin says is being misleading.

PARA.TAB: Maybe because Mr Baldwin thinks the advice from his Department is misleading is one reason why it has done nothing about it because all it has done is come up with phoney solutions with non-existent jobs. To accuse the coalition of creative accounting by daring to reveal the official ABS surveys is the last card in the pack. We never use anything other than official Bureau of Statistics figures. I get them—if the Minister wants to know—from the statistics section of the Department of the Parliamentary Library. Is he accusing them of being liars too?

This Government is ignoring all the evidence that the official ABS figures largely understate the disasters. There is huge underemployment as evidenced by an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey. When one adds the underemployed looking for full time work, who have part-time jobs, to the unemployed, one gets a total, basic unemployment figure of over 40 per cent. It is between 40.1 per cent and 40.5 per cent, depending on which figure one wants to use.

The reality is—and this Government is not prepared to face up to it—that it has no answers. At least we have: the Fightback package, which will create 2 million real jobs, not phoney jobs, to meet this real disaster. It is not a phoney disaster. We will create jobs for these people that the Government pretends do not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has never hidden from the fact that the high level of unemployment in this country is of major concern to it. Indeed, the reason why in a few hours time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country will make a major economic statement is to address that very dilemma.

PARA.TAB: Our concern about unemployment goes to all of the unemployed and the situation in which they find themselves. We are concerned about the longer term unemployed. We are concerned about those in middle age and without the new skills that may be required in the labour market who face bleak opportunities. We are concerned particularly, of course, about unemployed young people who in many respects are to be regarded as the engines of the labour market in the future. Our concern is for all of the unemployed. Our economic statement this evening will be aimed, among other things, at generating the growth in this economy that will lead to a change in that situation.

This so-called matter of public importance brought on by Senator Michael Baume has been worded in the strongest language. Both in his motion and in his speech he has used such terms as `dishonesty', `lies' and `phoney', and he has addressed this chamber with a great deal of passion. Passion is not, and never has been, any substitute for logic. It may be an indication of commitment, but it does not mean that it is rationally directed. That strong language that has been used at each point in fact can, should and will be turned directly back on Senator Baume for the fraudulent and false thesis that he has presented to this chamber in the arguments that he has made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prove it.

—I am enjoined to prove it; I will shortly do that. There are a couple of threshold points that ought to be made to get the position into focus. In this debate about unemployment in Australia we rarely hear very much said about the participation rate. When we came to power in 1983 the participation rate in Australia was 60.3 per cent; that is to say, of all those people between the ages of 18 and 65 eligible to work in this country, 60.3 per cent of them were in the labour market and the rest were not.

PARA.TAB: One of the big changes that has occurred over the life of this Government is that the size of the labour market has increased. The participation rate—all of the people seeking work—is now 63.4 per cent. They are significant factors because over the period of the Labor Government the size of the labour market has grown, and grown significantly.

If we were to apply to the present level of unemployment the same size of the labour market that applied in the last years of the Fraser Government, the level of unemployment in this country would be 5.8 per cent, not the levels that we are now looking at. That figure ought to be kept fair and square in the middle of the mind when this matter is being debated because our success in the total size of the Australian labour market being grown is one of the matters that is now being statistically used against us.

Before he concluded his address, Senator Baume said that the so-called Fightback package—the Hewson consumption tax package—offers a resolution to this problem. It does not. There is no part of it that does. In that package we see a watering down of sensible and reasonable labour market support programs so that once again—typical of the Opposition—the blame is put on the shoulders of those who are the victims and the burden of that cost of dealing with unemployment is carried by the poor in this community.

Those matters should be kept up-front because they inform the wider issues in this debate as I now turn to the basic question. The Government is not disputing the fact that the youth unemployment rate, in the size of the youth labour market presenting for employment, is 30 per cent. But we are explaining that this does not mean, as Senator Baume said in his press release dated 16 February—and it is a fraudulent statement—`No jobs for more than one in three young Australians'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the text.

—That is Senator Baume's headline. That is the most glaring comment he makes in his entire press release and it is simply not true. The truth is that not one in three young Australians are out of work. The fact is that one in 10 are and the real figure is 8.8 per cent, as my ministerial colleague Peter Baldwin said.
—Rubbish! A deliberate lie!
—It is not a deliberate lie and I ask that that comment be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Baume, it is unparliamentary to suggest that another member is telling a deliberate lie and I ask you to withdraw unconditionally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now!
—Madam Acting Deputy President, it is either a deliberate or a non-deliberate lie.
—Order! Senator Baume! Senator Faulkner, I am quite capable of handling this, if you would not mind, if you would just give it a go. Senator Baume, I ask that you withdraw.
—I withdraw that it is a deliberate lie; it must be an unintentional lie.
—That is still not acceptable.
—The honourable senator has withdrawn the relevant remark, Minister.
—Do I understand, Madam Acting Deputy President, that there is no reference to lie then on the record of this debate?
—There will be a reference in the sense that it will not be wiped out of Hansard. No retraction from the honourable senator can do that.
—I withdraw in whatever way he wants. Let him get on with telling the fibs that he is telling.
—Thank you, Senator Baume.

—We are having a game of cutie pie here. Senator Baume is making a goose of himself because he is committed to sustaining the argument that he has put. I will ignore the unparliamentary reflection and go to the argument because the fraudulent nature of what he said needs to be explained.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I should say—this is a key and fundamentally relevant point in analysing this issue—is that the nature of the youth labour market is very different from that of the adult labour market. That point has been made by my ministerial colleague Mr Baldwin many times. In his press release on youth unemployment, issued last week, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The real percentage of young people genuinely seeking full-time work and who are unable to find it is 8.8 per cent.

It is not 30 per cent, the figure Senator Baume wishes to sustain. Let me explain why the youth labour market is so different from the adult labour market. There are three fundamental aspects that ought to be quoted. Firstly, the difference is due mainly to the large proportion in the 15- to 19-year-old age group who are undertaking some form of education and training. That is not a feature of the adult labour market; it is a feature of the youth labour market, and it is a significant reason why the figures that have been presented are wrong. About 66 per cent of the 15- to 19-year-old age group are undertaking some form of education and training. With adjustments, that leaves about 28 per cent of this group in the teenage labour force.

PARA.TAB: Approximately 70 per cent in the labour force are employed and 30 per cent unemployed. Or we can put it this way, which is the more accurate and honest way of putting it: if we have 10 young people, around seven of them will be in education or training, two of them will be employed, and one of them will be out of a job. Let us get our statistical basis right. That is why the youth labour market is a different labour market from the adult labour market. We cannot apply the measures that Senator Baume has applied. It would be absolutely false and misleading to characterise the unemployment rate for youth at around 30 per cent and one in three. Yet Senator Baume says in his press release that there are no jobs for one in three Australians. As I have demonstrated, the true figure is one in 10 young Australians who are unemployed.

Let me make myself even more clear. No-one on this side of the Parliament, least of all me or the Minister, Mr Baldwin, is saying that the current level of youth unemployment is acceptable. Of course it is not acceptable. Indeed, the human face of this problem needs to be constantly kept in view, and we do that.

Let me look at some more facts that will not give the Opposition any joy. Under this Government, teenage full time unemployment has fallen by 40,600, or 25 per cent. Even so, taking into account the effects of the current recession, the number of young people unemployed now compared to April 1983 has fallen by 25.8 per cent. This fall in the number of young unemployed youth reflects a number of factors. They include higher rates of education retention—more kids have stayed at school longer in our period of government; enhanced labour market programs that provide training as an alternative; and the strong employment growth that has occurred in the economy between 1983 and 1989.

It has been a deliberate and considered policy of this Government to encourage young people to stay and finish high school and to undertake further post-secondary education. One of the important reasons why the Government has undertaken this policy is that the youth labour market is going through enormous structural change. Jobs that used to be there at entry level positions now do not exist. These jobs have traditionally required few skills—jobs such as couriers or telephonists. Due to organisational changes and the introduction of new technology, these sorts of jobs—the cheap jobs for young workers—are diminishing. That is why young people are responding to this Government's encouragement to go on to further education so that they will have the skills to contribute in a restructured work force, better levels of education, and be eligible for better classes and better quality of jobs later on.

In the meantime, what is the Government doing to assist the proportion of young people who are unemployed and about whom we are genuinely concerned? Quite a lot. The Government has demonstrated its commitment to assisting young people during an obviously difficult period. We have done this by historically high spending in the higher education sector. In real terms, we have increased spending in the higher education sector by 41 per cent since we came to power. That is not 41 per cent in dollar terms; that is a 41 per cent increase in real terms.

The adoption of the Finn agenda, which is a substantial report before us for young people's participation in post-compulsory education, is also one of the important considerations. Substantially, we have increased subsidies for the uptake of apprenticeships by employers, which is an area of general concern. We have been offering a range of labour market programs that have proven time and time again to be effective in retraining people and enhancing their prospects of finding a job. The training element in these programs is clearly the key element to their success, particularly for young people.

I can now ask: what is the Opposition offering young unemployed people and the unemployed more generally? First, as I have said before, there is nothing at all in the consumption tax package for young unemployed. In fact, labour market programs, because of the consumption tax package, will be cut by an amount of $140m. The words `crocodile tears' were flung across this chamber a moment ago. How can an Opposition sustain an argument that it is concerned about youth unemployment and cut by $140m labour support programs aimed at doing something to improve the prospects of young unemployed?

In addition, the Opposition will replace Jobstart, one of our most successful programs, with a new program with the smart name `Austrain'—a fraudulent name, I submit. This scheme will mean that young people who have been unemployed for 12 months will be made to work at 80 per cent of the award wage. The title `Austrain' suggests that this is an on the job training program for young unemployed. We are invited by the title to take that implication. But there is no clear commitment for any training to occur during the life of this program at all—none whatsoever. That is why it is fraudulently named. It is nothing more than a cheap labour scheme.

Not content with exploiting the long term unemployed, the Opposition's consumption tax package will actually worsen the employment prospects not only for youth but for all age groups. Let me demonstrate why the consumption tax package will lead to higher unemployment. The Opposition claims that with its consumption tax package it will create two million jobs—that figure was flung across the chamber by Senator Baume a moment ago. That is two million jobs by the year 2000, according to their prognostication. This claim is based on the so-called high road scenario in the Access Economics Murphy econometric model of the Australian economy, where the projections are based on the implementation of all of the recommendations of the Industry Commission reforms. This same high road scenario—these are the words we never hear from the Opposition when it is promoting its consumption tax package—requires an inflation rate of 12.4 per cent in 1994-95. Let me comment on that for a minute.

Gerard Henderson, who formerly was John Howard's chief of staff and a senior adviser to Malcolm Fraser when he was Prime Minister and who is now a newspaper columnist, wrote in his column in the Sydney Morning Herald on 10 December—we are hearing this from a blue chip Liberal source—referring to the employment prospects:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, the firm warranty that some 2 million jobs "will" be created and unemployment halved by the end of the century is—
these are his blue chip Liberal words—

just a guess. Well meaning, no doubt. Yet a hypothesis just the same. What is more, the AEM model on which this overtly optimistic promise is based does not take into account the inflationary impact of the Coalition's across-the-board goods and services tax. It is—
this is again from the same source—
all pie in the sky.

These are the words of the former chief of staff to John Howard, senior adviser to Malcolm Fraser, and continuing big `L' Liberal, now newspaper columnist. From within the Liberal camp comes this condemnation. How we can take it that superficial assertions flung across this chamber can be accepted? Henderson continues:
. . . it is a matter of record that the evidence that this expression of faith (ie two million jobs) is not to be found in almost six hundred pages of "Fightback" documentation.

He is saying that there is no evidence in the 600 pages of the Hewson consumption tax package which supports the contention that these jobs will be created. Even John Hewson—or Professor Hewson—does not believe his own consumption tax package will assist the unemployed. On 22 November, when referring to the so-called transition costs of his consumption tax, he said:
. . . transition can involve some increases in unemployment or at least dislocation as people move from one job to another.
On 23 November, he said:
I'm not making any promises about unemployment. There will be transition effects.

So at least we have an open admission, a passing honest admission, that this so-called elaborate tax will not solve the problem. Yet we have a contention here, flying in the face of what the Leader of the Opposition has said, that it will.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition policies will exacerbate unemployment. What else could be the result of slashing, as it proposes, $10 billion off government expenditure? When government expenditure is being cut to the bone, cutting $10 billion out of outlays now means an attack on welfare, health, housing and education and a cut to programs that mean real things to real people.

How could we get anything other than high unemployment by slashing tariffs at a quicker rate than we are proposing? What else could be the result of a 15 per cent goods and services tax that imposes an extra 15 per cent cost on goods and services? What else could be the result of a tighter monetary policy to achieve the stated target of zero inflation? All of those things, and the Murphy model on page 8 of the Murphy paper that was debated in Question Time today, demonstrate that there will be higher unemployment because of a consumption tax. So that is the promise that the Opposition in its most considered statement on the consumption tax package makes to the Australian community. It makes that promise but comes in here and talks about its concern for the unemployed. I want to contend that that is a concern not based on what the Opposition is proposing as a policy or a platform and, therefore, it must be seen as false concern.

I turn back to the question with which I started. The real figure that we are talking about in this debate is not the outrageously and emotionally presented figure from Senator Baume that is meant to start a few editorial hearts fluttering and a few headline writers grabbing for the quickest and shortest expression. It is not, as he puts in his own press release—falsely, in my contention—that there will be no jobs for more than one in three Australians. That is a false statement because the real figure is one in 10 and it behoves the Opposition not one whit to pretend that the picture is other than what it really is and present a falsity in place of fact.

—I do not intend to table or incorporate it in Hansard. It is a press release which I have labelled as falsely headlined and I have no interest in propagating a falsity. If Senator O'Chee wants it incorporated in Hansard, he should ask the author of it, Senator Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not delay the Senate too much. I simply say that the Minister refuses leave to have it incorporated because the text of that press release clearly says that it relates to full time unemployment rates. The figures are specifically and directly accurate. The Minister's refusal to allow that press release to be incorporated demonstrates the mendacity in his approach by reading selectively a heading without, in fact, reading the press release, the details of which clearly show that everything I said was exactly correct. I ask the Minister to revise his ludicrous position so that I do not have to move this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in opposition to the motion. I note that it is Senator Baume's press release; it is not mine. Therefore, it is not my property to incorporate. I do not intend, in making a speech against the content of this press release, to incorporate the offensive document. I also note that Senator Baume, in making his presentation, did not see it reasonable or fit for him to include his own press release.
—I didn't know I was going to be misrepresented so disgracefully.
—Order! Senator Baume, you should speak from your chair if you wish to make a comment.
—I have no opposition to tabling the document so that it is available to senators in the chamber, and I hereby do so.
—I seek leave to withdraw my motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter of public importance today. I do agree that we have a crisis. The rate of youth unemployment is appalling. To just say that it is high underestimates the problem that we have. However, I must first warn anyone who does happen to be listening to this today that Senator Baume's comments really should be taken with some cynicism, because he and his colleagues have had a very important role to play in making the lives of our unemployed young people even more miserable than they need to be.

PARA.TAB: Listeners should be aware that, despite his protestations of concern about young unemployed people, he voted with the Government to cut their incomes, thereby forcing these young people further and further into poverty, forcing them to live even further below the poverty line. This is not usually something that any of the Liberal senators make a comment on, but I believe that young unemployed people are surely entitled to ask the coalition, `If you are so concerned about our plight, why did you agree to cut our incomes?'.

The Opposition's hypocrisy does not let the Government off the hook. It is, indeed, a damning indictment of this Government that at least one-third of young people who want to work cannot find a job. I stress that that is an average figure. In parts of Adelaide it is double that and in some country towns, such as Whyalla, it is well over that again. What do these figures say to our young people? What sort of message do they send to them about their value to our society? It is obviously not a positive message. The fact that we as a nation are not facing up to the predicament of our young people is reflected in alarming statistics about youth suicide, youth homelessness, juvenile crime and family breakdown.

There is no doubt that young Australians are among the major victims of the recession. As a country we need to recognise that this problem of youth unemployment is not a temporary one.Young people are being squeezed out of paid full time work. There is no sign that either the coalition or the Government have any long term plans that will redress this situation. We have seen two decades of neglect by successive Federal governments and youth unemployment is now very much a long term structural problem.

There has been a massive decline in teenage full time employment since 1966. Over 200,000 full time teenage jobs were lost between 1966 and 1986 and a further 100,000 jobs have been lost during the current recession. This fairly rapid disappearance of full time employment for young people has resulted in a significant increase in the number of teenagers participating in full time education, and my colleague Senator Sowada will elaborate on this in more depth. Because of this trend and a fivefold increase in part time work for young people over the last 25 years, the true level of youth unemployment is somewhat difficult to determine, but it seems reasonable to assert that many more young people than actually appear in official statistics are out there; they want to work full time and are actively trying to find a job. They are being locked out of the labour market.

What Australia has basically witnessed is the elimination of what we might call entry level jobs, those jobs that, in the past, young people have been able to find and have been able to take as the first step up the ladder to entering a particular industry or profession. I refer here to a recent report by the Youth Affairs Council of South Australia entitled Surplus to Requirements, which states:

Youth unemployment is often portrayed as a result of "high wages" and lack of skills. However, a deeper analysis reveals that fundamental structural changes, such as the participation of women in the workforce, technological innovations and changes in the organisation of work, are responsible for the collapse of the youth labour market.
The idea that young wages are too high is one of the most fervently held, frequently expressed and least substantiated beliefs about young people.

SPEECH.PARA: A 1983 study by the Bureau of Labour Market Research, which claimed that an 8 per cent increase in junior award rates compared with adult rates between 1972 and 1974 has decreased youth employment, is the only substantial evidence for this view to date. This research is contradicted by an overwhelming volume of evidence. For example, the reduction in difference between adult and junior wages was greatest in the metal trades industry, yet this area provided the largest number of new teenage jobs between 1971 and 1976.
