PARA.TAB: Employers also cite low youth skills and other negative characteristics as factors in the decline of youth full time employment. A survey commissioned by the Confederation of Australian Industry found that major employer reasons for not hiring young people included: lack of maturity, 86.5 per cent; low skill level, 82.9 per cent; and lack of relevant training, 76.2 per cent. The Opposition's quick fix proposals, as found in the Fightback package where it simply suggests that youth wages should be lowered and all will be well, certainly have absolutely no foundation whatsoever. We cannot rely on that. I stress again that the jobs young people used to do have gone. For example, we now put petrol in our own tanks when we pull into a service station. The young people who used to do those jobs have long gone.

Young people are emerging citizens who will carry us forward to the year 2000 and beyond. We must stop acting as though our young people owe us something, that they have to keep somehow proving their worth. Instead, we as society owe them—we owe them a stake in the future; we owe them the options of education, work or training. We must also ensure that they have a secure income—not an income dependent upon walking the streets, having to prove week after week that nobody wants them, that there is not a place for them in the labour market.

Our social security system is not coping and cannot cope with these long term problems of structural change. It cannot cope with the new needs of young people who find themselves locked out of the labour market in the long term. We need a fresh approach. We need a new look at the situation. I await with interest tonight's statement in the hope that we will really see some changes for young people. We cannot afford to ignore their needs. We cannot leave them with no hope; we cannot leave them without any opportunity to fulfil their dreams. I hope that we will hear tonight of new long term proposals to ensure that young people have access to work, to education or to training with an assured income.

I stress some of the jobs that have been lost. I refer again to the report of the Youth Affairs Council which states that we no longer need mail deliverers, receptionists, telephone operators, messengers and electricians in the numbers that we needed before. We now have fax machines; we now have centralised exchanges. In our manufacturing industries we have automated testing and computerised surveillance. Architecture has also been, to a large extent, computerised. We do not need process workers, draft persons or technicians.

In publishing, we no longer need a lot of printers and typesetters. We have computerised printing and typesetting. Retailing and banking has seen another large number of reductions in the work force. We do not need as many bookkeepers, tellers or cashiers—all jobs that in the past have been held by young people. We have computerised accounting and automatic teller machines. In our offices we see photocopiers and word processors. Some offices and cafe bars have no need for tea ladies.
In closing, I want to stress that these jobs have gone in the long term. We need structural change to ensure that our young people are guaranteed education, work or training with a secure income.

TALK.START.PARA: —Until the last few days I had thought that there could be no greater indictment of a government than its failed policies in relation to offering employment to those in the nation who want to work, and particularly not being able to offer employment to young people seeking work. It seemed that the greatest indictment that one could make of a government was to claim that its policies had failed to result in a situation where people who wanted a job could actually get one. We now find that we have about one million Australians, many of them very young, who have no hope, no job and no access to tertiary education. They see themselves as being at the end of the line.

PARA.TAB: In the last couple of days my colleague Senator Baume has alerted me to a situation that many would regard as much worse than so many Australians, especially young Australians, being out of a job. He has alerted me to the fact that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) is not so much turning a blind eye to this problem but is actually manufacturing figures which give a false impression and are quite deceptive. That is worse.

I find it intolerable for a government to generate policies that leave Australians, especially young Australians, without jobs. But it is even more intolerable for it to then engage in some sort of statistical mishmash and pretend that the problem is not as bad as it really is. That is the ultimate disgrace. Australians are entitled to expect honesty from their government. Perhaps the history since 1983 has lowered the expectations of Australians in that respect. I am sorry that that is so.

The point that Senator Baume has been making quite ably is simply this: when we talk about the percentage of unemployed we all know that we are talking about the percentage of people who want to get a job but who cannot do so. Obviously, we do not refer to retired Australians over 65 years of age as being unemployed and looking for work—that would be meaningless. When we talk about the percentage of unemployment, we talk about the percentage of people who cannot get a job and who are in fact looking for work.

Senator Cook came in here today and sought to defend Minister Baldwin for coming up with an unemployment rate that shows the number of unemployed as a percentage not of those in the work force—that is, those looking for work—but of all people in that age group, whether they are looking for work or not. It is no defence at all for Senator Cook to come in here today and say, `Oh well, it is a bit different for young people—a lot of them are in education and that is a factor in relation to the youth labour market'. It is not. The people in full time education are not in the youth labour market—it is quite separate; it is irrelevant. So, we have this disastrous situation, made worse by a government trying to pretend that it is not as bad as it really is.

I support some of the remarks made by the Minister. I am pleased that more young Australians are going into higher education or are spending longer in their secondary education. But that does not change the percentage of people who are not going on to further secondary education or tertiary education, who are looking for a job and who now cannot get one. It is another irrelevant argument in relation to the people that Senator Baume's matter of public importance is directed at; that is, the young Australians who want to get a job and who simply cannot do so. It is true to say that one in three of those young Australians—perhaps even closer to one in two—cannot get a job.

We have a disastrous situation. The situation is far worse than the figures show and Senator Baume has outlined that perfectly adequately. He has indicated that discouraged job seekers are not included in some of the unemployment figures. Nor is the level of underemployment revealed in the unemployment figures. We have a Minister trying to pretend that in fact the situation is far better than the figures show and that is a disgrace.

We could stand here for hours and argue about the best way to refer to this situation statistically, but we would be wasting our time if we did so. There must be some common agreement that the situation at the moment is unacceptable. Surely, between all of us, we have some common ground in that respect. It is plainly unacceptable. People who are unemployed do not care what the unemployment rate is—they are 100 per cent unemployed.

This situation is hitting young Australians, the private sector and women—especially older women—and I am pleased that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, so graciously condescends to tell us that he is concerned about all unemployed as though there were something wrong with us in directing our attention to the plight of young Australians. We are all concerned about those people who want to work and cannot get a job. We clearly understand that this disastrous recession, which we were not going to have and then suddenly needed to have, is affecting young Australians, the private sector and women—especially older woman who are simply giving up. But surprise, surprise, it does not appear to be affecting the public sector; they are not feeling the pinch at all.

I noticed earlier that Senator Harradine was listening to this debate. He has had a longstanding interest in youth unemployment and, in particular, he has had a longstanding interest in the failure of the Australian Public Service to take and train its fair share of young Australians. I am sorry that he is not on the speaking list today because I would have been interested to hear what he would have had to say on this matter. What this Government has been doing in fact is fiddling while Rome burns. We have had promises, promises, promises in relation to employment or unemployment and the Government has been very short on delivery.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I take you back to five or six years ago when this Government spent hundred of thousands of dollars—I am not talking about $100,000 or $200,000; more likely $300,000 or $400,000—advertising that young Australians were its No. 1 priority. You might remember the Priority One: Young Australia scheme. Young Australians were going to have Australian traineeships. I think there were going to be 75,000 of them in our bicentennial year, according to the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. I think we got up to about 7,000 in that year, which put his promises at about 10c in the dollar. Of course, I would not give you that much on his promises in any event, but that is what the figures showed the promises were worth: 75,000 trainees in our bicentennial year and we ended up with about 7,000 or 8,000.

At that time I remember seeing a cartoon and I have never forgotten it. It had Bob Hawke sitting at a table with a carpenter's file filing his nails, because the slogan for Priority One was, `Youth of Australia, you are our No. 1 priority'. The slogan at the bottom of that cartoon was, `Youth of Australia, priority two—don't call us; we'll call you'. The youth of Australia have been waiting for the call for a job, and they have not got it yet.

Tonight we will no doubt hear some other extraordinary concoction of policies, and we will yet again pretend to young Australians that there is some opportunity being created for them by this Government; and yet again they will be let down. That is a disastrous situation for us to be facing.

Let me turn to some of the things that we could do. I listened with interest to Senator Lees because she and I have some common understanding in relation to certain aspects of her remarks on youth unemployment. But we differ in a number of areas, and I would like to give some attention to those at this stage.

We could give a couple of hints to the Government. First of all, it has to get the economy healthy so that the real jobs are there. There is no point in the Australian Democrats talking about how much we pay the unemployed and what we are going to do with this unemployed person or this unemployment training scheme if we do not address the basic problem of generating more real jobs. We can put as many bandaids as we like on those who are unemployed; it will not help the problem if at the end of the day we do not give them a real job. The Democrats should be concentrating on the policies being proposed by the parties—that is, the Fightback package and those policies practised by this Government since 1983. Let us not be fooled by any tinkering at the edges that goes on tonight. This lot has been in government since 1983. They want to choose between the results that have come about through the policies of these people over here and the alternative package that we offer and should not be misled, as I say, by this tinkering at the edges.

One of the aspects that we offer of particular interest to young Australians—I am sorry that Senator Lees is not here because she might have some interjections that she might like to make on these remarks—is the opportunity for genuine enterprise bargaining; that is, for people who work in a factory to make an arrangement with their boss in respect of that factory. If the factory is down at Millicent in South Australia, they do not want to have the award for that task be set in Sydney in some industrial commission by a whole lot of QCs who are paid far more than we or anybody in the gallery will ever get a sniff at. It is much better for an agreement to be reached on something that suits that factory down at the workplace level.

We might find one factory in South Australia, through mismanagement or bad luck with one of their big customers, going broke or for whatever reason in financial strife. We might find another factory on the other side of South Australia doing fairly well within the same award. Those workers in the factory that is battling, for whatever reason, should have the chance to keep their jobs by being able to make rearrangements. Similarly, the workers in the factory that is going really well should be able to share in the benefits of that and get over-award payments without running the risk of a wage spiral going through the whole economy. If it is their work, their effort and their conscientiousness that has made that factory go, and go well, they should get some benefit of that.

Senator Lees says that there is not much evidence to show that young Australians are being priced out of jobs. I note that she referred to the metal trades industry. She indicated that that industry has taken on a very significant proportion of young Australians, despite the fact that the disparity between adult and youth wages has not been that large. She says that that puts paid to the argument that young Australians are priced out of jobs. It is really not that simple. Senator Lees is forgetting the type of work that is available in the metal trades industry. The work has not changed as drastically as the work that is available in other industries. There are still more jobs available there for younger, less well trained people than there are in other industries. It is just not a simple situation.

Senator Lees should put herself in the position of having a small factory where she has five men or women working who are, say, 22 years old with some experience in whatever the industry is and she wants to take on another person. She should ask herself whether she is going to take on an 18 year old at full adult rates with no experience and sack one of the 23 year olds who has, say, four or five years experience. The simple answer to that is no, she will not do that.

These people have to have a chance; they have to be able to be above a minimum level. The coalition and I understand that. Our industrial relations policy provides for a minimum award rate so that people cannot be—I think the terminology is—screwed down by unscrupulous employers. We will not allow that to happen. But we do want young Australians to be able to say, `Look, I will take $20 less a week if I can keep my job'. I think plenty of young Australians out there on the dole queue of a million or more would very much like the opportunity to make their own negotiation with their employer; to offer to work for a bit less in the beginning to get the experience and to then make themselves a valuable employee who the boss cannot afford to dismiss because of the experience they have gained.

Senator Lees spoke of giving more dollars to the young unemployed and why do we cut the money to young unemployed. Without addressing the point, that question in one sense is irrelevant. It is irrelevant in the sense of what does one do to make real jobs for these people to turn them from being unemployed into being employed. Senator Lees wanted to talk about what money you give to the unemployed. I want to talk about how to turn them into employed people so that they get a decent wage and a wage that they feel they themselves have earned rather than a constant handout from the Government.

Last but not least, I note that the Democrats say that we need a fresh approach, a new look at this problem. But I do not hear any ideas from them as to what to do with it. In contrast to that, of course, the coalition's Fightback package will take off payroll tax, fuel excise and wholesale sales tax off business inputs. That takes the tax man's hand out of the business pocket. It makes business more efficient and gives it the opportunity to employ more Australians—and, it follows from that, young Australians. In conclusion, let me say that some honourable senators on the other side do not seem to understand that a GST will not increase prices by 15 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance from Senator Michael Baume which talks about the Government's dishonest attempt to pretend that the real youth unemployment rate is less than the adult rate. Let us look at what the Minister actually said in his press release. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The real percentage of young people genuinely seeking full time work and who are unable to find it is 8.8%.
What he is saying is that the number of young people seeking full time work relative to the total youth population is 8.8 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The 30 per cent figure represents the number of unemployed young people in the full time labour force. It is as simple as that. That is the least important issue in debate, although I agree with Senator Cook that, under this Government, from April 1983 to January 1992 teenage full time unemployment seasonally adjusted fell by 40,600, or 25.8 per cent, and the proportion of the teenage population unemployed and seeking full time unemployment fell from 12.3 to 8.8 per cent.
I want to say only one other thing about the haggling over figures that has occurred. Senator Baume was upset about the heading of a press release dated 16 February, which boasted:

SPEECH.PARA: No jobs for more than 1 in 3 young Australians.

It is clearly misleading. All I would say to Senator Baume is that he is a journalist and he knows that the heading often is the most important part of any communication, and that is a clearly misleading heading.

PARA.TAB: What we are saying does not change the number of young people looking for jobs who are unable to find them. No-one on this side of the Parliament thinks that the current level of youth unemployment is satisfactory. The real question is: whose policies will create jobs for young people seeking work and whose policies will ensure that there are measures in place to assist young people during this difficult time of high unemployment? The dispute over figures highlights a greater difference between the Government and the Opposition. I hope to deal with that contrast of policies, as I acknowledge that other people have attempted to. I certainly take up the challenge of Senator Vanstone to argue that point.

This Government believes that young people are the important next generation of our work force. The Government is concerned to ensure equity amongst young people through the youth social justice strategy, which targets disadvantaged young people in particular. Of course, we say that, by contrast, the coalition's package will not do that. We believe that a work force must be educated and skilled. The basic layer of education and skill that underpins the work force has been raised by this Government during its period of office.

Young people today have far greater access to education and training, be it through TAFE, universities, workplace-based training or labour market programs. That has occurred under this Government, in sharp contrast to our Liberal predecessors. It is no wonder that the Opposition does not want to acknowledge in its calculations the increased number of young people remaining at school or in post-secondary education.

As Senator Lees has indicated, technological and organisational change over the past 20 years has meant that many jobs that have traditionally been entry level positions have disappeared. Senator Lees reminded me of what has happened in the printing industry. I have had a long association with the printing, paper and metals industries, and all I can say is that, since I entered the printing industry in the 1950s, there have been dramatic changes in the prospects of young people. In general, traditional jobs are going or have gone. We as a government have been actively acknowledging that that is happening and have concentrated our emphasis on post-secondary education. The Whitlam Government, the Hawke Government and now the Keating Government have allocated massive resources into that area.

I want to talk about `value adding', a phrase that is now very commonly used. It is a very frequently used phrase that is perfectly appropriate. In industry, value added management and total quality control are used to denote the integration of advanced management technology and management systems. It is an issue of major cooperation in manufacturing industry. This Government, in its commitment to education and training, has value added to our human capital. That is a contrast with the Liberal governments of the past and with the package that the Liberal and National parties have for the future.

The runs are on the board as far as this Government is concerned. The retention rate in secondary schools has gone from one-third under the Fraser Government to two-thirds under Labor. As Minister Cook has said, in March about 66 per cent of the entire teenage population will be in some form of education and training, attending school or tertiary full time study. With adjustments, that leaves about 28 per cent of the teenage population in the labour force. That contrasts with what is happening overseas. When one compares this record with that of the Fraser Government and the Menzies Government—one can take any of the conservative governments in that whole period of conservative control—one can see that they were characterised by inertia in this area. It is very difficult for Opposition speakers to talk about what this Government is doing when it has such a poor record.

This Government is now moving to the next phase of adding value to our human capital in TAFE and universities right across the country. This reflects the Government's concern that Australia should not face the long term skills shortages that occurred after the 1982-83 recession we inherited. The Government will provide more than $13 billion for universities over the 1992-94 triennium and will create almost 35,000 new places for Australian students, making a total of 85,000 new places since 1988.

The 1992 funding includes an extra $9.7m in operating grants and $24 million in research funds and an additional $70m in capital funding to help alleviate overcrowding problems. Arising out of the November employment statement, there is an additional $34m funding package for new technical and further education in New South Wales, the home State of Senator Baume and myself. In practice, the Greiner Liberal Government's contribution to educating young people in my State has been to allow the TAFE system to deteriorate. This funding will provide the equivalent of an extra 15,000 full time places in New South Wales in 1992. The Government has also announced a $33m package of incentives to expand apprenticeship and traineeship opportunities and to save existing jobs.

This Government does not play a role only through the formal higher education mechanism, and this is one of the contrasts. It also has a range of labour market programs that time and time again have proven to be effective in retraining people and enhancing their prospects of finding a job. The training component of programs such as Jobtrain, Jobskills, Jobsearch training and Jobstart is clearly the key element of their success. I will later show that the coalition's program does not have that training component that is a characteristic of this Government's training programs.

As the Minister has pointed out, the industry is supportive of the Government's belief that training and further education are the key to young people's futures. The integration of better educated and trained young people into the work force has occurred under this Government and the training and broadbanding of skills has occurred in industry after industry. That is the other side of the integration of education and industry that has occurred under this Government. It lays the basis, as we move out of the recession, for ensuring that the employment people have will be career employment, whether in traditional careers or in industries that, until this Government came along, were not career based industries at all.

I find it interesting that we have the Opposition professing its concern for young people when, as Senator Cook has said, the only attempt in the document detailing the Fightback package to address the needs of at risk young people is a statement that the coalition would help young people to make the transition from school to further training. Apart from a reference to the end of automatic entitlement to the Jobsearch allowance after nine months, there is no further mention made in the document to disadvantaged young people. But this applies to everyone; in other words, young people will be disadvantaged in exactly the same way as older people.

I turn to the specific proposals of the Fightback package to show how young people would be affected under the coalition. Labour market program expenditure will be reduced by $140m. That is horrendous. By replacing Jobstart with Austrain, abolishing the self-employment assistance program and cutting Jobtrain, Austrain will be a wage subsidy program where the subsidy is paid to the unemployed person in the form of below award wages.

We have just heard Senator Vanstone advance the ideology of the coalition. She said that people could take $20 a week less. In other words, she is saying that it is fair enough to give the employer untrammelled rights in an enterprise bargaining arrangement. Of course, the coalition puts forward this enterprise union nonsense. What this would really do is smash unions. How would a young person, who bowls up to an employer in an industry which has no award laying down minimum standards, get into employment? Indeed, in principle Austrain is a below award arrangement which undermines the rates in a particular industry or field.

Senator Vanstone said in her example that a person might take a cut of $20 to help out his employer, as it were. What the coalition ignores is that the good employer who is doing the right thing will be forced by a direct rival to cut wages because of market competition. In no time flat, the person who is disadvantaged will be the younger person.

So what young people face is not only the abolition of the CES and youth access centres under a coalition government but also a whole system designed to make it difficult for them to get training. Once again, that contrasts with the situation under this Government of a whole system of training, cooperatively agreed between all the principals of an industry. What people face under the coalition is the offer of a jungle—the power of a jungle against young people. I believe that we have to look past the immediate problems. Tonight we will solve many of those problems. When we consider the future of Australia, we must recognise that we need planning and industry agreement. We do not want the coalition's jungle.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Cook opened the case for the Government this afternoon he criticised my colleague Senator Baume for his emotive and eloquent address and promised instead to introduce some logic into the debate. Unfortunately, he did not do so. This debate is about the disreputable and dishonest attempts of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to play down the serious crisis of youth unemployment. Anybody with any intelligence at all knows perfectly well that the youth unemployment rate in this country is far higher than the overall unemployment rate. Yet Minister Baldwin continues with the pathetic line that the youth unemployment rate is 8.8 per cent and below the average unemployment rate. Nothing could be further from the truth.

PARA.TAB: But let us just assume for a moment that Mr Baldwin is right. Let us assume that `the real percentage of young people genuinely seeking full time work who are unable to find it is 8.8 per cent'. On that basis, what Mr Baldwin is saying is a bald admission that every single person aged 15 to 19 years who is in education or who is in part-time work is really seeking full-time work. That in itself is a damming indictment of this Government's failed policies. If Mr Baldwin's statement is correct, then very clearly we have a massive problem with the underemployed, the people who cannot get a full-time job and have to make do with a part-time job; the people who aspire to have a decent standard of living yet who, under this Government's policy, have been condemned to a lifetime of penury. That is the indictment and it comes from the Minister's lips.

Furthermore, if Mr Baldwin is correct in saying that the real percentage of young people genuinely seeking full-time work and unable to get it is 8.8 per cent, then what he is saying is that all those people who are in training or in education are really unemployed. It is an admission that what we have under this Government is not some effort to increase the number of skilled people or the pool of people in the skilled work force but the implementation of a policy of study for the dole.

We have believed for a long time that there is a massive level of underemployment in this nation and now we find that it is true. If the Government follows the logical consequences of Mr Baldwin's statement, that can be the only truth—that young people in this nation do not have a certain future, that they are having their aspirations crushed by the failure of this Government to create real work and that they have been sold short by Mr Hawke, by Mr Keating, by Mr Baldwin and by Senator Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do, Senator? Let us hear it.

—I would sit and wait if I were Minister Collins, because we are going to get into some of the genuinely extraneous arguments that have come from the other side of the chamber. One of the words that Mr Baldwin has relied upon is `genuinely'. `Genuinely seeking employment', he says. Does that mean that all those people who are in higher education or who cannot get into the course they want and who have to stay at school for another year, like my brother, are not genuine in their attempts to get work? Is that what he is saying? That is what it sounds like. There is an attempt by this Government to slur the integrity of those young Australians, and I think it is disgraceful. But that is just typical of this Government; it cannot face up to the facts.

PARA.TAB: Of most note in all of this is Senator Cook's argument that we have to use a different measure for youth unemployment than is used for the rest of this nation. He said, and I quote him almost verbatim, that `education and training is a feature of the youth labour market which is not applicable generally'. Does Senator Cook really ask this chamber to believe that there are no people aged over 19 years who are involved in training or education? Does Senator Cook genuinely ask this chamber to believe such a ludicrous argument as that? That is what Senator Cook said. It was a disgraceful and dishonest attempt by Senator Cook to distinguish the youth labour market—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Senator O'Chee, I ask you to withdraw that reference to the Minister. You used the word `dishonest'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I am happy to withdraw, but does that mean that we will have a withdrawal of all the comments from honourable senators on the other side of this chamber which have been directed at us?

—You know the rules of parliamentary procedure in here, Senator. If you are not clear, I will be happy to advise you. You may proceed with the argument but you may not use such language as that against a Minister.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, the mendacity of this Government is disgraceful. The intellectual sloth of members of this Government is disgraceful. Their inability to understand or repeat the truth is disgraceful. Their little minds cannot even grasp the truth. The truth is that young people have been sold short by the people sitting opposite us in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: That is the truth in Australia today. Although the Minister and his friends may not understand it, although the Minister and his friends may not like repeating the truth, young Australians know the truth, young Australians repeat the truth, and young Australians will bring the truth home to this Government at the next election. That is something we can all be sure of.

Senator Cook does not like the truth. That is why he tries to distinguish the youth labour market. That is why he makes up all these crazy, fanciful arguments, this sophistry as to why young people should be treated as second class citizens by the Bureau of Statistics. After all, young people are treated as second class citizens by this Government in the implementation of its policies. On Senator Cook's line of argument, why should young people not be treated as second class citizens by the Bureau of Statistics?

In listening to the debate and the argument Senator Cook put forward, it struck me that if Mr Baldwin ever discovered the truth about youth unemployment, he would be like the atheist who, upon coming face to face with the Almighty, finds himself forced to declare, `But I am sure you have another job'. This Government has tried to hide the evil and unacceptable face of youth unemployment for far too long. Let us get into some of the real figures from the Bureau of Statistics, which show that everything Senator Cook said in the chamber today—I am glad he has come back in—was a sham. Senator Cook tried to tell us that employment prospects for young people have actually gone up.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't really!
—He did; he tried, but I am going to blow that one down. In fact, teenage full time jobs have fallen from 464,000 in January 1983 to 290,400 in January 1992.
—They just got wiped out.

—They just got wiped out, as Senator Baume has so eloquently said. We have seen all of those youth jobs wiped out—from 464,000 down to 290,000. What is worse, that is in a population 40,000 larger than it was in 1983. So the prospects for real full time employment for young Australians in Mr Keating's Australia, Senator Cook's Australia and Mr Baldwin's Australia are half what they were in 1983. We can compare the total number of young Australians employed in January 1983, which was 620,400, with the total number of young Australians employed in January 1992, which was 580,000.

PARA.TAB: I do not know where Senator Cook and Mr Baldwin get their schooling in logic, but logic tells me that when the number of employed young people—full time or part time—drops from 620,000 to 580,000 in the course of this Labor Government, there is not much opportunity for young Australians to labour profitably in this nation any longer. That is what it tells me, that is what it tells every thinking Australian, and only people such as Senator Cook would be foolish enough to believe the contrary. But that is the argument the Government has tried to advance here today.

Senator Cook tried to advance the argument that we should be talking about the labour force participation rate. I hope Senator Cook is smiling right now. Let me make it clear: the labour force participation rate is based on the number of people who are in or seeking paid employment. So every time this Government refers to the labour force participation rate and does not refer to the unemployment rate, what it is really doing is congratulating itself on the number of people who are looking for a job and cannot find one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—That is the truth. Senator Cook knows it is the truth. We all know it is the truth. That is why this Government does not have the integrity to talk about unemployment. That is why this Government has a Minister who does not have the desire or the intestinal fortitude to talk about the number of young Australians who are really unemployed. Let us not talk about increasing the dole; let us not talk about fanciful training schemes. Let us now get down to the truth, to reality.

PARA.TAB: I refer honourable senators to my family, and I will tell them what this Government is doing to young Australians. I have a brother who turns 18 this year. He falls slap bang in the middle of this statistical group. He finished school with a pretty good TE score—a score of 900, which when I left school would have got one into most tertiary courses in Queensland. What is he doing this year? Is he in tertiary studies? No, because a place could not be found for him—so many young Australians are missing out on places in tertiary studies. Did he take the next option of going into the work force, which is what he wanted to do? No, because there were no jobs. So what is he doing? He is whiling away another 12 months at school doing it all over again.

That is the sad face of youth unemployment in this country; that is the sad face of youth underemployment in this country. Let us not hear about the Government's fanciful training schemes. Let us not hear all this nonsense about creating a pool of skilled labour. The fact is that young Australians are being locked out of universities, locked out of TAFE and locked out of jobs. There is no point either in arguing, as Senator Childs has done—I am sure it was with the best intentions in the world—that voluntary employment agreements will not improve the job prospects of young Australians. There is no point in arguing that improving union membership will give young Australians jobs. I will tell honourable senators opposite how the union movement works in this country. My brother has a part time job; he works his way through school so that he is not a burden on his family. The union movement says to people such as him, `Listen, brother, you are not a member of the union. You can cough up $150 to join the union so that you can spend just four hours a week putting the colour inserts into the Sunday Sun'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's shameful.

—It is shameful. But what is really shameful is that my brother earns $70 to $80 a week doing that job. What the union said to him was, `If you want to keep your job, you have to work two weeks for us'.
—That's under no ticket, no start.

—Yes, no ticket, no start. The irony of it all, of course, is that my brother's job ends in March but, under his union rules, he has to give three months notice. If he cannot give the union three months notice, for whatever reason, he has to pay his union membership dues for another three months. What did the union do for him? It did absolutely nothing at all. That is the shameful truth about what this Government and its friends are doing for the young people of this nation. They are doing absolutely nothing at all.

PARA.TAB: They are the facts. We have had enough of the sophistry from the other side of the chamber, enough of the failed attempts at logic, the failed attempts at eloquence, the failed attempts at emotiveness. Yes, we may be emotive on this side, but with good reason. I hope we are eloquent on this side, and for a good reason. We are certainly logical on this side, and for a good reason. There are over 150,000 good reasons why we should be emotive and eloquent and logical. There is over 35.8 per cent youth unemployment in this nation, and that is another reason why we should be emotive and eloquent and logical. That is why this side of the chamber will persist in being emotive, eloquent and logical until this disreputable Government is thrown out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make one point very strongly in my contribution to this matter of public importance: not only do I believe that youth unemployment in this country is far too high; I also believe that unemployment in this country is far too high. That spans the spectrum of people, be they people from 15 to 19, be they the over-45s, be they in their twenties or thirties or whatever. We have far too many unemployed people in this country.

PARA.TAB: I will defend Minister Baldwin and Minister Cook on the statistics we are talking about, but I do not want to get lost in the statistics and forget that we are talking about real people, people who are very close to the commencement of their adult lives. The fact that many of these young people have been through the education system, which generally has geared them to enter the work force, and that we in turn have not delivered them a job at the end of it is an indictment upon us which I am certain that we as a Government will be redressing with a sense of urgency. I am hopeful that measures to relieve the suffering will be contained in the statement that will be delivered in this place and in the other place in a matter of hours.

I listened with great interest to all the speakers in this debate, although I was not able to be in the chamber all the time. I certainly endorse the comments made by my Minister Senator Cook, and my colleague Senator Childs, and will not waste the time of the Senate by repeating the arguments advanced by my two colleagues. I also have to admit that there were some contributions made by colleagues on the other side of the chamber with which one could find oneself in partial agreement. I completely and utterly dissociate myself and, indeed, this side of the chamber from the argument that if we slash wages, youth unemployment will be resolved. I also do not agree that if we slash taxes youth unemployment will be resolved.Senator Lees, I think, made a very balanced contribution and we should take her comments into account in addressing this matter in the near future.

When the matter of public importance was first brought to my attention this morning I undertook to try to find out where it had come from. I was aware that Senator Baume had asked a question yesterday and was moving this matter of public importance today. I searched, as indeed my colleagues have done, the bible of the Opposition—the Fightback! document—for references to youth unemployment to see exactly where this new-found idealism and new-found will to assist our young people had come from. I was sadly disappointed because there is very little reference in that document—a very weighty document—to youth, the future of this nation. Certainly, it is mentioned, but it is mentioned more in the negative than it is in the positive. One could accuse the Opposition of completely and utterly overlooking the youth of this country.

I think that the Fightback! document could better be described as an economic document looking at screwing the working class of this country rather than creating jobs or creating growth. Certainly, there are a number of measures in it that will contain Government expenditure, such as the saving of an alleged $160m by amalgamating the Commonwealth Employment Service with the Department of Social Security and privatising or contracting out the job placement activities of the Commonwealth Employment Service. However, the Opposition overlooks the fact that Australia's Commonwealth Employment Service is by far and away one of the world's best government bureaucracies in terms of placing people in employment. Nonetheless, for the sake of saving $160m, the Commonwealth Employment Service will be wiped out.

There is no mention in the Fightback! document of the Jobsearch assistance programs which the Hawke Labor Government introduced and which the Keating Labor Government also has in place. There is no mention of the Jobskills program or the special intervention programs which we have engaged upon or, indeed, of Task, the mobility assistance program, or the Office of Labour Market Adjustments. They are not worthy of a mention in a document which is supposed to be dealing with jobs and growth.

The local employment boards, comprising local Department of Social Security officials, State and local government training representatives and community and business sector representatives, are said to build on Skillshare while allowing local communities to determine the best means of spending funds allocated to labour market programs. There is a mention of Skillshare in the Fightback! document, a very worthwhile Government initiative which is, indeed, placing people in employment in Australia today.

The Opposition's Austrain program, part of its proposal to slash wages, is elaborated on in the Fightback package. The document states that after six months of unemployment an employer will be able to offer a job at 90 per cent of award rates or other equivalent minimum to an unemployed person, provided that that person has been unemployed for six months. After 12 months that job offer could be made at 80 per cent of the minimum award rate. If one followed that scenario through to the end, one would see that a person who had been unemployed for five years could be offered a job at nil rates of pay. Indeed, I think that if the Opposition ever regained the treasury bench we would find that it would certainly be going down that track. The difficulty we have got with the Fightback package is that it has been developed by New Right think tanks which have sprung up around Australia in recent years. They are think tanks which are out of touch with the electorate and out of touch with youth.

Obviously, the resolve to bring this matter before the chamber did not arise from the Fightback! document. I wondered where else it might have come from. As a parliamentarian I receive lots of items of mail, some of which are filed immediately and some of which are read. I am tempted to say that one item of mail which I have received recently is perhaps where the Opposition or Senator Baume got their ideas from. Vanguard is a publication of the Communist Party of Australia—Marxist-Leninist.

The lead article of the edition of Vanguard which I received recently in my office is headed, `Anger Among Youth Grows'. A quick scanning of the article reveals that it has used some of the same figures that Senator Baume has been using in this place. I have not completely studied the article, nor have I had the opportunity to study Senator Baume's figures which were incorporated in his speech earlier this afternoon, so I will not comment. However, I suggest that it is perhaps more than an accident that this particular newspaper has arrived at the same time that Senator Baume has put forward his very caring—as he would see it—matter of public importance on youth unemployment.

I also listened to Senator O'Chee. Of course, we now know where Senator O'Chee gets his advice from—his 18-year-old brother. Although there may be some difficulties in taking and acting on advice from 18-year-olds, I do commend him for at least talking with young people, even though the young person may indeed be an immediate relative, because he might learn something from meeting and talking with a younger person.

I do that as well, not only as a member of parliament, as a representative of Western Australia in this chamber, but I happen also to be a parent who in recent times has gone through the difficulty of having an offspring who has been part of the unemployment statistics. That person, my daughter, is now, thankfully, part of the education system—also a statistic. She dropped out of school on completion of year 10—she did not complete years 11 and 12. She has now, thanks to the good grace of this Government, but more particularly the Western Australian State Government, returned to full time schooling and, hopefully, is working her way towards the completion of TEE.

There is no way in the world that Donna, my daughter, could be included in the statistics of people looking for work. It does not matter that she is now in full time education at the age of almost 19. Her being in full time education is an indication that she has removed herself from the labour market, certainly in the immediate sense. Therefore, if one uses a real life situation and applies it to Senator Baume's argument—an argument which he has put to the Australian media by way of a press release on 16 February this year—there is absolutely no way that it will stand up when one considers real human beings rather than just figures.

A great deal of the argument we have heard in this chamber this afternoon about whether the statistics of unemployed young people are one in three or 8.8 per cent, as Minister Baldwin would have it, is an irrelevance. Honourable senators on all sides of the chamber would agree that youth unemployment is far too high and that action must be taken to get it down. I am confident that if this debate were being held tomorrow after the delivery of the Prime Minister's economic statement, contained in that statement would be initiatives to relieve the sufferings of these young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it provide them with genuine jobs?

—I am certainly hopeful that there will be genuine jobs. It depends on the definition of what a genuine job is. Is being an Opposition senator in this place a genuine job? I would argue that it is, but I would argue that many of those opposite do not do their jobs particularly well. In raising matters such as Opposition members have raised this afternoon, they have not made a tremendous contribution to undertaking a genuine job. If it is a genuine job and we are serious about cutting salaries, why pick on the unemployed and particularly youth unemployed? Why lop 10 per cent or 20 per cent off their income? I ask those opposite why they do not start with themselves because they do not deserve the salaries that are being paid to them at the moment. Opposition members are hardly laying a glove on the Government and that is part of the reason, I suggest, why youth unemployment and unemployment are as high as they are today.
—It is an interesting reason.

—Perhaps I should change my tack or I shall get myself into difficulty. Opposition members will quote me in the context of statements about the unemployed. I support Minister Baldwin when he puts forward the figure of 8.8 per cent. I conclude by making the point that, irrespective of whether the figure is 8.8 per cent or one person in three, it is still far too high. I am certain that the Prime Minister tonight will deliver a statement that will reduce either of those figures.

—The new poor in Australia are the young. The growing underclass is unemployed young Australians, many of whom are unskilled, inexperienced and in desperate need of training opportunities. The new poor are found on the streets of Kings Cross in Sydney, on the beaches of St Kilda in Melbourne, in the urban sprawl of Adelaide, Melbourne and Sydney and throughout the country. They have been betrayed by this Government which promised that no child would live in poverty by 1990. I defy any Minister to walk through Kings Cross and look at the child prostitutes, the street kids and the hopeless ones in the eye. The obscenity of the ex-Prime Minister's salary, payments for interviews and other perks are in stark contrast to the legacy of young unemployed people struggling to survive on only a piddling $62.05 per week two years after he made that audacious promise.

PARA.TAB: The latest unemployment statistics, which record a massive youth unemployment rate of 30 per cent, sanitise the human misery and the destruction of our most valuable resource, the idealism of young people, hope and belief in their future and the future of Australia.

This Senate must consider the socially and economically disastrous effects of these record levels of youth unemployment. The Government has an obligation to provide solutions; such an important task cannot be left up to the `invisible hand' of market forces. The figures paper over this misery by understating the huge level of youth unemployment. We cannot begin to imagine how many young people are actually out of work, as the Australian Bureau of Statistics deems employment to be anyone working one paid hour for profit or pay during a survey week, including cases where they worked one hour in a family business. A large number of younger workers have lost their jobs as a result of the recession, but not all are joining the dole queue.

We have seen enormous changes in the workplace over the past 10 years. New technology has made redundant many low skilled labour intensive jobs which traditionally soaked up young people and school students who left the system before completion of their studies. The retail sector, normally a large employer of young people, has been badly hit by the recession and job opportunities have shrunk.

It is no longer possible for students to leave school before completing year 12 and expect to obtain decent employment opportunities. The changing nature of the workplace means that employers need skilled workers who can perform a variety of tasks. A young school leaver with no qualifications simply cannot compete in this kind of environment when the job market contracts. Hence, enhanced training and education opportunities must be offered to young people. But what we have seen is an inability of the education system to cope with these new demands. This is evidenced by as many as 50,000 university applicants and up to 100,000 TAFE applicants who missed out on places this year.

The fact that we are, according to Minister Beazley, `comparatively generous' in our education provision is not a reason to continually decrease our spending on education and training but is every reason to promote it and expand it to its traditionally high standards. Countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development such as France, Germany and Sweden are leading the way with additional funds for education, training and research. Australia's spending on education is below one per cent of gross domestic product.

The review into post-compulsory education, known as the Finn review, recommends that 95 per cent of all 19 year olds will be in either higher education or the work force with a certificate of some kind by the year 2001. This commendable target will not be met by the Government unless we see a commitment of up to $5 billion injected into the TAFE sector, as suggested by the Ramsay review into TAFE. A major expansion in TAFE facilities would help ensure that our young people are qualified for their futures and ensure a better future for this country. But this Government has rewarded the aspirations of our youth with limited access to education and training, increased living costs and rocketing unemployment levels.

Employment for young people not only means the ability to sustain themselves and often their dependants, but it also represents a step towards independence and self-respect. This self-respect is the lifeblood of the clever country. The Government has bled this dry with its economic rationalist policies that have resulted, according to former Minister Clyde Cameron, in `nothing short of a social tragedy'. In reality, what this Government offers the youth of today is no jobs and no hope.

We can only hope that tonight's economic statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) offers recovery in the form of increased expenditure for further education and training programs for young Australians. We would hope to see some direction given to Australia's faltering apprenticeship schemes so that the skills base so necessary for Australia's economic development is nurtured.

How can we claim to be the clever country when so many students cannot gain access to universities or colleges of technical and further education and those that do are in institutions that are overcrowded, have substandard facilities and have to support themselves on Austudy payments below the poverty line?

The Opposition's panacea for youth unemployment, the idea to cut youth wages by 20 per cent, is confirmation of a belief that young people have little to offer this country, yet their services are available to those who want to exploit them for the benefit of profit margins. The coalition's policy would create an underclass of unemployed young people with no incentives and no self-respect. When combined with their scorched earth industrial relations policy, this is a recipe for exploitation and the kind of developments which have emerged in New Zealand. For example, under the New Zealand employment contracts legislation there have been a number of examples that have emerged in recent months which have shown that real exploitation is the result of a totally deregulated labour market.

I have a couple of examples. One is of an 18-year-old who worked in a takeaway bar on three months probation for $30 a day. She was then hired full time for five 12-hour days per week, still for $30 a day, or $2.50 per hour. The old award minimum rate was $7.15 an hour for a 40-hour week for a kitchen hand. As another example, a 16-year-old took a job at a rest home, signing a contract for a flat rate of $6.30 an hour, with no extra loading for overtime. Some time later she found herself working up to 10 hours a day, seven days a week for the same hourly rate.

In the Age recently there was an advertisement extolling the virtues of the New Zealand economic situation as a new location for industry. It said that the recent Employment Contracts Act had abolished industrial awards, leaving employers free to negotiate terms of employment for a labour cost saving of up to 25 per cent. I point out that labour cost saving is not just a bottom line figure that appears on someone's balance sheets. It means a 25 per cent reduction in real wages for workers. That is what we would have in Australia under a flat earth industrial relations policy, and young workers in non-unionised sectors of the economy would be hit very severely.

Australians need to look very closely at the kinds of policies that are being promoted and the kind of deregulated labour market promoted by both the Opposition and the Government. It is vital that adequate safety nets be provided for workers, especially young workers, to ensure that they do not fall below the poverty line in a grab by employers simply to offer lower wages to workers as the labour market contracts.

It is a prevalent notion that the reduction of youth wages will provide increased employment opportunities for the young. The theory goes that young people receive lower wages than adult workers on the basis that they have different levels of experience and different social and economic needs. These assumptions require re-examination, as young people nowadays often acquire the responsibilities that come with adulthood, such as being responsible for themselves and often dependants without adult status. Governments are quick to recognise adult responsibilities that come with adulthood, such as voting, the age of consent and the right to drink. Yet most awards with junior pay rates do not give adult wages to under-21-year-olds.

The cost to Australia in terms of lost skills cannot be measured and the cost to the taxpayer has not been determined. Youth homelessness has not been substantially reduced, with up to 30 per cent increases in the number of children haunting Kings Cross. This Government must recognise its responsibilities in the area of training and education as a major way of helping improve the job prospects of young people.
Once again, the Democrats expect that tonight big business will receive government support: in essence, corporate welfare at the cost of welfare support for ordinary suffering Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Australian Institute of Marine Science on its annual report for the year 1990-91. Queensland can be proud of the fact that such a worthwhile institute is in Townsville in north Queensland. The work the Institute does in undertaking research and development in order to generate knowledge in marine science and technology and to promote its application in industry and government is vital to the healthy maintenance of our vast coastal areas.

PARA.TAB: As a Queenslander, I am particularly keen on the vital work it does, especially in the north of the State on the vast expanses of the Great Barrier Reef. Those honourable senators who have travelled to north Queensland, as you have, Mr Deputy President, will know what a wonderful tourist attraction the Great Barrier Reef is. People go there to scuba dive and snorkel. There is a great marlin fishing season around September each year on the Barrier Reef. On one occasion I tried diving underneath a boat out from Lizard Island. I am afraid that I am not very good; I am nothing like a good scuba diver. I managed to get down just far enough to have a look at the big spotted cod that were there and I realised that there are many marvellous fish on the reef. I prefer to look at the reef through a glass-bottom boat. It is certainly a much easier way of seeing the wonders of the reef, as far as I am concerned.

We must ensure that the many tourists who go there do not damage the reef. At low tide a lot of tourists go out and look at the wonders of the reef, and that is very important. In this report the Chairman notes that the scientific highlights in the area in the past five years included a number of research projects. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The institute's crown-of-thorns study continued and helped to allay many of the fears that the infestation would destroy the Great Barrier Reef.
The report goes on:
Work on coral density banding provided information about coral growth over long time periods.
The institute found evidence for a decline in coral growth in the last few decades in the central and northern sections of the Great Barrier Reef.
However, longer growth records show that such declines have occurred in the past.

I think I could say the same about the crown of thorns starfish, which at different times has infested the reef. I can remember many occasions while my husband was Premier when authorities were worried that the reef would be utterly destroyed by the crown of thorns starfish. Then nature seemed to revive the reef and the plague disappeared for some time. It comes and goes. That is one of the things with nature—one just does not know how these things happen. On page 35 the report points out that the Institute has been conducting surveys of the crown of thorns starfish and corals over much of the Great Barrier Reef since 1985. I believe that God has made a wonderful world, and I class the Great Barrier Reef as the eighth wonder of the world.

PARA.TAB: On page 29 the report talks about cyclone Ivor and the effects of tropical cyclones on the Great Barrier Reef. Often the cyclones come down that way and affect it. I have also noted—as you would know, Mr Deputy President—the number of times people complain about the road that was built through the Daintree forest to Cooktown. I always felt that was a very important road for the people who live in Cooktown. I once travelled right around the back road to get to Cooktown. It was a terrible road and very long. They talked about the damage to the reef from that road. We can see that the reef manages to rehabilitate itself from time to time.
It is very good indeed that we have an institute such the Australian Institute of Marine Science, and I am very pleased to speak to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak to the report of the Australian Institute of Marine Science. It does not seem to occur to many Australians what a huge and vast coastline we have and how much the sea is part of our livelihood. We are not a maritime country; we do not think of the sea as being important, and this is an area that must change. In changing that view, it is appropriate that we should spend more on and become more involved in marine research. This Institute is doing that in a very practical way at Townsville. We have some great marine scientists, not only at the Institute but in other places as well.

PARA.TAB: So many Australians know nothing about the Institute. Regrettably, even Australians who get as far as Townsville very seldom find their way to the Institute. It does not get nearly enough publicity for the work it does, so very few people find out about it through normal media processes. It is doing wonderful work. The work that it is doing and the people who are doing it receive praise from all around the world. In particular, the work of the Director, Dr Joe Baker, receives special recognition. He speaks at various conferences and groups in all parts of the world. He is very highly regarded and we are extremely fortunate to have a man of that calibre able and willing to look after the Institute in Townsville. I occasionally see Dr Baker when he comes to Canberra. I always find him a fascinating person to talk to and the projects that the Institute is undertaking are most exciting. I was interested to learn from the report that its five-year plan has just concluded and it has started on the next one.

The work that is being done by the Institute covers a variety of areas. It is mainly the work that is done on the Barrier Reef that most people know about. That is not all it does by any means. It is not only the crown-of-thorns starfish that is important; the corals themselves are important.

I am pleased that this organisation has taken a lot of trouble to allay some of the fears that people have. It is very easy to follow the type of line that tells us that everything is bad, we have problems galore and it will only get worse. I have just come from a discussion. Talk about distortion and destruction! We heard nothing but half-truths on another matter. I am very pleased that the Institute of Marine Science at least provides comfort to people as far as the quality and quantity of the corals are concerned and the fact that the crown-of-thorns starfish will not be the be-all and end-all—particularly the end-all—of the Reef.

The research that the Institute has done into climatic conditions through the effects on the corals over a period of 250 years is most important to Australia and does a lot to tell us the life of the area over that period. The Institute has carried out research into the coastal ecosystems, the mangroves and all the fish that live and breed amongst the mangroves. To many people, mangroves are a nuisance and an encumbrance towards development. They form a very important part of the Barrier Reef.

I conclude by paying tribute to Dr Farrands who held the chairmanship of the Institute from 1982 to 1990. He did a great job through very difficult times. I hope to get up to the Institute again in the very near future. I recommend to anybody who has an interest in science and great scientists to try to do likewise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I wish to associate myself with the remarks that Senator Archer has just made about the Australian Institute of Marine Science. It is a very competent and well regarded organisation. Organisations such as the Institute of Marine Science deserve to have their very good works publicly acknowledged as often as possible. The Institute needs to be encouraged to continue with the magnificent work it is doing and the quality and excellence for which it is well renowned.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Archer has mentioned, the Institute is recognised around the world as one of the leading organisations in marine science. I am very proud of the organisation. It is located in the area where I live and where my office is. In association with the James Cook University of north Queensland, it has done some magnificent work on the Great Barrier Reef, marine life, fishing and all of those sorts of things generally. While I had the opportunity, I wanted simply to join with others in acknowledging the magnificent work that that organisation performs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to place on record the Opposition's congratulations to the Chairperson of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, former Senator Peter Baume, Professor Peter Baume, on being recognised on Australia Day, among others, by his receiving of the Order of Australia. There is no doubt in all our minds that he was a very worthy recipient of that recognition.

PARA.TAB: I have to chide my cousin in his report to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) covering this annual report because no date is reproduced on the letter to indicate on which day it was sent by Professor Baume, as Chairperson, to the Minister. The reason I am concerned about this is that this report is being presented in this chamber late in February when a draft of it was presented to us in the September Senate Estimates Committee. It is incredible that even though this report was basically available—not in its final state but certainly in draft form—it is finally brought into this chamber towards the end of February. That is just not good enough; it is ridiculous.

I pressed the Australian Sports Drug Agency at the time of the Senate Estimates as to when it expected its annual report to be presented to the Senate. At that time, the slot time—almost like aircraft arrivals—given by AGPS appeared to be November at the earliest. At that stage it had not received the Auditor-General's certificate. I now note from the annual report that the Auditor's certificate was received on 25 October. Even though the Senate sat until 21 December, it could not get this report into this Parliament by then. This is grossly inadequate.

I am not blaming the Australian Sports Drug Agency. On the contrary, I congratulated it at the time for giving us the draft report. I recognise, however, that its expectation that the Auditor's report would be available within a few weeks of 9 September did not come to fruition. I see that the Auditor's report is dated 25 October. It is still unacceptable that it takes so long for reporting to take place from government bodies, particularly an important one such as this. This report has a lot of significant material in it.

As I understood from the Department at the time of Senate Estimates, it is obliged to do all this through the Australian Government Publishing Service. As Mr Blunn said, it is like getting into a queue for printing, which can cause significant delays. That queue for printing is unreasonably and improperly delaying the presentation of a whole host of reports to this Parliament. This is a classic example of how that takes place.

There are many matters relating to the Australian Sports Drug Agency which I do not want to raise now because we will be dealing with amendments to its Act shortly. It seems extraordinary that some of those amendments have to be made so recently after the Act was passed, including, for example, making the Sports Drug Agency exempt from sales tax. One would have thought that that would be an obvious part of the original legislation, but it was not to be. We will deal with the matters of substance when that legislation comes up. In the meantime, I hope that the Australian Government Publishing Service and DASET itself can do something to speed up this quite unsatisfactory situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to speak to the annual report of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I am very unhappy to have listened to Senator Michael Baume's contribution. I am very happy to support him in his remarks about his cousin and I sincerely hope his cousin, who is no longer in this place, takes him aside at the next weekend and speaks to him sternly about this tedious complaining about timing and dates. We have already reported this matter at length in the report on annual reports, which is one of the more splendidly preoccupying reports in this place. It is a matter that has already been very strenuously addressed; it is a matter that really is not of concern to be associated with a report. It ought to be taken up with the Australian Government Publishing Service. I think it is a big distraction from the points at issue in this report that could be more seriously addressed.

PARA.TAB: As the report says, the ASDA was established under the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 on 18 February 1991. The Agency operated as an interim organisation within the DASETT portfolio from 1 July 1990 until 18 February 1991 when it was separately established. The report lists its aims, objectives and corporate priorities. These include, particularly, encouraging not only the testing of drugs which is obviously part of its responsibilities, but also enhancing the climate in this country where drugs in sport are regarded as—`unfavourable' is probably a useful word—totally unacceptable.

In fact, the Agency quite clearly continues the work of the so-called Black Report handed down by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and Arts drugs in sport inquiry. I believe my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne, as a member of that committee of inquiry, will have some words to say about that shortly. This Agency continues to foster the climate of attitude that was created by that report.

I think there would be no disagreement now in this country that the use of drugs in sport is cheating. While it is still clear that it continues in some places, the testing has meant that more and more people are aware that they are likely to get caught if they do not change their attitudes. I think there is a community perception and awareness that using drugs in sport is cheating.

On page 16 of the annual report there is reference to a caffeine study and the research work being done by the Australian Sports Drug Agency, jointly funded with the Australian Sports Commission, to investigate the pharmacokinectics of caffeine ingestion and elimination. This is of particular relevance because of an inquiry that is currently being conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, of which I am Chair. That Committee should be reporting within the next couple of weeks.

The question of caffeine has certainly taxed our minds and those of many others besides. I am very pleased to see reference in the report to the fact that considerable research has already been done. The results of the study are not available, at least they were not at the time of printing. Hopefully, we will get those very soon. Quite clearly, while there are significant consequences for people who are found to have caffeine levels above the levels regarded as prescribed levels, there is a very great difference from individual to individual about how those levels might be reached. Given the seriousness of the consequences, it is very important that we endorse this part of the report that looks at adequate research so that we can make better decisions.

I am also interested to note that the Agency undertook a literature review based research study looking at the effects of marijuana which was found, we understand, when testing some sports people in this country. It is very interesting to note that the report says that the literature shows that the effect of marijuana was to reduce rather than enhance sports performance. I would have thought it was necessary for the Agency to give us clear definitions of why drugs are proscribed. If they are to be proscribed because of performance enhancement, then there will be a need for a rethink in the area of marijuana. If we want to proscribe them because of ethical decisions, moral values or something of that sort, that can be done, but that needs to be distinguished from whether they are performance enhancing. If the Sports Drug Agency is focusing on a rethink as to whether marijuana is performance enhancing, an elaboration of the debate about whether marijuana belongs on that list should be made available to the full community.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Baume observed, we will be dealing with amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency legislation which will give us a proper opportunity to ventilate some of the matters that need to be ventilated. We ought to record that the Australian Sports Drug Agency is now perhaps the leader in the world in the contributions it makes under its terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: I observe that this year, of those Australian athletes who were tested for drugs, 71 were found to be cheats. I note that the self-confessed cheat, Martin Vinnicombe, is now taking action in the Federal Court of New South Wales, under restraint of trade, as I recall, against the Australian Sports Drug Agency for what appears to be a technicality. I do not want to comment on the litigation, of course, other than to say that it involves the Australian Professional Cycling Association, an association that will not have access to large funding. I hope that the penalty the Association has imposed on Mr Vinnicombe is not compromised because of its financial inability to contest the litigation in the courts. I hope the Government will give thought, in view of the circumstances, to seeing that that body has appropriate funding.

I also note that in the last 12 months three German athletes have been banned, together with the coach of one of those athletes, for allegedly being involved in what is described as urine substitution. One of the athletes was the winner of the 100 metres women's championship at the recent competition. It would appear on the evidence thus far available which has lead to their four-year bans that they were banned because it is alleged that their urine was substituted for somebody else's for testing purposes. In fact, the same person's urine was used on each occasion.

There are now very serious penalties for this type of action. I well recall the uproar that I caused when I raised the issue of Jane Fleming and an official of Australia being involved in exactly the same thing. This case involving the German athletes shows that this situation is not unique and it shows that the world has a very strong view which is illustrated by the penalties that were imposed.

The report shows us that there is still a high use of anabolic steroids and, while it is not shown, I suspect that there is a use of human growth hormones. While I do not want to make any quantitative judgments about it at the moment, I think evidence will prevail in due course that will show that there is an active trade in the use of these drugs in Australia. There have been detections at the customs barrier of illegal importations of both veterinary and human growth hormones for improper purposes, and the importation of anabolic steroids for improper purposes.

I am sure that evidence will show that it is a flourishing trade. I am sure it will show that the industry of peddling these drugs is rife in Australia.
