While a body such as the Australian Sports Drug Agency is capable of testing a wide range of athletes, at the end of the day there are finite resources and it is inevitable that there will be those cheats who will not be detected. One can only hope that the level of resources presently available to the Agency is maintained.

I conclude by congratulating the Agency on the level of its competence, skill, integrity and ability and the reputation which it has internationally for the activities it carries out under the references given to it by the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I observe that this is another report that has taken a long time to come into the Senate. In fact, the report was signed by Mr Harris, the Chairman, on 6 December 1991, so obviously it could not have had time to be printed and placed here before we rose on 21 December 1991.

PARA.TAB: I shall make a couple of points and then seek leave to continue my remarks. This is an important report which should be considered at some length by the Senate. In particular, I draw attention to the fact that the Australian Sports Foundation, which was established to generate private sector donations and support for sport through the Australian Sports Commission, is in a sense not doing as well as one would hope in view of the taxation benefits available. I hope that in the future, particularly under a coalition government, far greater attention will be paid to this important element of sports funding. In the latest annual report we see that income derived by the Foundation comprised only $4.5m compared with $8.8m the previous year. I understand that to an extent that diminution was because of the special boost the Sports Foundation got as a result of the unsuccessful bid by Melbourne to win the Olympic Games. A lot of money was raised specifically for that purpose.

Apart from all that, we see that funds raised through the Foundation to assist national sporting organisations still fell by something like $900,000 last financial year, from the 1989-90 level of $3.12m to $2.25m. As I said, I hope that greater effort and concentration can be made in the future and more energy utilised in encouraging, through the tax system, further and better assistance to sport.

There is no doubt that the GST package—the Fightback package—will provide significant benefits to many sporting organisations. As the Senate knows, at the moment there is a 20 per cent sales tax on all sporting equipment. Not only will sporting clubs receive the benefit of that tax being wiped out under the Fightback package; all sports organisations will be able to get a full refund of the GST of 15 per cent payable on sporting equipment because they will be in the `business' of providing sporting facilities. Therefore, all payments for such sporting equipment will be fully deductible. That is an important matter. That applies to the GST or any other taxes on equipment used, for example, for mowing wickets, for preparing pitches and so on. This would be a significant reduction in the costs of the sporting organisations.

I think a lot of sports bodies have wrongly assumed that they will somehow be disadvantaged by the Fightback package. Looking at the broad impact of the package, particularly the reduction of fuel costs and so on, there is no doubt that sporting clubs will be significantly advantaged by the introduction of the Fightback package. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendment made by the Senate to the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill 1991.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 18 of 1991-92, efficiency audit, entitled Management of Australian purchases under the United States Foreign Military Sales Program (FMS).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The efficiency audit was carried out by the National Audit Office in relation to the Department of Defence and its management of Australian purchases under the United States foreign military sales program.

PARA.TAB: The efficiency audit is very important. It is a very disturbing report. This program is very large indeed. It relates to purchases by the Australian Government of military supplies from the United States Government, through the United States foreign military sales program, which was set up 20-odd years ago to assist allies of the United States such as Australia in obtaining equipment made in the United States under programs where the United States is procuring this equipment. Allies such as ourselves have been able to acquire this equipment as part of production runs for the purchase of the same equipment by the United States. There is a great benefit for Australia in that program and, no doubt, a benefit for the American manufacturers, who obtain larger orders and their production runs are therefore greater and more efficient.

The program that is being investigated by the Auditor-General's Office reveals that, as at 31 December 1990, the programs still being considered had a value of over $6 billion. There were outstanding payments under the program of over $1 billion. This is a very large program which has been administered within the Department of Defence. Yet the report shows that there is no central authority established within the Department of Defence to provide guidance, general control and related matters associated with such a large purchasing program as the one in question.

The report notes a lack of adequate policies for a proper information system to be available for the purpose of financial management. It also notes that there are large payments on account with respect to many of these purchases and that the final payments are resolved by the assessment of the equipment received by Australia. Adjustments have to be made. The report notes that there have been significant refunds of surplus advance payments and difficulties in determining the value of supplies received and so on. So there is revealed major financial mismanagement on the part of the Department of Defence.

Just by way of example, I refer to one section of the report which reveals that the Audit Office carried out I suppose a random survey of 66 cases. The Audit Office sought detailed information from case managers in respect of this sample of 66 current cases. In 13 of these cases, the values of supplies received by Australia were less than the values of supplies shown in the United States quarterly billing statements as having been delivered. They are really quite extraordinary discrepancies. But in nine cases it was found that the Department of Defence had no record of the values of supplies received by Australia at all. So obviously there is a large degree of inadequate record-keeping in relation to these, albeit, very large programs. The record-keeping by the Department and the financial management generally of this program were found to be severely wanting.

This, unfortunately, is not by any means the first time that there have been problems with procurement by the Department of Defence and failings in management by the Department with respect to a number of these programs. We are familiar, of course, with the very severe cost blow-outs in Department of Defence procurement programs. It must be a very severe worry that at the moment the Department has procurement programs of something like $27 billion—that is, procurement not just relating to foreign military sales but to other sources. Fortunately these days procurement is also carried out in Australia. But where there are such large procurement programs being undertaken by the Department of Defence, it is very alarming indeed to get reports like this which throw very great doubt upon the quality of the financial management in the Department.

Only a week or so ago we read that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) made a statement in which he admitted that the Department was having to look at options to make further savings in the combat side of defence. Presumably, there is to be some shortfall in the Navy's budget for the current year. The Navy's activities are going to have to be tightened—possibly by the mothballing of some of its warships, including a new frigate. Whether that is going to occur or not is, according to the Minister, not decided. But the fact that it is having to be considered shows how tight the defence budget is and the way in which mismanagement of procurement programs of this size can have such a very severe effect on the combat capability of our Defence Force.

The Opposition has been pointing out the need for much greater savings and efficiency in the management of the Department of Defence, not just at Russell Hill in Canberra but generally. Here, again, we have another example of where very great losses could be sustained as a result of mismanagement of procurement programs. I know there is no finding that there have actually been losses in this case, but the concern is that that could easily happen when we have such lax procedures and such inadequate management structures. One must be left with very great concern about the procurement program generally. As I have said, we must be particularly concerned when we are looking at the present programs, which amount to something like $27 billion.

Last year, I had occasion to draw attention to these problems. I learnt that, in fact, the Industry Commission had suggested to the Government that it should be given a reference to consider the whole of the procurement policy and the management of procurement by the Defence Force. To my surprise, the Government rejected that proposal from the Industry Commission—a very highly skilled external review body which now possesses a very high reputation for providing an examination of government activities of one sort or another.

It seems to me—and I say this again—that this whole procurement program of the Department of Defence is crying out for a review by such a body as the Industry Commission. The report that we have now received and which has been tabled in the Senate is a very good example of why an external review of that kind of that whole program is so urgently required. Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS (TASMANIA) REGULATIONS AND POLITICAL BROADCASTS (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) REGULATIONS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the luncheon adjournment—
—Before the luncheon adjournment.

—On the rising for lunch, I was just finishing my speech. I am delighted to see the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, here because he had not been here following the debate on the regulations. Indeed, he had sent in Senator Richardson to take the fire in his place. I am also delighted to see him because I am about to make reference to the complete shambles that he created in tabling these regulations and in seeking their proclamation.

PARA.TAB: I go very briefly through what occurred. The first proclamation was on 1 January 1992. On that day, part II of the Political

SPEECH.PARA: Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act was to commence. It was signed by the Governor-General on 19 December 1991. The proclamation is probably void, as the Minister will acknowledge—it just had no effect—because it was not published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette until 2 January. That was contrary to section 17J of the Acts Interpretation Act.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought it pretty elementary that the Minister and his Department would realise that unless the proclamation and the gazetting occurred on the same day the whole thing lacked any legality. They did realise this and attempted to fix it. We therefore had a second proclamation on 3 January as the date of commencement for part II of the Act. It was signed and published in the Gazette on that day. That was the first mix-up.

The second mix-up occurred when two sets of regulations under the Act relating to Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory were made on 19 December 1991 and gazetted on that day. They were tabled in the Senate on the same day and were subject to a motion of disallowance by us, which was moved by leave. There was debate and the matter was finally adjourned.

A further set of regulations relating to New South Wales were made on 23 December and published in the Gazette on 3 January. These regulations were never tabled. Why was there a mess up? Why were they not tabled?

The first two sets of regulations were expressed to commence on 1 January 1992. The regulations could not commence on that date because of the problem with the first proclamation. As the Minister well knows, other errors occurred in the set of regulations relating to New South Wales. All these problems having been realised, all three sets of regulations were repealed. So the Minister made a dreadful mess of all three sets of regulations. When this was brought to his attention, they were all repealed and substitute regulations were made on 3 January 1992 and published in the Gazette of the same day.

These regulations were all illegal. The first two sets were illegal because they were contrary to section 48B of the Acts Interpretation Act, which prohibits the remaking of regulations that are the subject of an unresolved disallowance motion, and the third set was illegal because it violated section 48A of the Acts Interpretation Act, which prohibits the making of regulations before they have been tabled.

When these problems were realised, further sets of regulations were made and published in the Gazette on 10 January. Those people really listening to this debate must begin to wonder what on earth the Government, the Department and the Minister could have been on about over those months from December to January. In the meantime, we had elections coming up in New South Wales where there was a by-election, in Tasmania where there was a State election, and in the ACT where there was a Territory election.

The implication of all this mucking about must be seen by the Minister as at least embarrassing to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, which at this stage was trying valiantly to make some decisions. But it was also embarrassing to the Commission. The events could not help but have been embarrassing to it.

As has already been stated, a number of problems have arisen from that course of events. One member in the ACT who says it was all illegal anyway and that he was not given the right of advertising and publication of his programs and policies is saying that he will sue and take the matter to the High Court. There is also a challenge from the various States, as well as some of the television stations that were deprived of income.

Today we have been debating the inconsistencies and the tremendous problems that this side of the chamber sees in relation to democracy Labor style. We have pointed out time and time again that when those opposite talk of democracy and this piece of legislation they talk only about the democracy of the three major parties—Labor, Liberal and the Australian Democrats.

Senator Schacht made claims today that we were all very happy about it in Tasmania. He quoted Bob Lister, our General Director back home, and Michael Hodgman as saying how happy they were about it. Mr Lister was only answering questions in relation to our Party. Very rightly, he said that we were happy with the results. He was not asked to answer on behalf of the Independents of that State. I pointed out earlier—and the Minister was not here then so he might be interested—that the people who had free air time were Labor, Liberal, the Greens and one Independent out of the 10 Independents who had to put their names in a hat to see who would get that additional free time. An Advance Tasmania group which, just because it had not been given the required amount of time to register as a party, remained a group. But it had two candidates in every electorate.

The names of its members were not drawn out of the hat; only one Independent, a Mr Jamieson from the west coast, was drawn out of the hat. He got 10 minutes free time. Every other Independent, including those in the Advance Tasmania group, were denied free time. That is democracy Labor style and that is democracy Australian Democrat style. They joined to put this legislation through.

It is not democracy Liberal style, although it suited us and we did so well in our State that Labor got only 29 per cent of the vote. We did very well and we were perfectly happy with our result. But many of us, including me, are furious on behalf of those Independents who did not stand a chance. Because of Labor's type of democracy they were denied any free time, any advertising, on radio or television and they did not stand a chance of putting their policy and their views to the Tasmanian public.

I would like to have an acknowledgment from the Minister that he thinks this is all right, that this is what the Labor Party intended in its legislation. If he does not give me that acknowledgment, then I presume he is not too happy about it but is thoroughly ashamed about it. I doubt whether I will get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will you do if you don't get it? You'll huff and puff a bit more.
—Maybe that would indicate that the Government is prepared to amend the legislation, because the Government cannot possibly claim that that is a true democratic system.
—Heavens above! We sat up all night discussing it.

—Senator West says, `Yes, it is'. I acknowledge it is democracy Labor style. There is another occurrence of that. Senator Tate, who just faced selection, was dumped from No. 1 position down to No. 4 position. That is true democracy Labor style. The Tasmanian Labor Party is allowed to select its senators in order only if they do the right thing. If they do not do the right thing, according to the executive, the executive will step in and change it. This is the second time that Senator Tate has been dropped down and the second time that the executive has had to step in. The Labor Party has a good democratic system. But then I do not really believe that we on this side of the House ever thought the Labor Party knew a thing about democracy.

PARA.TAB: I have not anything else to say on this Bill. I just point out the complete shemozzle that the Minister has caused in these regulations. As my time has expired, I shall take my seat.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The redebate of this issue using this means is, I think, a disgraceful abuse of the Senate and sits uneasily on the shoulders of people who sing the praises of the Senate system and its proper use. The Opposition is having a second go. Having lost the argument during the debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, it is now attempting to disallow the regulations. The irony is that the regulations it is trying to disallow relate specifically to elections in Tasmania and the ACT, both of which have been held. So what the Opposition is doing, in fact, is attempting to disallow regulations which no longer have application. I think that makes the process a nonsense and a disgraceful waste of the Senate's time. But it does give the Opposition an opportunity, I guess, to rabbit on with the same posed, self-righteous fervour which it applied during the debate on the Bill and which makes no more sense now than it did then.

PARA.TAB: In all of this the Opposition has consistently failed to concede the central problem from which the ad ban and the accompanying disclosure provisions arise. The Bill arose out of the widespread concerns, not only in Australia but also in many comparable countries around the world, about the possibility of the corruption of the political process as a result of the twin problems of, on the one hand, the rapidly rising costs of political advertising, in particular television advertising, and, on the other, the resultant pressure placed on political parties in a highly competitive environment, in which the stakes are inevitably high, to raise the increasingly large budgets to fund such campaigns.

The Opposition has consistently chosen to ignore expressions of concern, for example, by the various inquiries set up to examine this very issue. I have referred in previous debates to comments from the Fitzgerald inquiry, from the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales, from the Carter Royal Commission in Tasmania, and from the WA Inc Royal Commission looking into these matters in Western Australia. All three of the completed inquiries—that is, all of those inquiries except the Western Australian one—have expressed specific and strongly worded concerns about the need for regulation of political fundraising in the light of the increasing costs of campaigning. In Western Australia there is now a general inquiry, which is running concurrently with the individual inquiries, which is looking at that very same thing and is bound to come up with some recommendations that I believe will be similar to those of other inquiries.
Perhaps it is best expressed by Commissioner Roden—and I will not go into all the quotations which I have given before—from the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales who said:

SPEECH.PARA: So long as substantial donations can be made to political parties or candidates without disclosure, they can be used to purchase influence. The law that allows secret political donations, creates conditions conducive to corrupt conduct.

As increasingly large sums of money become necessary for successful political campaigns the problem will grow. It must be faced and dealt with firmly and openly. To allow large secret donations to political parties or candidates is but one step removed from allowing secret deals with political parties or candidates.
He went on to say:

The alternative to compulsory public disclosure, I believe, is an unacceptable risk that through financial necessity influence with government (of any political colour) will be a purchasable commodity.
I think that aptly sums up the link between the question of the increasing cost of running campaigns and the pressure that is put on political parties in trying to meet those costs.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has also consistently refused to acknowledge overseas experience, which demonstrates the direction in which the Australian political process could go if we do not face the problem boldly and creatively. I have already referred to the Recruit scandal in Japan, which has rocked, and continues to rock, the very foundations of that society at the highest levels, and the Watergate scandal in the USA, in which systematic corruption of the political process was uncovered at the very highest levels of that society too. We cannot simply assume that that sort of thing will not happen here. There are early indications that it might have happened here, particularly in the honourable senator's State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the Western Australian Labor Party?

—I speak particularly about Senator Macdonald's State, where the real evidence is. Yet the Opposition fails to pay any attention to the vigorous debate that is currently under way in the United States to address problems uncovered by Watergate, problems which have been inadequately addressed by previous attempts at regulation but which are now again the subject of lively debate because of that.

PARA.TAB: It is rather like the movement towards a republic in Australia; the Opposition just cannot cope with change. There is an inexorable movement towards a republic in this country, just as there is an inexorable movement towards a cleaner political system in this country. Yet the Opposition always finds itself in the position of having to oppose. Canute-like, it is pushing back the inexorable waves of time, but it fails, inevitably, because change does occur despite the Opposition's conservative posture.

The Government has introduced, with the support of the Democrats, a two-pronged approach to a problem which is widely acknowledged but studiously ignored by the Opposition. On the one hand it has introduced full disclosure of all political donations, disclosure of a kind which cannot be avoided, as political parties of all persuasions have done, and, secondly, it has introduced a ban on paid political advertising for the period from the issuing of the writs to election day and replaced this with the mandatory provision by TV networks of a limited number of two-minute information slots run concurrently on all stations.

In all of this it is interesting that the Opposition has failed to give anything but hedged and contingent support to the concept of disclosure. It has twisted and turned and unearthed every furphy possible to try to avoid disclosing who gives it money. Despite the fact that previous speakers have said that they would have been in favour of disclosure, they showed no signs of this during the debate. They hedged and attached contingencies to it. They showed paranoia about one set of donors, completely ignoring another set of donors. When there was some attempt to get an amendment that might suit both parties, the Opposition would not be part of that in any case.

Yet the question of disclosure is widely seen as the crux of any attempts to guarantee the integrity of the political system. I would like to quote briefly from a submission that I have made to the Royal Commission in Western Australia in its general inquiry into this whole area. In the conclusion to a submission that I have made, I say the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The question of fund raising for political parties is a vexed one and one which goes to the heart of any assessment of the integrity of the political system. The public, understandably, cannot have confidence in a system in which they believe that money buys influence and that elected representatives lack independence because of their need to pander to wealthy donors.

We have consistently supported full disclosure; we have consistently supported the sorts of changes to the electoral system which make it fairer and which the Opposition has opposed consistently over the years. I went on to say:

Most politicians and party officials from all political persuasions, involved in party fund raising, approach the task, in my experience, honestly and with due propriety. Most apply clear caveats to donations, indicating to the donors that they can expect no favours in return for their support. Yet despite their honest intentions they are, I believe, unwittingly compromised by the very process of which they are a part.

Forced to raise funds from the corporate sector, which is now by far the largest source of funds for the major parties, they are tacitly a part of a system in which at least some of the participants believe that they are trading in patronage and influence. Tony Eggleton, the well respected former National Director of the Liberal Party admitted in an interview with Michelle Grattan of the Melbourne Age that when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister, he was told when Liberal Party donors wanted to see him, and that this would—
and I quote him—
"get them in the door marginally more quickly."

Such commitments in return for donations are at the not altogether benign end of a continuum of influence peddling. Of similar benignity is the not uncommon status seeking which motivates some donors. At the other, less benign end of the continuum are those who believe that they are, through their donations, directly purchasing patronage, favour or privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what the unions do.
—Let's go fishing.
—Do not talk nonsense. I continued as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: There are, I believe, few major donors who do not expect to gain some personal advantage as a result of their donations or who, conversely, hope to avoid by their willingness to donate, some perceived disadvantage at the hands of government, the parliament or the party in question.
I concluded:

There is growing concern that the political process in Australia is following patterns set in the USA or Japan—systems characterized by some observers as endemically corrupt. Something must be done to halt this trend and to defend the historical integrity of our political system.

I went on to recommend to that Commission that it express support for the full disclosure of all political donations, whatever their source or purpose; a systematic public funding for political parties; and realistic initiatives to limit the impact of the rapidly increasing costs of political campaigning—all of which have been attempted by this Government and most of which, in fact, have now been implemented.

PARA.TAB: It is also interesting that the Opposition has consistently ignored the fact that there is nothing unusual about banning political advertising. In fact, it can be argued that Australia, with its previous lack of regulation, was the odd country out. Such regulation is the norm in comparable countries overseas—many countries which Opposition members would be very happy to associate themselves with. Of the 19 countries studied by the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, first of all, and then by the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures in more detail, only four permit paid political advertising and one of these, Canada, limits it to the campaign period. So countries like England, France, Sweden, Austria, Italy, Norway and Denmark—none of which one would call countries that are undemocratic or countries that have applied draconian laws—all apply bans of various sorts to advertising.

Finally, the advertising ban, where it has been applied, has been successful. I think all the indications of the limited experience that we have had now in Tasmania and the ACT and the by-election in The Entrance in New South Wales have lent support to that argument. It has reduced expenditure; it has reduced it by as much as a claimed 50 per cent in Tasmania. It has reduced expenditure in all of the elections that I have just referred to. It has not diminished, as many claimed it would, the awareness of elections, as has already been pointed out in some detail by Senator Faulkner. The voting turnout went up in Tasmania and the ACT and was at a remarkably high level in The Entrance for a by-election held at the very difficult time that it was.

There is no evidence either that the money that would have been spent on television was spent in other areas, which the Opposition has consistently claimed, otherwise there simply would not have been the 50 per cent reduced expenditure already claimed. I think the Opposition would find that that would be the same for its own political party. It is interesting in that regard that I did not notice the Opposition refusing to take the advantages of free air time, or offering the networks that it is so very worried about the money to make up for the free time that it was getting.

On the anecdotal evidence, there seems to have been a great deal of success and the public seems to have accepted the whole thing remarkably well. Most people, it seems, are much happier with the idea of a two-minute head and shoulder substantial advertisement than statements made in 60 or 30 seconds which tend to be glitzy, superficial and often misleading, and seldom much to do with the substance of an election.
Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! Senators on my left, I cannot hear the senator speaking. A modicum of silence, please.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot hear myself, nor can I actually hear the interjections, which is some benefit. Members of the Opposition, it seems to me, seem excessively concerned with revenue lost for the networks and yet, as I have said, it is interesting that they were quite willing to take the free time without offering anything in return for it.

PARA.TAB: I do not share their concern for the networks which took us to the cleaners consistently—both of the major parties anyway. Any party which spent large on television advertising was taken to the cleaners by networks consistently at a time when they knew they had us over a barrel. We had to run an election campaign, and they had the right to charge us almost what they wanted—and they did. I have no concerns about the networks as far as that is concerned.

The Act, built upon previous reforms, has gone a long way towards cleaning up the Australian political system and avoiding the sorts of excesses that are all too common overseas and the growing concern that we might be going in the same direction here. I believe it is time the Opposition stopped bleating and misusing the time of the Senate in extending this debate beyond its useful life, and accepted the legislation just as it has been prepared to accept the free time without paying any additional money for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the last time I spoke on this particular Bill was at a quarter to seven in the morning after we had been sitting all night. I remember following a whole host of speakers and thinking to myself, `What can I say that is different?'.
—Nothing.

—I did. I actually mentioned local government, which no-one else had mentioned. In fact, these regulations that we are disallowing—these shonky regulations that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has made so many mistakes on—really do not change my view as to what could happen to local government and what in fact did happen in the Tasmanian election.

PARA.TAB: I intended to be reasonably short. I only wanted to bring in a few observations because I happened to be in Tasmania during the election. However, Senator Beahan came in and got stuck into us on this side and said that we had been repeating all the stuff we had been talking about, but then turned around and went on to talk about disclosure. He knows as well as everybody else that Dr John Hewson and our Party—the coalition—are on record as saying that we will debate disclosure. We are in favour of full disclosure. We wanted to debate the Bill separately, but the Government would not do that. It wanted to push the whole lot through in one hit and that is one of the reasons we opposed it, as everybody remembers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was your good excuse to oppose it.

—Rubbish. I had a laugh when Senator Beahan made the point about other countries having ad bans; he told us how good they were and how they stopped corruption. It brought to mind a Japanese businessman whom I was talking to only a couple of days ago. I mentioned the problem in Japan of corruption which has embarrassed the Prime Minister so much and which has meant the dismissal of the Japanese member for Hakodati. I cannot pronounce the member's name. When one talks about corruption, it makes Burkegate look like a Sunday school picnic. The corruption involved in this case involved a ballpark that was to cost something like $14 billion and the pay off figure was $40m. That is not a bad little figure to be picking up. I guess there would be a few people around here having second thoughts about that.

PARA.TAB: The political ads ban had many people in Tasmania saying, `It was nice not to be seeing people on TV', but then they had the free stuff. One of them made the comment to me, `It does not look as professional as other ads I have seen.' As Senator Walters and everybody else has pointed out, there is no doubt that it has disadvantaged the Independents and those candidates who were standing for the first time. They had three weeks to get their profiles up.

Premier Field is quoted as saying today in the Australian that Labor has won only one Tasmanian seat in the last 17 years and that was the seat of Denison in the Federal Parliament. Its vote dropped from 54.3 per cent in 1979 to 28.9 per cent at this month's election. I bet that Premier Field would have loved to have been able to put some ads on and to have quoted from all the different economic sources which pointed out what a great job he had done in trying to turn the economy around in Tasmania. He would have loved to have done that but, unfortunately, he did not have a way of doing it. If he had been able to advertise some of the more positive things he has achieved, he might have got a few more votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might have got 30 per cent.

—He might even have got 32 per cent. As I said, the ban affected those people who stood in the election for the first time. One only has to look at the results. Most of the sitting members were re-elected. Unfortunately for some, Mr Holgate disappeared, and we had a few new Liberal candidates elected, but most of them had stood before and did have some profile. One candidate from Franklin in particular that I am aware of—one talks about going around knocking on doors—never stopped working from the start. He doorknocked all the Labor areas. I expected him to get in, but he failed. I believe that the only reason he failed was that he did not have the opportunity to put his voice over the airways, particularly on radio.

PARA.TAB: One of the concerns that came out of the election was that, because of the free advertising, the Government was in a position to use the news bulletins to its advantage. Even the other major party that is now in power—our side of politics—used the news bulletins to its advantage but, unfortunately, none of the Independents or anybody else, unless they could come up with some huge political stunt, could get any advertising or any profile at all.

As a result, we saw on the television all sorts of things being announced down there such as the steel mill scheme that I have mentioned today. Nothing had been happening in the election campaign and then all of a sudden we had this great steel mill proposal into which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the Government was to put half a million dollars. We also had the proposal that we were to have a new source of energy from a gas field. Just like the gas and just like the arguments of the Government, as soon as the election was finished, what happened? Our $500,000 promise from the Prime Minister evaporated and so did the gas. The only reason it was done was to get some free time on television, and that was denied to all those battling independent candidates who should have an equal chance.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those were the sorts of concerns that the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, raised.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a laugh this morning when I heard Senator Kernot from the Australian Democrats say that she did not care what the voters thought anyway. Then she wanted to say that she was very pleased about the—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! Could senators to the right and the left give Senator Calvert a go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is worth listening to anyway, but I want to put my few words forward if I can. I had to laugh this morning when Senator Kernot said she was interested in the democratic principle of the whole thing. I think she should talk to Hank Petrusma down in Tasmania. Hank Petrusma was a sitting member with a very high profile in the Hobart area. He thought he was doing the right thing for Tasmania and put forward the Advance Tasmania group. It had very good candidates. In fact, I think my colleagues would agree that some of the candidates it had standing in Braddon and Bass would have been very good candidates for Labor or the Democrats, or ourselves for that matter. They were very good candidates.
—Don't get carried away.

—Come on, some of those guys would have been pretty good in Senator Bell's sort of politics. They achieved less than about 2 per cent of the vote—all because they were well known in their own area but could not promote themselves because they were disallowed. The other thing that came through in this election that really worries me is the huge amount of power that was put in the hands of the—
—How did they get on before television?
—They had radio.
—We had television in 1990.
—What about radio?
—I am talking about before then.
—Do you think I could join in the conversation around here?
—I take your point, Senator Calvert. Honourable senators should allow Senator Calvert to continue. But he should make his points through the Chair.

—The major point I am trying to make is that in the final analysis what really concerned me was that the net effect of the regulations and the ban was to place, in my opinion anyway, a huge amount of power in the hands of the print media. If an example is wanted of that, on the day before the election when there was still a big undecided vote out there, the Mercury put out on its front page results that a news poll had produced saying that the Liberals were going to bolt in, which in the event they did. But there was some thought around that that may have engendered people to get on the winning band wagon. People like backing winners and that may have influenced that undecided vote. Conversely, of course, it may have gone the other way.

PARA.TAB: On top of that, an editorial appeared in the paper that day—rightly or wrongly—that was very biased towards the Labor Party. We had the two chief political writers virtually imploring the public to vote for the Labor Party. In fact, that did not happen, but the point I am trying to make is that these people in the media bent over backwards to try to influence the voters one way or the other. I do not believe that would have happened if the candidates had been able to put forward their points of view on radio or television. I have to correct a couple of things that I put forward this morning. Senator Faulkner—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did a fine speech.

—Along with a few interjections. He made the point, as did Senator Schacht, that Bob Lister—I think Senator Walters corrected this—in an interview said, `any disadvantage to any particular party'. I know for a fact that he was talking about the two major parties: the Labor Party and the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: Somebody commented—I think it was Senator Faulkner again—that Michael Hodgman, the current Speaker of the House of Assembly in Tasmania, made the point that it did not disadvantage things too much. I can tell Senator Faulkner that I was in the company of Michael Hodgman on at least two occasions at public functions when he made the point very strongly that, regardless of the results, it was an erosion of human rights that people were not able to put forward their points of view on radio and television.

I can also tell Senator Faulkner that the reason there was a huge turnout of voters in Tasmania was not because there was an ad ban, it was because the voting public of Tasmania had been waiting for 2 1/2 years to put a majority government, of whatever flavour, back in power. They had enough of the Green-Labor experience. Let us face it, there was only one real issue in that election: stability of government.

When we have a political situation in a State or even in the nation where issues and policies have to be debated, I wonder just how the people are going to find out the points of view and how candidates are going to correct incorrect statements that have been made either in the Parliament or in unpaid ads? We had evidence only yesterday in the House of Representatives of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, making some false statements about the Fightback package. If that happens during an election campaign, when candidates cannot pay for ads and put their points of view, how are these things going to be corrected? How is the opportunity going to be given to political parties or independents to correct those statements? The Minister should look at some of the effects of the exercise in Tasmania. I believe that, further down the track, he will rue the day he pushed this shonky Bill through the Senate. I hope that when we return to government we will be in a position to give people the right to say what they want to say, where they want to say it, and to use whatever medium they care to use.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be intrigued to hear the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) indicate to us just which set of regulations he thinks applied to the three elections that have been mentioned this evening: the Tasmanian and ACT elections and the New South Wales by-election. There are three sets of regulations, and no-one seemed to be able to indicate to me just which regulations the Minister or the ABT think they are working on. I would like the Minister to tell me which of the regulations they are using.

PARA.TAB: The Government introduced the first set of regulations but could not get the numbers right. This Minister is so incompetent that he could not even get the headings in the sections of the Act correct. That was the first mistake this Minister made. Then he and his officers messed up the day on which it should have been proclaimed. They published this first set of regulations but realised, or thought they realised, that they had proclaimed the regulations before the Act had been proclaimed. So in a series of brilliant manoeuvres, they decided to introduce regulations set No. 2.

Regulations set No. 2 was done supposedly on the right day, 3 January, but the Minister and his officers did not realise that there was a provision in the Acts Interpretations Act saying that, if there were unresolved notices of disallowance in relation to the first set—which there were—the second set could not be used. So they said, `Well, obviously we cannot use this second set'. They then went to the third set, which they got around to on 10 January, and they thought, `Seeing that the second set is not right, we will just amend the first set. That way we do not have to worry about that rule that you cannot deal with them while there is an unresolved disallowance motion on. We will bring in some amendments—not new regulations.' They thought they were going to amend the first set of regulations by this third set of regulations.

That is all very well, except that they did not look carefully enough at the second set of regulations. If the Minister looks at the second set of regulations he will realise that most of the provisions contain matters that are substantially the same as in the first set, therefore they could not be dealt with. But the Minister did not realise that he had a final paragraph in the second set of regulations which said that the statutory rules introduced previously were repealed. That was not the same as the previous regulations that did not apply.

What the Minister is left with in the Tasmanian case, if I might use that as an example, is 14 regulations in the second set, which were substantially the same as the first set and therefore could not apply. But the regulation is not substantially the same as the first set and so it does apply. Does the Minister know what it says? It says that the regulations he introduced on 3 January—one to 14—are repealed. Does the Minister realise where that has left him? He cannot use the second set of regulations. The third set of regulations, which he thought were good, are only amendments to the first set, which he has repealed by the second set. That leaves the Minister with no regulations at all.

I will tell the Minister what it will do to him and to the Government. They tell me the Minister used to be a lawyer. Does he think someone might sue for damages? Does he think that might be a possibility? Some of these people who have been wronged, to their monetary detriment, by abiding by these regulations, which he said were right and which the ABT has acted upon, are going to be out of pocket. Does he think they are just going to walk away and say, `That is bad luck.'? Of course they are not. They are going to sue the Government or the ABT of someone for a lot of money. I know that the Government's Budget deficit is hopeless at the moment—$9 billion overdrawn. How is it going to be when these people get to it?

The Minister has no regulations at all. He is going to be looking down the barrel of a very substantial damages case, and rightly so. I just hope it comes against him personally because it may make him more careful in the future. There is no need for the Minister to leave the chamber. I am sorry if I have offended him, if he cannot take it, if he has to leave when the hopelessness of his administration of this Act is pointed out to him. I am sorry that has made him leave—

TALK.START.PARA: —Running.

—Yes, running. They are things that should be pointed out to the Minister because he has one unholy mess in front of him on this matter. It is all because he would rush these things through in such an undemocratic fashion just before the end of the last year. He was not prepared to allow people to look at them. He was not prepared to allow people to go through them and work out what they were about. He insisted that they be rammed through before there was any proper or considered opinion and debate on it. He has an absolute and unholy shambles. He will wear it, and he deserves to wear it.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Bolkus—if he is in earshot, having scurried out—what I wanted to put to him to his face, and that is the disgraceful, despicable and cowardly attack he made upon officers of this chamber in his speech. It is typical of the Labor Party and the people on the front bench to attack people who cannot respond and who do not have the right to respond. That is what Senator Bolkus embarked upon today—a despicable and cowardly attack. He accused officers of this Senate of giving us advice. As I understand it, that is what they are here to do—to give all senators impartial advice—and that is what they do.

I did not notice Senator Bolkus being too concerned about the quality of the advice during that debate when he and his advisers were continuously seeking the advice of the Clerk. It was good enough then, when the Clerk was advising the Minister on how to try to get this stupid and irresponsible Bill through this chamber—they were then well prepared to seek the advice of the Clerk—but when the Clerk gives us advice that is apparently not convenient to the Government's course of action, suddenly that is wrong, and Senator Bolkus embarks upon this despicable and cowardly attack.

Because the Clerk happens to give independent, impartial advice which is not convenient to the Government, therefore, it is wrong. But when the Clerk gives advice to the Minister to help him get his shambles through this chamber, it is okay. The hypocrisy is almost as unbearable as the despicable and cowardly attack. Those opposite should have a little more respect for the institutions of Parliament and not just criticise people because they happen to give advice that does not suit the political agenda of this Government. That is quite despicable.

I could not follow some of the arguments propagated by Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht in particular. I stopped listening after them. If the rest of the speakers were going to give out the drivel that Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht did, then they would not have been worthwhile listening to. Senator Bolkus tried to use the line that, because advertising costs a lot of money, it engenders corruption and, therefore, has to be banned. But he did not refer to the ACT Labor Party advertising on the electronic media through Sky Channel on videos around the clubs, and he did not talk about it using the movie houses to advertise.

I challenge Senator Bolkus to answer this: did he give advice to the ACT Labor Party on what it could do? I challenge Senator Bolkus to tell this Senate just what he told the ACT Labor Party it could do—whether it sought his guidance and advice on whether it could advertise on Sky Channel, on videos around the clubs and on movie screens. Those things seem to be electronic to me and it also seems to me that, unless they are owned by Laurie Connell or Alan Bond, it would have cost the Labor Party money to do that.

Where is the sense of the argument the Government has been running that it is banning political advertisements on television to save money so there will not be corruption, but such advertisements can be run at the movie houses at an expensive price? The ridiculousness continued when either Senator Schacht or Senator Bolkus referred to a campaign that Mr Kroger was running in Victoria. I know nothing about that, but I do know about the campaign that Mr Goss is running in Queensland. If the whole premise of the Government's argument about banning free speech is that advertising costs too much—you need a lot of money—and that causes corruption, can the Government tell me what the difference is between that and Mr Goss in Queensland at the moment running advertisements costing hundreds, probably millions of dollars? How is that saving expenditure? How is that stopping corruption? I would like someone to tell me.

Hundreds of thousands, even millions, of dollars are being spent on television advertising by Mr Goss in Queensland at the moment, and the Government says that, because he is spending all that money, that leads him to corruption. I would probably agree with the Government. Where is he getting all this money from? How will he pay for all these expensive television advertisements in Queensland? How will he do it? The Government's theory is that, because he is paying for the expensive television advertisements at the moment, he must be getting the money for them corruptly and, therefore, they should be banned.

That is how the Government started out. That is how it wanted it initially—it wanted to cut out those advertisements. But someone got at the Government—probably Mr Goss. He probably told the Government he wanted to advertise between now and then and made the Government change its mind. So the Government's whole argument was completely ridiculous. I notice the gentlemen opposite are silent—there are no ladies. This seems to be an argument that embarrasses them somewhat and they cannot answer it. Senator Bolkus may be able to explain that as well.

I refer to the Australian Democrats and the way that they have been involved in this issue. For the 30 pieces of silver in the old days, which converts, as Senator Kemp mentioned, to $1.8m, the Democrats were allowed to be bought off on this Act. Last time the Democrats spent $380,000 and this time they will get $1.8m of so-called free—free to them at least—advertising campaign money.

I was at least pleased to see my Queensland colleague Senator Kernot today agree with Senator Kemp that his figures were right. The Democrats used to spend about $400,000, they will now get almost $2m worth of `free' advertising at the next election. I admire Senator Kernot's honesty in admitting to that. She should, however, talk to her Leader, Senator Coulter. During the debate on 3 December he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the formula of time allocated and the formula used to divide up time, we calculate that it is remarkably similar to and probably slightly less than we have had on previous occasions.

Senator Coulter, the Leader of that bunch of Democrats, is saying that they used to do almost the same amount of advertising as they are getting now. As Senator Kernot acknowledged, that is a complete and utter mistruth and Senator Coulter should come into this chamber and either explain it, or at least apologise to this Senate for such an outrageous assertion. It could only be people of the likes of Senator Coulter who could believe that their previous spending of about $400,000 in some way equated in time to $1.8m. It is absolutely ridiculous. I hope that Senator Coulter will come into this debate and explain how he calculates that and apologise to us for misleading us.

PARA.TAB: One of the failures of this legislation is that the Democrats will get advertising paid for by the television stations—expropriated from the television stations—of about $1.8m, which equates to the 12, 13 or 14 per cent that they might have got at the last election. This is absolutely amazing and unreal in view of the fact their vote is now running at about 5 per cent and it is falling rapidly, particularly when Senator Powell was Leader. She was struggling, the polls were falling, but then the Democrats, in a flash of wisdom, got rid of Senator Powell and installed that statesman like new Leader, Senator Coulter.

The polls have shown what people think of that—they have continued to go down. By the time the next election comes around—and that will be a long time away because this lot opposite do not have the courage to call an election before the latest possible time—the Democrats' vote will be down to nothing. Yet they will still be funded on the basis of the vote they got at the last election at the height of the environmental vote in this State.
I might say, as others have mentioned, that the ALP in Tasmania got a magnificent vote of some 29 per cent in the Tasmanian election.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is better than Victoria.
—That is better than Victoria, I suppose. They do not deserve any more. I ask the gentlemen opposite to think about this.
—You hypocrite.
—When the next election comes around—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. As a rule, I am not delicate about expressions but I think it is not within the Standing Orders for Senator Faulkner to describe Senator Macdonald as a hypocrite, and I require it to be withdrawn.
—For the sake of the debate and because it is unparliamentary, I ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw the remark.
—If truth is no defence, I withdraw, Madam Acting Deputy President.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, we could all be ever so clever. But the truth of the matter is that you have asked for an unqualified withdrawal, and nothing is added to the colour of the debate by Senator Faulkner's conduct.
—I withdraw, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—Thank you, Senator Faulkner.

—I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for his intervention on my behalf. It was quite unnecessary. I never listen to anything that Senator Faulkner says; and what is more, I take no notice of what anyone might tell me he ever said. I might say that nobody else takes any notice of him either, except, of course, when he talks about the third runway. I assume that Senator Faulkner is the sod that Senator Collins turned over at the end of year. Is Senator Faulkner the sod that Senator Collins promised that he would turn over by 31 December 1991? I think we are still waiting for it. If it is a sod of dirt, it is still in the ground and we are still waiting. If it is the other sort of sod, obviously it is Senator Faulkner because he has been turned around. Is he a supporter of the third runway now? As I said, the intervention by Senator Crichton-Browne was unnecessary, but I thank him anyhow.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have a holier than thou attitude about the democratic institutions and about how our society has to be entirely democratic with people having the freedom to do what they like. Would you believe, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it is the Democrat crew who are going to stop the Greens right around Australia from advertising on television at the next election? One might say that was just an oversight, that maybe the Greens were caught up in the euphoria of the moment and that the Democrats did not think of them. I suggest to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that is not the case.

I would say that the Democrats knew full well that new parties and independents around Australia, such as the Greens, would be competing very strenuously at the next election for the vote that the Australian Democrats have received in the past. We can tell from their lurch to the left and their lurch to anything that is green in this society at the moment that the Australian Democrats are petrified by the vote that the Green independent candidates around Australia will get at the next election.

I suggest that all of the votes that the Democrats picked up last time were `Richardson' votes that went to him via the Democrats—the Democrats picked up something; the balance went to the Labor Party. The Democrats well know that all of that vote will go to the Green independents at the next election, because not even they trust the Australian Democrats—not even they trust them to do what needs to be done in their view. They do not trust them because they see the Australian Democrats as, in their view, just another political party with all of the machinations, all of the leadership overthrowing and all of the backstabbing. I am not even sure that Mr Keating did not learn some of the art of backstabbing from the way that the Australian Democrats got rid of their former leader.

The Democrats are under challenge from the Greens. If one were a Democrat, how would one stop that. One would make sure that they could not advertise. One would not want them telling one's constituents how hopeless one was or that one does not look after their interests. One would not want them to get any advertising.

What have the Australian Democrats done? They have caved in to this Government. They have sold out for $1.8m and made sure at the same time that their opponents get no chance at all. Maybe they learnt that from Keating. This is the group that, in the interests of democracy, supposedly supported this piece of legislation.

The Tasmanian experience has shown that independents, in particular, have no chance in federal seats. Independents have to fight sitting federal members who, practically by the grace of this Government, which has a majority in the other place, are given an almost unlimited amount of money to use on direct mailing to people in their large electorates. Any independent, any new candidate, any new party which might want to contest some of these seats will not have the advantage of all of that postage money that has been splashed about by the ALP Government and will not be able to get themselves known through advertising on television or radio.

So, effectively, this Government has given itself a headstart in any future election. It knows it full well. The Government knows that it cannot advertise because its supporters have realised what a rotten bunch its members are, and would not give them any money. Labor is broke everywhere. It cannot even run its property in Sydney without showing huge losses and trying to impose levies on the unionists to bail it out of its problems. So the Government has given itself a huge benefit at the expense of independents and new parties. I think that is a disgraceful act which the Australian public should continue to be reminded of.

I raised this matter with Senator Harradine, who I know was genuinely concerned that independents should not be disadvantaged by this legislation. Senator Harradine sought certain assurances and was given them. Although I still maintain that the regulations and the Act are wrongly worded—and I do not think it will turn out as Senator Harradine believes it will—some concessions were made by this Government so far as the Australian Senate is concerned. I understand—and I have only been told; I cannot guarantee the truthfulness of this—

TALK.START.PARA: —That won't stop you, will it?
—Senator Collins has not bothered about the truth of anything that he ever says in this chamber. So I do not know that he should interject along those lines.

PARA.TAB: The situation in the ACT election, as I understand it, was that Michael Moore, who was a sitting member of parliament and under the principles of this legislation was supposed to be funded, missed out completely. It is simply another example of the incompetence of this Minister and the Government that they are trying to push through legislation that they do not really understand and have no idea how to implement. It is another example—if any more are needed—of how these regulations are poorly drafted and administered. This situation needs to be looked at. People in the situation of Michael Moore—and I do not know him; he is probably a Labor Party reject anyhow—deserve the same right enjoyed by other candidates to get their message across. But this lot over here took away from Michael Moore the right of free speech.

Senator Walters raised an issue which I cannot believe is true. I hope that Senator Bolkus might be able to convince me that this is not the case. According to Senator Walters, in the recent Tasmanian election the independents were allocated a certain amount of time. However, because there was not enough time to run all the advertisements, the choice was made by drawing balls out of a hat—by a ballot. I cannot believe that that is true. I can only hope that Senator Walters has got that wrong. That sort of thing is unbelievable. Yet, apparently, it was widely publicised during the Tasmanian election that if one did not happen to be from the Liberal Party, the Labor Party or the Greens, one had to rely on having one's name drawn out of a hat if one wanted to advertise. What a great sort of democratic principle that is from this Government that will go to any lengths to stay in power!
I started to say before—and I was distracted by Senator Faulkner—that the 29 per cent that the ALP got in Tasmania is probably a lot more than it deserved. Come next election—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what the Liberal Party got in Queensland?
—The Liberal Party in Tasmania—as I understand Senator Collins's interjection—got something like 54 or more per cent.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator Collins what is going to happen to his Tasmanian colleagues at the next election—that is, if they still exist after they are taken over by Senator Loosley because of what they did to Senator Coates and Senator Aulich and to his Tasmanian Minister? Come next election—and this will serve them right—the Liberal Party is going to get 60 per cent of the free time but the Labor Party is going to get only 30 per cent of the free time. As I say, that is all it deserves, but even I do not think that in the Australian democratic system, the Australian parliamentary system, that can be right. A major party such as the ALP will get only half the advertising that we in the Liberal Party are getting. Even though it is nothing less than the Labor Party deserves, I cannot see that there is any fairness in that. Those sorts of anomalies, in particular, will have to be looked at.

This is another disgraceful set of supplementary or subordinate legislation. I ask Senator Bolkus again to indicate to me which of the regulations did apply because I am sure that the courts will be very interested in determining that later. As I say, my understanding is that none of them apply. Boy oh boy, what an unholy mess we will be in then. It is typical of this Government—which is incapable of governing itself, which is certainly incapable of getting legislation through the Parliament, and which is completely incapable of governing this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The political circumstances that now confront us are entirely different from any we have encountered in the postwar period and, in particular, since the introduction of television in Australia in the middle of the 1950s. We can now make an early but reasonable judgment of the impact of the Government's electoral reform legislation in the area of political broadcasting and political disclosures as a consequence of three political contests, each of which had different results—very clear and unambiguous results but very different results in terms of their outcomes. I refer, of course, to the Tasmanian general election, which was won by the Liberal Party, and to the victories by the ALP in the Entrance by-election and the Australian Capital Territory election.

PARA.TAB: It strikes me that, in terms of the debate here in this early part of the evening, the remarkable element that is common to the three elections in different political, cultural and geographical circumstances is not only the clarity of the results but also the fact that each of the results has been remarkably free of complaint and recrimination. That, of course, is not characteristic of Australian political history over the last couple of decades or so. The impact, very directly, of the Government's electoral reform legislation—and I stress that; it is legislation which has been designed to reform the system—has been overwhelmingly positive.

The easy way to judge that is simply to reflect for a moment on the simple, elementary fact that each of the political parties competing under the terms of the new legislation and each of the candidates, not necessarily those affiliated with the major parties, competing under the terms of the new legislation found it relatively easy to do so. So far as we can tell, based on the experience to date, the Government's legislation in this area has had absolutely no negative impact whatsoever—not upon the parties, not upon the candidates, not upon the people charged with administering the system and, most importantly of all, not upon the voters.

The electors have greeted this legislation with an ease and a preparedness to work within the new system—which again is not characteristic of our history. When we have changed electoral laws in the past—be it voting systems, be it related to distributions and redistributions of seats, be it related to the registration of political parties and so on—there have been problems. But based on the experience in the Entrance, in Tasmania and in the ACT, virtually no problem has been experienced anywhere. So far as we can tell, there have been no distortions in the system as a consequence of the new legislation. There have been absolutely no unforeseen consequences. That must be unique in our political history.

We have not seen claims of manipulation and deception by anyone. We have not seen claims of people having been misled. We are not in the courts, as we were in New South Wales, for example, as a consequence of the 25 May 1991 general election. No one has been denied rights: rights to participate, rights to have their views registered in a free way—and I will come to that term `a free way' a little later. Certainly it has not been suggested by anyone that a group of people, a political party or a single candidate has been given an unfair advantage over competitors or opponents.

I stress again that among the Australian electorate, among the public, no-one is complaining at all about the absence of political advertising on television and radio. From what we can see, by way of making an early judgment—I think a reasonable judgment; a little later we will be able to say an informed judgment—the Australian electorate seems to have welcomed the impact of the legislation. We have not seen claims and recriminations.

Mention has been made of circumstances in Tasmania. I had cause a few days ago to describe certain political decisions on the part of my Party as an intolerable folly. I must say that this debate has reached a point of sublime farce, and I say without fear of contradiction that it is in part an inexcusable waste of the Senate's time to debate regulations that apply to a unique circumstance which has passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is freedom of speech a waste of time?

—Someone ought to tell the Liberal Party that it won the Tasmanian election. At the end of February we are debating regulations which applied to a general election at the beginning of the month. That is the problem opposite. It is not only ideological zealotry that is continually in evidence opposite; we have come to expect that. It is not even anticipated. It is a simple reality. It is the politics of throwback all the time that we see. It is harking back; it is looking back. It is trying to undo things that have been done. In this case, what has been achieved by the Government in terms of electoral reform works. So it is unfortunate that, judging by some of the contributions opposite, the debate leads absolutely nowhere.

PARA.TAB: Let us stop for a moment to look at political campaigns now as a consequence of what has happened in those three political contests in New South Wales, in Tasmania and in the ACT, because I think it is instructive for all of us who are concerned with the democratic process and all of us who are committed to its effective functioning. For a start, it is easy to observe but nonetheless true that newspapers have come back very much into the centre ground of our politics in terms not only of their political coverage and their editorials but also of the campaign material that is contained within them—not just flagship advertisements and how-to-votes, but material that is designed to establish a theme. I make that point by way of an opening remark. The remarks I make beyond that I hope will mean far more.

It is definitely true that face to face campaigning at an electorate level is now far more significant. It is not a circumstance where candidates can reinforce their messages with comforting and conditioning slogans and jingles. I am glad that those conditioning slogans and jingles are gone because I think they contribute very little, if anything at all, to the political process. I say that as a person who, like many others in the chamber, was charged with the conduct of political campaigns during the 1970s and 1980s—successful campaigns in the main; unsuccessful campaigns on occasion. The common element in much of that electronic advertising was that it simply contributed very little to the political process, to the understanding by the electorate of the significance of issues, to the platforms on which the parties were fighting the contest, and certainly to the manner in which the Australian electorate was informed as to what the political parties intended to do in government. The Minister at the table, Senator Collins, knows that, from the point of view of opposition in the Northern Territory and government in the Federal sphere.
The circumstances of political contests are now that news and public affairs are of far greater significance in terms of the parties being obliged to communicate their messages effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you introduce this legislation in 1987 when you had Brian Burke's money?

—I will acknowledge Senator Crichton-Browne's interjection for the simple reason that I was arguing right throughout the late 1980s for these changes. I first began arguing for this manner of change in terms of political broadcasting in the middle of the 1980s. I moved the proposition at the National Executive of the ALP a matter of a few weeks after the Hawke Government had been returned for its fourth term—when there was no question about political and financial capacity. It has been a long term commitment I have had. That proposition on political broadcasting was consistent with the determination that originated with the New South Wales Labor Party to move the Federal Parliament to a four-year term.
—I accept that, but why did you keep spending buckets of money?

—The circumstances were always, from the 1960s right through to the 1980s, very similar to those which prevailed in international affairs—that unless one spent an absolute avalanche of dollars in the campaign one would be outspent by one's opponents, who would simply have an advantage. In terms of news and public affairs, though, it means that the parties have to be more creative, more thoughtful, more deliberate and more pointed in the manner in which they communicate with the electorate.

PARA.TAB: There is another campaign tool that has come very much into its own, and that is the tool of direct mail. I like the tool of direct mail for a number of reasons. In particular, I like it because it actually enables the political parties to have a dialogue with constituents—with people who are electors making judgments and casting votes. The best political direct mail invites a response, either in the way the Liberal Party traditionally has adopted, that of a questionnaire or survey, or in the manner the Labor Party favours, which is a direct response. Where that is followed up by doorknocking, telephone contact and the like, particularly involving the candidate, I think it is a very good thing.

The experience in the United States, to which I will turn in a moment, is of an electorate alienated due to the impact of television, principally television advertising. It is so alienated that recently, when the Governor of California was talking about victims of the recession in the United States, he was found to have made up composite unemployed workers because he simply had never had contact with any.

As a consequence of what the Government has done by way of its reform program, the parties are obliged to have a much better and clearer focus upon the issues—again, because the jingles are gone. It does not really matter whether it is `Turn on the lights' or `Wran's our man'. Heavens above, what did those jingles ever contribute in an enduring sense to political understanding or the health of our democracy? I would be interested to hear any honourable senator opposite argue the contrary. It is a question now of issues rather than themes, and I would argue very strongly that, as a consequence of the Government's reform program and our electoral reform legislation, the standard of political debate in Australia has been lifted—in a qualified sense to date; I believe it will become more pronounced as the impact increases.

I listened with interest to the Opposition's arguments. I think it is always of value to listen to what other people are saying in a debate. No-one has a monopoly on wisdom. I must say that I was disappointed. In terms of the notion of freedom to communicate being argued opposite on a continuing basis, I think there is a very necessary response. Where lies the freedom in being obliged to raise millions upon millions of dollars to make a point of communication? Where is the access? It is not open; it is not free; it is not unfettered. As a matter of fact, access to television and radio is open only to those possessed of enormous resources, as everyone in the chamber knows clearly and well. Where is the free capacity for people to argue a political point of view on the national television networks or the FM radio networks without an inexhaustible supply of campaign funds? It simply does not exist. That is the great furphy of this debate.

It is also very disappointing to see politics reduced to a concept of television advertising, as if nothing else is of any consequence at all. Political advertising on television has always been in very large measure, with only a handful of exceptions that come to my mind, characterised as follows: glib, superficial, inconsequential and evanescent. Again, I simply challenge people to produce a single political television commercial that mattered in the longer term.

People argue that the legislation relates to the Government's standing in the polls. That is simply untrue.
