As I mentioned earlier, many in the Labor Party argued year in and year out for these reforms to be introduced. The former Prime Minister gave me a personal commitment in the late 1980s that it would be an early item on the agenda after we won in 1990. He kept his word. There is no question that this reform legislation needs to be seen as consistent with other determinations of Labor governments at State and national levels, particularly in respect of the extension of the parliamentary term. That is a very important step to take, and I hope the Government and the Opposition can see their way clear to moving to a referendum in the not too distant future which would extend the life of the House of Representatives from three to four years.

I want to touch briefly upon the manner in which the Opposition has made reference to the Clerk's advice. It is not something I would ordinarily have raised. However, I do not think it can be ignored in the sense that I think the Clerk's office was put in an absolutely invidious circumstance by the manner in which the advice was used and, in my view, misused. I think Senator Bolkus made that clear in his opening remarks. Deleting the important qualifying word `if' in order to make an extraordinary political point was, at the very least, questionable, and if anyone ought to be apologising it is those opposite who were responsible for that.

We have also heard from time to time some special pleading on behalf of the television networks from one or two honourable senators opposite. I say again, without fear of contradiction, that the television networks in Australia gouged the political parties for decades for campaign dollars. We are not talking about thousands of dollars; we are talking about millions of dollars. I go right back to 1984 and to the general election of 1 December 1984. There was a television network running a first-run Australian series. From memory, it was The Last Bastion, but I cannot be certain of that. The circumstances were that the television network that was putting that series to air sought and received nearly $13,000 from the political parties for every 60-second commercial. That was unconscionable.

I refer again to Senator Crichton-Browne's earlier interjection as to why the political parties paid that money. They paid it because they believed, in my view in large measure quite rightly, that if they did not their opponents would and their opponents would have an artificial advantage conferred upon them.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you concede it is an advantage?

—It was perceived as an advantage at the time. I am no longer convinced of that. I want to touch briefly on a recent American experience. In so doing, I want to quote from the Economist of August last year—a lively, if somewhat conservative, magazine. The Economist, talking about political campaigning in the 1990s, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Putting politicians, ad men and journalists together on the campaign trail produces the worst of all three worlds: public relations stunts, half-true commercials and acres of trivia. Gone are the far-off days of worthy debate. Politics today has to be sold to a viewer whose finger is poised over the television zapper.

PARA.TAB: The 1988 campaign set new lows. It also demonstrated the power of image-making in changing a result.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, those observations related to political advertising on television in the United States in 1988 and subsequent to that. There is no doubt that American politics is absolutely dominated by television. An article in the Washington Post in December of last year—a front page article, as a matter of fact—observed of the current United States Congress that it had grown very good in two areas of achievement only: the creation of symbols and the making of 60-second television commercials. One can see the impact upon the legislature of the political campaign process being dominated by television.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say that I do not think television has an absolutely vital role to play. It can be very constructive and valuable. Particularly in Australia, some of the better public affairs programs achieve that result. Programs such as Lateline, Sunday and Dateline, just to name three that come to mind, are very valuable in terms of the democratic process. As to 60-second television commercials, I think that they are of no value whatsoever.

Of course, in the United States not only do we talk in terms of costly political TV advertising. Overwhelmingly that advertising is negative because, combining the dominance of television with the effective tyranny of voluntary voting—and I use that term deliberately—means that candidates, and by that overwhelmingly I mean incumbent candidates, focus simply upon cobbling together a coalition of voters in a dwindling overall voting constituency.

People must be motivated to vote. Motivating people to vote in primaries and in general elections in the United States now overwhelmingly involves making observations that are detrimental to one's opponent and some of it borders on the vicious. A lot of it is inane; some of it is amusing; a lot of it borders on the vicious. That is true of mayoral contests, gubernatorial contests and contests for the State legislatures, the United States Congress and for the occupant of 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. One need only look at the Republican commercials that focused on Willy Horton in 1988 to appreciate that at a glance.

In the contest for Governor of California on the last occasion between Pete Wilson and Dianne Feinstein, 90c in every campaign dollar raised by both parties was spent on television—90c in the dollar. What sort of communication does that purchase? It is not free. It is not unfettered. It is not an open access. It is designed to communicate with people in their homes, to motivate them to vote in a voluntary voting system. There is little contact between candidates and constituents. There is an almost total absence of policy debate. The platforms mean very little. It is glib, superficial political advertising by virtue of the lowest common denominator.

In terms of electoral systems, in terms of voting and in terms of the democratic process, in the United States now approximately only 50 per cent of Americans vote in presidential contests. In terms of the United States Congress—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they have to enrol.

—I will be interested to see whether Senator Parer argues the virtues of this, because I see none. In terms of the United States Congress, approximately one-third of Americans now vote in a number of seats. That means that it is very easy to put together a majority if one is an incumbent candidate possessed of the privileges of the United States Congress—of the House or the Senate—or in the State legislatures. That is why there is now more change in the Politburo in Beijing than there is in the United States Congress.

PARA.TAB: I can tell Senator Parer that at the last congressional election 98 per cent of incumbents were returned. There is precious little health in a system that guarantees a person a seat for life in a legislature—which is what the Americans have now managed to achieve. That is the direction in which Senator Parer would take Australians. Senator Parer is committed to that system. He is committed to a system that guarantees a gerontocracy. Again, we are dealing in throwback politics—the politics of the throwback; retrograde and regressive. The consequences to date of the three contests we have seen in Tasmania, the ACT and The Entrance, overwhelmingly have been positive. There is virtually not a negative report or a negative circumstance.

I want to conclude by making some observations in the broad. Of much greater significance than much that has been said in this debate is to focus on the fundamental reforms which the Government introduced to our electoral process towards the end of 1991. In my view, it is unquestioned that those measures strengthened our democracy. It is unquestioned that they made our political capacity to communicate more equitable and fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just took away freedom of speech.

—There is no right removed. There is no right eliminated whatsoever. If rights have to relate to the capacity of one's wallet then we have reached a sad point. I am quite happy to have been part of a government that introduced those reforms. I think that Senator Bolkus is to be commended for having had the courage to do so. I am quite happy to accept the judgment of Australian history. That judgment is not instant or immediate. It is not microwave politics such as that which we see from time to time opposite. It is a judgment in the longer term interest—in the public interest of Australians.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that the debate was personalised by Senator Macdonald a little earlier. This issue ought not to be personalised. It ought to be the subject of deliberate evaluation and deliberate assessment. The principles are absolutely vital to the effective functioning of our democracy. They are vital to the maintenance, consolidation and strengthening of Australian values. That sense of values about our institutions and our traditions is based very firmly on a concept of fairness. Fairness lies at the core of the Australian Government's reforms of the electoral process undertaken in 1991.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collins) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) concerning economic measures and to move to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the speech and a related document entitled One Nation and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Prime Minister took office a little over two months ago he pledged to fight the battle against unemployment and for economic recovery with all the energy he could muster.
Tonight we turn those words into action. Tonight the Government presents a Statement to get Australia moving—a four year strategy for growth in the nineties.
Mr President, for a Government which took pride in creating 1.6 million jobs in the 1980s this recession has been a bitter blow. Far worse, we know, has been the blow to a great many Australians.
In 1992 we need recovery and we need jobs.

Mr President, in the past 70 days the Prime Minister and a number of his ministerial colleagues, including myself, travelled around Australia, meeting business people, union leaders, State Governments and community organisations.
We received hundreds of messages from concerned Australians offering ideas and suggestions.
We listened.
We tested our ideas with people trying to succeed in tough times.
We reflected on our successes and failures, and drew some lessons from them.
We worked through the proposals and put them to three tests.
We decided that whatever we did should speed recovery.
Whatever we did should set us up for long-term prosperity.
And whatever we did should be most helpful to those in need.
Tonight we announce measures which meet these requirements.

Labor's plan for the next four years will create over 800 000 jobs, without increasing the current account deficit and at the same time return the budget to surplus and Australia to growth. Low inflation growth.
We have a $2.3 billion dollar plan for Australia.
Mr President, tonight's Statement contains great initiatives. We believe, historic initiatives.
Measures big enough to kickstart the economy and get things going. Big enough to get people back to work.
And big enough to stir the imagination.
But our program will do more than speed our recovery from recession—it will build the Australia of the future.
It will help our young people now; and it will still be helping them when they raise their own children.
Building on our advantages and the great gains we made in the 1980s, it will make us much stronger.
This Statement is very much about making this nation strong.
It is about government and private enterprise working in partnership. About co-operation to achieve worthwhile change, instead of barren confrontation.
It's about Australians, realising that their destiny is in their own hands, combining their strengths to make the nation strong.
A nation, like all successful nations, where employers and workers pool their creativity and energy to transform workplaces.
A nation in which our rail, road, sea and air services serve us better and bind us together as a federation—as a nation.
A civilised country where we take care of those in need. Where we invest in our children.
This is the nation we have always thought we should be. It's the nation we think we can be.
That is why we want to keep up the pace of change. We want Australia to be fiercely competitive in the world—so that we can deliver opportunity and care at home.
We want us to be strong within, so we can be strong in the world—a world which too often does not compete fairly.

This is the Australia we worked towards in the `80s: when the Accord transformed our industrial relations; when the number of strikes fell by 60 per cent; when investment and employment grew; and when we opened the country up to more competition.

We will get things moving by giving an immediate boost to spending with a one-off payment worth over $300 million to Australian families with children: by bold reforms to provide incentives to private investment; and by undertaking major capital works programs of permanent benefit to the nation.
Most of these initiatives will have an impact now, boosting demand and, in turn, boosting jobs. They will reinforce the stimulus coming from lower interest rates and bring forward economic recovery.
Mr President, spending will be sensible and responsible.

The economy needs a spur, and the soundness of the budget allows us to provide it. But as recovery proceeds and the private sector regains its spark, we will wind back the spending in the budget, returning it to surplus by 1995-96.
The scale of work over the next few years will be massive.

While private investment is low we will take the opportunity to build railways, roads, ports, electricity grids, air terminals, waste management plants, colleges, schools—in all, more than a billion dollars of new construction over the next two years.
Mr President, for much of our history Australia has been disadvantaged by the great distances which separate us from each other and the world.
Our major population centres were—and remain—hundreds of kilometres apart.
Our lines of supply were long: the costs of transport high.
Mr President, tonight we announce a series of historic undertakings to help overcome those distances, to improve our links Australia-wide and our interaction with the world.
To make us more truly one place.
One very much more efficient nation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Building a Rail Highway and Competitive Ports

SPEECH.PARA: We will do what should have been done a hundred years ago—we will create a standard gauge national rail highway from Brisbane to Perth via Melbourne and Adelaide.
We shall do it in a way that ensures the project is underpinned by work practices which make such an investment viable.

The Brisbane-Sydney-Melbourne rail line will be modernised and upgraded for faster and more reliable transit, and a new standard gauge will be laid between Melbourne and Adelaide, tying the east coast network via Melbourne to Perth.

A standard gauge spur will be built at the port of Brisbane, linking it to the Acacia Ridge rail terminus. A dedicated freight line will be built out of Enfield in Sydney to give trains clear access to the southern line.
A new rail-sea-road terminus connecting with the port will be constructed at Dynon in Melbourne.
Rail facilities at the ports of Fremantle and Adelaide will be upgraded.
Together with the other mainline rail investments, this will expand opportunities for moving freight across Australia and generally improve the efficiency of our freight transport.
Exporters will at last see the ports of Sydney and Melbourne competing for business with the ports of Brisbane, Adelaide and Fremantle.
The rail highway will also provide essential competition with road transport.
At the same time it will significantly reduce damage to roads, and make them very much safer.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A Better and Safer Road Network

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, we will be spending over $600 million extra on roads between now and the end of 1993-94.

We will accelerate construction of city ring roads in Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney to link national highways, and we will improve other roads to create a more effective network throughout Australia.
We are offering to develop the Sturt and Newell highways to create first class direct links between Adelaide and Brisbane and Melbourne and Brisbane.
Mr President, for too long Australians were priced out of air travel by the two-airline agreement.
Two years ago the Labor Government opened our skies to competition and, especially after Compass entered the market, air travel became affordable to most Australians.
The enthusiasm was enormous. It boosted business and tourism.
But we have taken only the first step.
With tonight's Statement a new Australasian air transport policy is unveiled.
It brings cheaper and more efficient air services within Australia and abroad.
It binds Australia and New Zealand in a truly competitive environment.
It means Qantas will at last carry domestic passengers, and our established domestic airlines will fly international routes.
The Government expects that Australian and Ansett Airlines will be operating across the Tasman by 1993 at the latest.
To help new competitors into the airline industry we will build new common-user air terminals where they are needed.
We will also speed the expansion of the international terminal in Melbourne, and the development of Brisbane's international airport.
Mr President, our great changes to the national transport system will make our continent smaller and our nation greater. They are a one billion dollar investment in the future.
Mr President, we will start other projects to make better use of our resources and integrate our States and cities.
We have a great capacity to produce electricity—but it is not as cheap as it should be.
We will seek the co-operation of the State Premiers to develop a National Grid Corporation to connect users and producers from Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania.
To facilitate this my Government is offering $100 million to upgrade the transmission link between New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.
With the States' agreement, we will take the crucial step of separating power generation from distribution.
By thus obliging the power generating authorities to compete, we will improve service and efficiency, and deliver energy to homes and industry more cheaply than most other countries in the world.
Mr President, among other major public works to be undertaken, in Victoria a high quality rail service will be built from Melbourne to Geelong.
In Queensland a rail service will be built to connect Brisbane to Robina on the Gold Coast, providing transport to one of the fastest-growing communities in Australia.
In Adelaide we will get the Multifunction Polis going by paying for and carrying out the early stages of site work.

And in Perth a sewage treatment plant will be built, using Australian-developed, world-best processes—for the benefit of the people and the environment—and as a sign that Australian technology can solve problems here and overseas.

Mr President, immediately, these great public works will help re-start the economy. They will create jobs now, and by the assistance they give to industry, they will still be creating them into the future.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Changing the Tax Rules to Boost

SPEECH.PARA: Investment
As our industries change, as workplaces are transformed, we will replace old machines with new machines, old factories with new ones.

Our discussions with business leaders have led us to change the taxation provisions in ways which will make investment in Australian industry more attractive—particularly the kind of big and durable investments we need.
From tomorrow the cost of new capital equipment can be fully claimed against tax long before its economic life is over by accelerating rates of depreciation.
The new rates are particularly generous to long life investment.
For example, from tomorrow, plant and equipment which lasts twenty years can be effectively claimed over seven and a half years.
These new schedules mean that from now on Australian tax rules for investment will be more than competitive with comparable countries.
Mr President, we will make other big changes to tax rules for business.
Infrastructure

In a landmark reform calculated to greatly improve public infrastructure and take the load off the States and local councils, we will use special tax preferred bonds to encourage private companies to build roads, ports and electricity generating plants.
and Medium Businesses
We will also change the tax system to channel new money into successful and promising smaller businesses which today are unable to attract equity capital, either on the stock exchange or privately.

To further assist small business we are increasing from 20 per cent to 50 per cent the amount of goodwill exempt from capital gains tax on the sale of a business. And more businesses will qualify for this exemption.
and Getting Them Finished

We are going to simplify the environment and heritage reviews which are often involved in big projects by building on the historic environment agreement we have finalised with the States. It will lead to a single environment process for Australia.

With the introduction of a 10 per cent development allowance we will reward big projects which complete the review procedures quickly, which are world competitive and completed within a reasonable time.
Mr President, we will change the rules to encourage the tourism industry, one of the great success stories of the 1980s and one of the economic stars of the 1990s.
In the next decade the number of tourists coming to Australia will increase from 2.4 million to 6.5 million.
That means 200,000 new jobs for Australians.
To meet the demand for accommodation we have made the write-off provisions on tourist-related buildings much more favourable for investment.
We will also increase financial assistance to the Australian Tourist Commission to promote Australia abroad.
Mr President, the recession has had a severe effect on motor vehicle sales.
From tomorrow the sales tax on new cars currently subject to the 20 per cent rate will be permanently lowered to 15 per cent—a saving on a new Commodore or Falcon of around $800.
With cheaper cars we will drive newer cars, which is good for the environment, good for road safety, and good for one of our most important industries.

Mr President, we are moving to prevent unnecessary foreclosure by banks of viable businesses unable to meet debts. Banks will be able to claim tax deductions for partial debt write-offs and also for losses on debt for equity swaps, allowing firms in difficulty to trade their way out of trouble.
Too few of our research successes are exploited commercially by Australia for Australia.
To help overcome the impediment, we will create an Australian Technology Group, to bid for the rights to publicly fund research projects and sell them on to business.
The ATG will make the link between good research ideas and good business.
This will be in addition to the 125 per cent deduction for the costs of research and development which is now a permanent feature of our tax system.
Mr President, all of these initiatives will help build a productive base for Australian exports.
The potential increase in our exports by 1994 is $20 billion. Of this the potential increase to Asia is $13 billion.
Among the measures we will take to seize this opportunity, the Government will extend Austrade's network throughout the world, and particularly to Asia.
Mr President, a nation cannot be strong if at the very point where wealth is made—the workplace—people are locked in conflict.
Modern industry has to be a cooperative process.

That is a truth we tapped when we began the task of changing the industrial culture of this country, from one in which employers and workers were always at each other's throats, to one in which they now talk about how to do things better.
We will continue this change and move quickly towards a bargaining system in which higher wages will come from increased efficiency.
Employers and workers will be free to change workplaces in whatever way is most efficient, and to register their settlements as binding agreements with the Industrial Relations Commission.
But basic standards must be met. We will not support slashing minimum wages and conditions.
Our reforms to industrial relations have been the most constructive step this country has taken since the war.
To stop now, as our opponents are hell bent on doing, would be the most destructive step we could take.
Mr President, our inflation rate is now the second lowest in the world.
We must keep it low.
Inflation puts up interest rates, it encourages speculation rather than production, it erodes the value of savings. It is a totally corrupting influence on the fabric of society.
The bed-rock of the great post-war economies has been low inflation.
It must be ours too. Labor will never surrender the inflation fight.
Mr President, last week the Prime Minister sought and received an assurance from the ACTU that wage claims will enable us to maintain an inflation rate comparable to that of our trading partners.
To create the climate of trust and fairness necessary to preserve wage outcomes the nation can afford, and with them low inflation, the Government will lower the tax rates over the next four years.
When these tax reforms are complete more than three-quarters of Australian taxpayers will pay no more than 30 per cent on their last dollar of income.
A 30 per cent tax rate under Labor, no inflationary consumption tax, no 15 per cent string attached.
Mr President, it is almost inconceivable that anyone would contemplate deliberately putting inflation back into the economy.
But the Leader of the Opposition contemplates it. It is his big idea.
With a 15 per cent consumption tax and without a wage agreement, even on the admission of one of his own economic consultants, we are back into built-in, double-digit inflation.
And of course we are back into rising interest rates.
Mr President, it is just astounding.
One of the objects of this statement is to give the economy the spark it needs by getting spending going again.
We want to bring forward the recovery without creating an on-going cost to the budget.
With this in mind, we have decided to boost spending by helping Australians who urgently need to spend—families with children, including the unemployed.

Mr President, tonight the Prime Minister will ask Parliament to approve a one-off, special payment on 2 April to every family which qualifies for the family allowance. The payment will be $125 for a family with one child, rising to $250 for a family with five or more children.
As part of the measure, Mr President, the family allowance supplement for low income families will be permanently increased by $3 per child per week at a cost of $240m in 1992-93.
Mr President, we intend to give special assistance to a number of other groups who have been hit hard by the recession.
We will be increasing the funding for the emergency relief agencies such as the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul who shoulder much of the burden of helping the poor and the homeless.
Australian farmers are the most efficient in the world.
For most of the life of this nation they have provided the economic backbone. They have also borne much of the hardship which uncertain markets and an uncertain climate have inflicted.
There are two major areas of rural production which have recently gone through difficult times; wool is one, wheat is the other.
We should nurture these great industries and help farmers during the recovery phase.
We will allow the Wool Realisation Commission to make cash payments to wool growers in the event that proceeds from the stockpile are surplus to debt repayment requirements.
We will also provide a one-off addition to the Rural Adjustment Scheme to help wheat and other broad acre growers plant their crops to take advantage of recent rains.
We are determined to become more competitive, but this will not blind us to the human cost of industrial change.

We will spend more on helping the textile, clothing and footwear industries to adjust; and we will assist further adjustments by creating opportunities for downstream processing of our wool clip, including the development of new wool-tops production.
Mr President, in the 1980s the Labor Government made two dramatic changes to education in Australia.
We increased secondary school retention rates and we expanded universities.
In 1983 less than four out of every 10 young Australians completed 12 years of schooling.
Today that figure has doubled.
In 1992 around 500 000 Australians are participating in higher education, an increase of over 120 000 students since 1987—the equivalent of 12 new universities.
There has been a revolution both in the way we think about education and in the way we conduct it.
We are giving more people more chances. We are becoming better equipped to meet the challenges.
But we cannot be a clever country if we lack the skills and know-how to innovate and deal with problems in the workplace—if we cannot implement our own ideas.
From tonight technical or vocational training, the weak reed in Australian education, will become a strand of equal strength.
We will vastly expand vocational education, so that we will become not just a clever country, but a capable one.
In conjunction with the States we are offering to build an expanded technical education system where the Commonwealth will fund the whole program.

With State agreement and Commonwealth money—an extra $720 million over the next three years—we can create thousands more places, giving school leavers a chance they would not have had while lifting the quality and status of vocational education.
Mr President, we will also provide training and support to prepare the young, including the young unemployed, for entry to the workforce.

By raising employer incentives, we will create an extra 9 000 first-year apprenticeship places in 1992; an extra 10 000 places in the Australian Traineeship System, and 7 000 apprentices presently at risk of retrenchment will be retained.
We will redirect funds to the needs of the long-term unemployed.
The Government will provide an extra $100 million to Jobstart creating another 44 000 job opportunities.
We will also provide funding to create jobs in regional Australia, and expand the Jobskills program and other programs of assistance.

As I said at the outset, we have a plan for Australia—a big plan. With our strategy, within four years the Federal Budget will return to surplus, and we will have created another 800 000 jobs, clipping 3 percentage points off unemployment.
We will have made up our loss in economic growth five times over, and will have done it while keeping inflation low.
Within four years Australians will be working in one of the best-designed tax systems in the world, and most will be paying a maximum taxation rate of 30 per cent—without a consumption tax.
Mr President, I spoke earlier about the great distances which have for so long separated Australians—geographical distances, social distances.
The measures we have announced tonight will help to close the gaps.

In transport and communications, in workplace reform, in encouraging investment in industries Australia needs, in expanding technical education and in providing help to people in need, we are closing the gaps.
Labor believes that the community and the economy must advance together: that all our efforts should go towards uniting the country, not dividing it.
The most successful societies are notable for their unity, for the co-operative quality of all their relationships, from the workplace up.
That is the kind of Australia we seek, and which we firmly believe we can have.
An Australia which is more truly one nation.
Mr President, we can come out of this recession stronger than we have ever been.
With low inflation, with strong manufacturing as well as our traditional rural and mining industries, with a new spirit of co-operation, new skills and a new culture of investment and productivity.
We are now living among the fastest-growing economies in the world.
For the first time in our history we are close to our major markets—the chance is there as it has never been before.
We have the essentials for a strong recovery.
The measures we have announced tonight will harness them.
They will harness Australia's talents and energy.
They will make us stronger.
They will give back to us our sense of purpose and our confidence.
Confidence in ourselves—and in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a report in the Weekend Australian titled `How the West Gave Saddam the Bomb' by Nicholas Rufford and David Deppard, which states that Iraq had everything it needed to build a nuclear bomb in 1991 had the Gulf War not intervened:
(1) Was Iraq unwittingly helped to build such a bomb by information gleaned from the Imperial College, London, and also by the freely available scientific literature.
(2) Did Iraq copy one of the West's most closely guarded secrets, the nuclear centrifuge developed by URENCO, a nuclear manufacturing alliance of Britain, Germany and the Netherlands.
(3) Did Iraq successfully build nuclear bombs using technology obtained from the West.
(4) Was Iraq, because it was a party to the Non-Proliferation Treaty, entitled to receive the benefits of nuclear technology in return for promising to use it peacefully.

(5) Did inspectors from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency regularly check to ensure that there were no breaches of NPT rules by Iraq; if so, has the United Nations International Atomic Energy Agency tightened up the rules to ensure that Iraq and other countries who are parties to the NPT do not follow a similar path to that taken by Iraq.
(6) Are any measures in place to stop Saddam Hussein from reactivating Iraq's nuclear program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I am aware of the article to which the honourable senator refers. My response to the specific issues raised are as follows:

(1) On the basis of information now available, it is reasonable to conclude that Iraq actively applied to its nuclear weapons development program information gained both from freely available scientific literature and from the normal overseas academic study programs of Iraqi students (including at the Imperial College, London).

(2) Inspections undertaken by International Atomic Energy Agency/United Nations Special Commission (IAEA/UNSCOM) personnel indicate that Iraq was developing concurrently designs for two types of uranium enrichment centrifuge. Both types were at least similar to designs used by URENCO, and an examination of components discovered in Iraq has led the IAEA/UNSCOM inspectors to conclude that substantial assistance was afforded to Iraq by a person, or persons, with knowledge of URENCO-type centrifuges. In the opinion of the IAEA/UNSCOM experts who took part in the relevant 12-15 January 1992 inspection, however, the Iraqis' centrifuge enrichment program had not progressed to the point where they could have started a sizeable production of centrifuges, although, given time, they would have been successful in such production.

(4) Article IV of the Treaty on the Non Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) sets out a moral and political undertaking by Parties to facilitate, and a right for all Parties to participate in, "...the fullest possible exchange of equipment, materials and scientific and technological information for the peaceful uses of nuclear energy." This provision, however, deliberately falls short of setting out an automatic legal "entitlement" to which a Party might appeal in order to receive particular nuclear cooperation benefits, nor does it dictate the terms the relevant parties might mutually agree for such cooperation.

(5) Yes, with regard to nuclear material and facilities which had been declared to the IAEA. Iraq's nuclear weapons program essentially was based on undeclared materials and facilities. As a result of the revelations about Iraq's nuclear weapons program, the IAEA and its member states are involved in a major program to strengthen IAEA safeguards, in particular as regards possible undeclared materials and facilities, with the clear aim of avoiding any repeat of the Iraqi experience.

The Government believes the experience with Iraq demonstrates the need for, and value of, advanced reporting procedures and comprehensive international export controls for sensitive items. We are seeking actively to strengthen export controls, both through the work of the Nuclear Suppliers Group, of which Australia is a member, and by promoting as a norm the adoption of fullscope safeguards as a requirement for new nuclear supply.

Australia is taking a leading role in these efforts, both through bilateral and multilateral consultations with likeminded states and through its position on the IAEA Board of Governors. In September last year, I led the Australian delegation to the IAEA General Conference and emphasised the Government's concern about these issues. At the same conference, Australia took the initiative to introduce a resolution calling for the strengthening of the safeguards system, a resolution which I am pleased to record was adopted by consensus.
The Government intends to maintain its strong support for the IAEA safeguards program and is determined to see prompt and effective action taken to strengthen it.

(6) Yes. On 11 October 1991 the United Nations Security Council under its Resolution 715 (1991) accepted an IAEA proposal for the future ongoing monitoring and verification of Iraq's compliance with Resolutions 687 and 707 (1991). The former prohibits Iraq's acquisition of, and research and development related to, nuclear weapons and nuclear-weapons-usable material, while the latter prohibits all nuclear activities in Iraq except the use of isotopes for medical, agricultural or industrial purposes. The program set out in Resolution 715 (1991) is designed to provide confirmation that all of Iraq's nuclear capabilities prohibited by Resolution 687 have been destroyed, removed or rendered harmless and assurance that such capabilities are not resurrected in the future by verifying that only those nuclear activities permitted under Resolution 707 are undertaken by Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the housing entitlements for the spouses of those service personnel who died in the following Air Force accidents (a) 12 March 1990, Nomad; (b) 2 August 1990, F/A-18; (c) 16 November 1990, Macchi; (d) 24 April 1991, PC3 Orion; (e) 5 June 1991, F/A-18; (f) 5 August 1991 PC9/A; and (g) 29 October 1991, Boeing 707.
(2) What are the housing entitlements for the spouses of those service personnel who died in the following army air accidents: (a) 9 September 1991, Nomad; and (b) 12 November 1991, Porter.
(3) What other entitlements are each of the above spouses entitled to.

(4) Is the Government proposing any legislation or amendments to existing legislation in regard to entitlements for spouses of servicemen killed in peacetime military accidents; if so, will it include spouses of reservists killed in peacetime duty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is necessary to have regard to the privacy of individuals in providing answers to the honourable senator's questions. It is not appropriate to provide details of the entitlements of each individual, which will differ depending on such variables as the date of enlistment of the member, age of the member, number of dependant children etc. The policy under which entitlement is assessed is the same for all three services. In general terms the entitlements are:

ANSWER.PARA: Housing entitlements for spouses of deceased members are as follows:

PARA.TAB: Home Loans depend on the member's eligibility for assistance under either the Defence Service Home (DSH) Loans Scheme or the ADF Home Loans Assistance Scheme (ADFHLAS).

DSH entitlements are the responsibility of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. However, I understand that if members were eligible for a DSH loan, the widow becomes eligible in her own right and is therefore entitled to a DSH loan. This loan can be taken up at any time. In addition, such a widow may be eligible for special relief provisions in cases of hardship.

Generally, if the member was an eligible person under the ADFHLAS, the widow is entitled to subsidy for the period equal to that which the deceased eligible person would have been entitled to at the time of death, had he/she been an incapacitated person. That is, where the member had been serving for less than 16 years, a subsidy period equal to the lesser of the number of completed years of effective full time service, or 10 years. The loan must be taken up within 2 years of the death of the spouse.
The spouse of a deceased member may remain in a Married Quarter, paying GRS rental, for up to three months, with extensions authorised by Service Offices in special circumstances.
The spouse of a deceased member is entitled to receive TRA for up to three months, with extensions authorised by Service Offices.
(2) As for question 1
(3) Other entitlements are as follows:

The spouse of a deceased member is entitled to a removal to the locality of the last permanent residence of the member and the member's family at the time of enlistment (within Australia) or to any other locality in Australia provided that expenditure on the removal is no greater than the cost of the removal entitlement to locality of enlistment.

The spouse may also be approved to be removed to any other locality in Australia, provided that the approving authority is satisfied that the family has established or intends to establish a permanent home in that locality. Removal to an overseas country may be approved provided that public expenditure is limited to the cost of the entitlement to the locality of enlistment.

The family of a Reserve member rendering full time service at the time of death is entitled to a removal to the locality where he/she resided immediately prior to the commencement of full time service, or to any other locality which will not involve greater cost.
The member's family may be granted travel at public expense following the same guidelines as for removals.
The spouse of a deceased member may also be entitled to Pet Relocation Expenses Allowance, Child Care Reimbursement Allowance and Disturbance Allowance.
Where the family is granted a removal, TAA may be paid for up to two weeks in the old locality and up to three weeks in the new locality.
Where a member dies, payment in lieu of annual recreation leave, recreation leave bonus, long service leave and war service leave entitlements is made to the dependant/s of the member.

Benefits are payable under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (CERCA), where a member's death arises out of or in the course of his/her employment during peacetime service. Where the deceased leaves dependants who were wholly dependent upon him/her, the Act provides for a lump sum of $148,933.84 (current at 1 July 1991) payable to the dependants. Where only partial dependency can be established, the dependants are entitled to an amount not exceeding $148,933.84. This amount is determined having regard to the losses suffered by those dependants as a result of the cessation of the earnings of the deceased.

As a basic principle, where there is a spouse who is wholly dependent, irrespective of any other dependants, they must receive no less than 75% of the full lump sum. Where there are wholly dependent children, the following general principles apply:
1 child—10% of full award—balance to spouse
2 to 5 children—each to receive 5%—balance to spouse
More than 5 children—25% of full award to be apportioned equally—balance to spouse
The lump sum payable to a dependent child is kept in trust until he/she turns 18. These percentages may be varied where, in the delegate's opinion, there exists a sound reason for the variation.
In addition, a weekly amount, currently $49.64, is payable in respect of each child under 16 years, or under 25 years if a wholly or mainly dependant student child.
Funeral expenses of $1,861.67 (current at 1 July 1991) are payable also.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) provides for the payment to surviving spouses of regular members and reserve members on continuous full time service, a fortnightly widow's pension of $325.60 plus up to $51.50 (max) per fortnight for each surviving dependent child. VEA benefits are tax free.
The benefits provided under the CERCA and the VEA are not payable concurrently.

Where a regular member, or reserve member on periods of continuous full time service in excess of 12 months, has not elected to transfer to MSBS, the surviving spouse of a member who died on or after 1 October 1991, but before 1 October 1992, has an option of transferring to MSBS or remaining with DFRDB.

ANSWER.PARA: Reversionary benefits under these two schemes are as follows:

PARA.TAB: Under DFRDB a surviving eligible spouse of a member who dies in service receives 5/8ths of the Class A invalidity pension of 76.5% of salary (the maximum benefit payable under the scheme). This amounts to 47.8% (5/8 X 76.5%) of salary and is paid as an indexed pension. Up to two years of the late-member's salary can be commuted, with a commensurate reduction in the pension payable.
In addition, an eligible child (other than an orphan) will receive 1/6th of the spouse's benefit (disregarding any commutation) plus a fixed pension of $338.83 p.a (indexed at CPI).

An eligible orphan receives a benefit equal to 1/8th of the benefit that would have been payable to an eligible spouse plus a fixed pension of $5,430 p.a (indexed at CPI). In these cases the total benefit payable to orphans is limited to the maximum benefit that would have been payable to the member had the member been receiving invalidity pay at the Class A rate.

Spouses of MSBS contributors who die in service receive a refund of the member's contributions plus interest. Where there are no dependants the refund is payable to the estate. The estate will also receive an employer benefit equal to the benefit that would have been payable had the member retired on invalidity grounds and been eligible for Class A invalidity pay.

A surviving spouse may take the employer component of the superannuation benefit as a lump sum or convert a minimum of 50% of the lump sum to a pension. If 100% of the lump sum is converted to a pension the rate of pension would be 67% of the Class A pension payable had the member lived. The amount of the superannuation benefit is dependent on the pension the member would have received had he or she served to age 55.

In addition, the pension is increased by 11% for each dependent child, to a maximum of 33%. That is, the spouse and the dependent children cannot receive more than the member would have received had he or she lived.

Orphans receive the member benefit lump sum plus an employer funded pension. The rate of the pension is 45% of the Class A pension for the first orphan, 80% for two orphans, 90% for three and 100% for four or more orphans.

(4) A military compensation scheme for ADF personnel during peacetime service is currently being developed. Consideration is being given to the compensation needs of both regular and reserve personnel. The benefits offered under this scheme will not be any less than those currently enjoyed under CERCA, and will recognise the special characteristics of ADF service as they are relevant to compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the housing entitlements for servicemen or women (regular and reserve) who are severely injured as a result of an accident whilst serving on peacetime duty and who may have to be discharged on medical grounds.
(2) What other entitlements are they entitled to.

(3) Is the Government proposing any legislation or amendments to existing legislation in regard to entitlements for servicemen and women severely injured as a result of accidents whilst serving on peacetime military duty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Housing entitlements for members who are severely injured and are discharged on medical grounds as a result of accidents whilst serving on peacetime military duty are as follows:

DSH Loan Entitlements. The responsibility for DSH loan entitlements rests with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. However, I understand that where a member was serving between 7 December 1972 and 16 August 1977 inclusive and had enlisted for a three year period, or a member who enlisted on or after 17 August 1977 for a six year period (other than a member who is entitled under the ADF Home Loans Assistance Scheme), was unable to complete the required period of service on medical grounds, that member would be entitled to a DSH loan. However, a member discharged on medical grounds within twelve months of enlistment during the dates referred to above would not be eligible for DSH assistance if the medical condition causing the discharge, even if aggravated, was not materially aggravated by that service. DSH loans are only available to members who render continuous full-time service which generally excludes most reserve members.

ADF Home Loans Assistance Scheme (ADFHLAS). A member who is eligible under the ADFHLAS, whose injury is accepted as being compensable and who would otherwise have served for a period of at least six years, is known as an incapacitated person. Where the member had been serving for less than 16 years, a subsidy period equal to the lesser of the number of completed years of effective full time service, or 10 years will be granted. There are no special provisions where such a person had served more than 16 years.

After discharge the member and his family may be permitted to remain tenants, paying full market rental, for periods up to three months, with extension to this tenancy granted by Service Offices in special circumstances.
After discharge the member has no further entitlement to TRA.
(2) Other entitlements are:

The member is entitled to a removal to the locality in Australia that the member nominated as his/her permanent residence when he/she entered the Defence Force or the port of entry in Australia where the member was enlisted or appointed from an overseas country.

The member is entitled to a removal to any other locality in Australia, provided the removal is limited to the cost of the entitlement above, or to any other locality provided the approving authority is satisfied that the member has or intends establishing a permanent home in that locality.

A Reserve member on full time service is entitled to a removal to the locality where he/she resided immediately prior to commencement of full time service, or to any other locality which does not involve a greater cost.
The member may be entitled to Pet Relocation Expenses Allowance, Child Care Reimbursement Allowance and Disturbance Allowance.

Where the member is granted a removal at public expense on discharge, TAA is payable for one day in the old locality and up to seven days in the new locality. Additional periods may be approved where warranted.
Where a member is granted a removal, he/she (and family where applicable) is entitled to travel at public expense to that locality.

Salary and certain allowances are paid in lieu of recreation leave, recreation leave bonus, war service leave and long service leave. Normally long service leave is only accrued where a member has served 10 years of admissible full time employment. Where a member is discharged on medical grounds, a period of admissible service in excess of 12 months will be counted for payment in lieu of long service leave.
A member separating compulsorily on medical grounds is entitled to the same resettlement benefits as a long term member.

Currently, ADF policy provides that compensable members who can be rehabilitated to active service may, in extreme cases, be retained in service on full pay for up to 18 months. However, if a member is discharged as a result of a compensable condition, the CERCA provides that regular and reserve members have an entitlement to the following:

Weekly incapacity payments of no less than 75% of pre-injury earnings, subject to a ceiling of 150% of Average Weekly Earnings as provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Low income earners would receive up to 90% of their pre-injury earnings. Incapacity payments cease at age 65.
A tax free lump sum payment for permanent impairment and non-economic loss up to a maximum of $136,522-69.
A maximum of $248.22 per week is payable for the cost of household services obtained by the ex-member. The same benefit is payable for the cost of attendant care obtained.
The cost of all reasonable medical treatment obtained for the accepted condition.
The cost of the supply, replacement or repair of an artificial limb, aid or appliance used by the ex-member. The cost of reasonable alterations to a house, vehicle or workplace.
In addition, Defence has a responsibility under the CERCA for the management of rehabilitation of its injured ex-members.

Under the VEA regular members and reserve members on continuous full time service in this situation receive a set disability pension of $345.10 (max) per fortnight from the date of injury, tax free, indexed twice yearly. They are also entitled to an allowance for attendant care of an amount of $168.60 (max) per fortnight. The loss of weekly earning benefits are payable, tax free, for life.

The benefits provided under the CERCA and the VEA cannot be paid concurrently. The beneficiary must choose which package best suits his/her circumstances and accept those benefits. Further, CERCA incapacity benefits are offset by the employer funded component of Commonwealth Superannuation invalidity benefits. There are no similar offsetting arrangements under the VEA. Similarly, where a member is able to return to full or part time civilian employment, wages earned are offset against CERCA entitlements, while at the same time the percentage of separation salary paid as compensation increases with graduated return to work. Dependant on hours worked, VEA benefits may also be reduced.
DFRDB contributors invalided from service on medical grounds receive the following benefits:

ANSWER.PARA: Class B pension38.25% of salary, or
Class C lump sumRefund of 1 1/2 X

PARA.TAB: if greater.

ANSWER.PARA: Under MSBS members invalided from service receive a refund of contributions with interest plus one of the following:
Class AAn employer financed pension payable
retireeimmediately based on actual and prospective service to age 55.
Class BHalf the Class A pension, payable
retireeimmediately, or the actual accrued pension, whichever is the greater.
Class CAn employer benefit based on actual
retireeservice at the date of retirement and preserved to age 55.

PARA.TAB: (3) A military compensation scheme for ADF personnel during peacetime service is currently being developed. Consideration is being given to the compensation needs of both regular and reserve personnel. The benefits offered under this scheme will not be any less than those enjoyed under CERCA and will recognise the special characteristics of ADF service as they are relevant to compensation.

PARA.TAB: (3) Yes where possible.
(4) Due to limited funding for research, CSIRO seeks to obtain the best return on community investment by allocating resources to priority areas. This is the case in all sectors, not just energy.

Factors that are taken into account include size and growth prospects, importance to the nation, maturity of technology, industry support and infrastructure, how much impact research can have and what role CSIRO can play (relative to the expertise and capability of other research providers). In the energy efficiency field effort will go into both improving existing processes and utilisation (particularly in energy intensive industries and the built environment) and in developing and transferring technologies (for example advanced insulation, more efficient space heating and knowledge based control systems).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 January 1992: With reference to a question asked during the consideration of the Appropriation Bill on 16 October 1991, the Senate was told by the Minister that a replacement propeller shaft was supplied for the refit of HMAS Onslow.

PARA.TAB: (1) Were one or two propeller shafts replaced.
(2) What was the condition of the shaft (or shafts) prior to removal from the vessel.
(3) What was the condition of the shaft (or shafts) after removal.
(4) Why was it necessary to replace the shaft (or shafts).
(5) Is it correct that a propeller shaft is seldom replaced at refit.
(6) How many replacement propeller shafts have been supplied on earlier refits to vessels in the RAN Oberon fleet.
(7) What was the cost of the replacement shaft (or shafts).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Two shafts were replaced during the refit of HMAS Onslow.

(2) The Starboard tail shaft was known to be worn beyond limits prior to the commencement of HMAS Onslow's refit. There were no known defects on the Port tail shaft when the submarine began its refit and before routine docking surveys could be undertaken.

(3 and 4) Surveys after removal indicated that repairs were required to both Port and Starboard tail shafts. The preferred method of rectifying defective tail shafts is to replace them with refurbished items drawn from Naval Stores, and subsequently to refurbish the defective tail shafts for return to Naval Stores as servicable stock.

(5) Submarine tail shafts frequently require refurbishment at refit. The preferred procedure is to replace worn tail shafts with refurbished items if stock is available from Naval Stores. If refurbished spare tail shafts are not available, the worn tail shafts removed from the submarine will be refurbished during the refit and subsequently replaced in the submarine. It is not correct that tail shafts are seldom replaced at refit.
(6) Records from 1984 indicate that six tail shafts have been provided from Naval Stores to subma-

ANSWER.PARA: rines being refitted during time period 1985 to 1989. Information prior to 1984 would require archival research, and this will not be attempted as a result of the time and cost involved.

PARA.TAB: (7) Tail shafts provided for HMAS Onslow's refit were refurbished items from Naval Stores and were supplied as Government Furnished Equipment. The average cost of tail shaft refurbishment is $37,000, hence a total of approximately $74,000 was incurred.
